PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the ``Porn Capital'' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State Legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes particularly in the A.C.T., with the open sale and/or hire of only G, PG, and M-rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of R rated video-cassettes, so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated or ``N.V.E.'' rated video-cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard-core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted support to Senator Walter's Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 10 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That Australian Federal Police Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 139 and made under the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, be disallowed.
2. That the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1989 No. 150 and made under the Australian Telecommunications Corporations Act 1949, be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short explanation of the concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances as to these regulations.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1989 NO. 139

These Regulations provide for services that may be rendered by the Australian Federal Police at the request of, or under an agreement with, a member of the public or a body corporate; or in relation to a prescribed authority of the Commonwealth. The Committee is concerned about the privacy implications for these arrangements, as the services expressly include reporting on convictions, reporting on a check of fingerprints, and reporting on harassment, violence and threats of violence.
AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORPORATION REGULATIONS STATUTORY RULES 1989 NO. 150

These Regulations provide for circumstances where the duty imposed on Telecom employees not to disclose certain information gained in their course of employment, does not apply. The Committee is concerned about a provision which permits disclosure of ``the affairs or personal particulars'' of a person in certain circumstances.

(a) notes that the trial on a charge of murder of James Hudson Savage is due to begin in Florida on Friday October 6th 1989;

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(i) on Saturday, 30 September 1989, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) authorised some 50 Australian troops to be deployed as reinforcements for civilian police engaged in controlling a gathering of protesters at the US- controlled Nurrungar `Star Wars' ground stations or Joint Defence Facility,

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday, 28 September, Senator Crichton-Browne accused me of being at home having a nice week with dad and the kids, so I feel the need to explain to the Senate why I was not present in the chamber last week. This is the first time that I have applied for leave of absence from the Senate since the last Federal election. Many senators are legitimately absent from the Senate for various reasons, and I do not criticise them. For example, Senator Knowles was absent from the Senate last Friday, Senator McKiernan was absent last Friday, and Senators Durack and Coulter were due to speak at the same conference at which I was speaking in Perth on Wednesday, that is, the Pathways to the Future Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: Due to the difficulties with the pilots dispute I believe that many senators have been unable to move around as freely as they would like. It is a fact that senators choose from time to time to take up engagements in their electorates and, as a consequence, they are prepared to miss one parliamentary sitting day. That was obviously the case with Senator Durack, who was ready to speak at the conference in Perth last Wednesday, and also Senator Coulter. Neither of those senators actually made it to the conference in Perth due to the pilots dispute because they realised it would have taken up more time than they were prepared to be away from the Senate, I presume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vallentine sought leave to make a personal explanation in respect of a matter touching upon herself, not an explanation as to why other senators are here.
—Senator Vallentine, you were given leave to make a personal explanation. You are beginning to debate the issue. I ask you to stick to making a personal explanation.

—Right. The other point made by Senator Crichton-Browne as far as I was concerned was that I did not choose to travel on a VIP flight last Thursday to be present in Canberra. The fact is that I was not notified of the VIP flight leaving Perth. Again, I am not criticising other senators for their choices in these difficult times and I am not criticising Mr Beazley's officer, who is attempting to move people around the country during the pilots dispute. I was not notified of that VIP flight last Thursday. I could have chosen all day Thursday to make my way to Canberra, but I had an important meeting in Perth on Saturday. I then would have been in the same position as Senator Knowles and McKiernan, of having to fly on Friday to get back to Perth. I thought that was not a good use of my time. I believe it is very important to address constituents' issues. During the days that I was away from the Senate, I addressed over 800 people in two public meetings in Perth. I consider that to be very important.
—We all do that.
—Of course we all do that, but the point is that I am not criticising other people for their choices when they had difficulty making a decision because of the pilots dispute.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Has the honourable senator finished?
—No, I have not finished.

—My point of order is that a personal explanation is not really meant to be as fulsome as Senator Vallentine is making hers. She has made her point about why she was not here, and about Senator Crichton-Browne's claims, but it should not be debated at this point. Senator Vallentine should conclude her remarks.
—Senator Vallentine, I remind you again that it is a personal explanation. You should not debate the issue.

—I am quite happy to conclude my remarks. I would not be debating the matter at all if people were not interjecting. If I had been given the opportunity to speak I would have finished by now. I wish to conclude my remarks, Mr President.
—Order! Senator Vallentine, people are perfectly in order to take points of order. Finish your remarks.
—Thank you; I would like to do so. The fact is that the major parties in this place cannot bear an independent being in this place and there are constant attacks--
—Order! Senator Vallentine, resume your seat.
—There is constant personal abuse, and a denial of speakers' rights which was--
—Order! Senator Vallentine, I am ruling you out of order. Are there any papers to be tabled by--
—Mr President, it was a disgraceful display in this place yesterday when the two major parties colluded to prevent a debate--
—Order!
—This is typical of what is happening.
—Order! Resume your seat, Senator.
—This is typical of what is happening in this place--
—Senator Vallentine!
—The Independents and the minor parties are not given--
—Resume your seat!
—due rights to speak.
—Resume your seat!
—The fact is that the issue that was being debated yesterday in this place is a matter of concern to 37 per cent of people--
—Order! I name Senator Vallentine.

TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I will move the formal motion in a moment. But it is well known that Senator Vallentine was reading up half an hour ago on how to get thrown out of this chamber. Therefore, I will have to accommodate her. The President has named Senator Vallentine and I shall move that she be discharged from the service of the Senate for 24 hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, in the normal course of events the Opposition would support a motion of this kind to uphold the authority and dignity of the Chair. I do not dispute that the honourable senator in this case warranted being named by you. However, it is a pity if this can be done just as a stunt by the honourable senator. It is a pathetic abuse of the Senate that a senator should set herself up to be thrown out just to attract attention. There are other ways, other forms and procedures in this House that are available to the honourable senator. Were she here--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Resume your seat!
—Were she here to exercise her rights as a senator--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vallentine, resume your seat!
—It was a disgraceful exhibition yesterday when democracy was denied.
—Mr President, I do not wish to persist at length with my remarks because the senator is continuing her abuse--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine, I am asking you to resume your seat.
—I prefer to leave the chamber altogether because democracy is being denied.

—I would certainly like to make an explanation.
—An explanation or an apology?

—I am not going to apologise, Mr President. I apologise to you for the difficulty in terms of your job in chairing the Senate, so I do apologise to you personally for this inconvenience but I do not apologise to the Senate because I think that democracy has been denied in this place. That happened yesterday and it was not the first time. I am repeatedly left off speakers lists. I am repeatedly denied the opportunity to speak on the issues which I was elected to represent. I feel that it is very important, as a matter of principle, to state that democracy is being denied when a quorum is deliberately denied on a legitimate debate. This is a subject of very great importance to the people of Australia-37 per cent of the people of Australia want this topic debated fully. It was too embarrassing for the Government--
—Order! Senator Vallentine--
—and the Opposition to have that issue debated fully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its cooperation. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:
(a) notes that a quorum was not present during debate on a matter of public importance on 3 October 1989, and as a result the Senate was counted out;

(b) notes that the matter of public importance in question was the action of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in calling in the ADF to deal with the situation at Nurrungar over the weekend: that is, the use of Australian troops against Australian citizens on Australian soil in defence of a US military base which ties Australia into the nuclear war-fighting strategies of the US Government;

(c) notes that the Government would have good cause not to want a motion of this kind debated because of its implications for the way in which the Government is dealing with the issue of public concern about the role of the Nurrungar monitoring base;

(d) notes the actions of Senator McKiernan in the Senate Chamber on 3 October 1989 when the quorum bells were being rung, in signalling to Senators approaching the Chamber not to enter it, thereby discouraging or preventing the formation of a quorum;

(e) considers that the conduct of Senator McKiernan was an abuse of the parliamentary processes which provided, in accordance with Standing Orders, for the matter of public importance to be debated in the Senate; and
(f) censures Senator McKiernan for his actions in abusing the parliamentary processes of the Senate.

I think it is very important that a motion of this sort is brought on as quickly as possible after the events around which it centres. There is a significant question involved here of abuse of procedures by an officer of the Australian Labor Party, the government party, who should have known better. His actions in causing the abuse of the Senate are a matter for censure in this motion and it is something that this place needs to take particularly seriously and to debate expeditiously. If this sort of thing is to continue to happen, I suspect that we may have to follow the example of the House of Commons and abolish the right of individual senators to call a count. That has not been a practice in the House of Commons since 1971, I presume for fairly good reason. I can only assume that what was happening in the House of Commons is what is happening here more and more, especially recently, and that is that quorums are called quite frivolously and frequently more as a matter of disrupting procedures and interrupting a speaker than simply to assure the Senate that there is the appropriate number of senators in or around the place.

Mr President, quite an extraordinary event occurred in the Senate yesterday. A debate on a matter of public importance was brought to a very premature close. It was closed before the mover of the motion, the first speaker, had even finished addressing the motion and the Senate was forced to adjourn for lack of a quorum. Neither the Opposition, which called the quorum that led to the count-out when only two of its senators were in the chamber at the time, nor the Government, which actively through the actions of its Whip encouraged its senators to stay out of the chamber, has anything to be proud of. It was not only an appalling action; it was also a very bad precedent indeed to be setting, and a very bad comment, I think, to the people of Australia about how senators perceive their role in this place and what importance they give to a sensible debate in this place.

I am reminded of the fact that last Wednesday somebody asked me why I was planning to leave an intelligent debating chamber like the Senate to go into what passes roughly for a zoo in the House of Representatives. I would have thought that anybody who believed that the Senate was a considered debating chamber where the rules were observed would have changed that opinion after yesterday's events. The Opposition has, in less than the last 24 hours, claimed that it was accidental, that it did not really mean this to happen. This makes one wonder, of course, why an Opposition member called the quorum in the first place. The Government of course has tried to justify its action by claiming that it wanted to bring events to a close here quickly in order to get on with Estimates committees. This raises the additional question of why Opposition members were prepared to sit back last Tuesday and last Thursday-both of which were Estimates days-and take part in a debate on the pilots strike brought on as a matter of public importance by the Opposition and not to get in the way of Senator Lewis indulging in an adjournment debate on Thursday. I think a little consistency, as well as some reasonable behaviour in this place, may not go amiss.

We all know why quorums are called in this place. They are called for a variety of reasons. Occasionally it may be that a speaker who is listed to speak is caught out by the fact that the previous speaker finished earlier than anticipated, is not in his place in the Senate, and the party to which he belongs wants to give him the opportunity to come here. That seems to be not a particularly excessive abuse of the use of quorums.

They are also, of course, called, and called much more frequently for this purpose than the previous one, in order to interrupt a speaker, probably for two reasons-to try to divert that person's train of thought to put him at a disadvantage, presumably in the hope that he will forget what he was going to say anyway and move on to something else. It also, of course, takes four minutes out of that individual's speaking time and that is the major reason why oppositions call quorums. It tends also to be Opposition members who call quorums when they are listening to a speech, the contents of which they do not support. That is, of course, why nobody ever calls a quorum when a member of his own party is speaking, no matter how few other senators there are in the chamber.

It is a device used increasingly not to ensure that we have the required 26 senators in this place, but to interrupt a speech and, more importantly, to take time away from a speaker's allotted period of time which varies according to the sort of debate we are involved in and, therefore, to give that speaker less time to put forward an argument. This was particularly important yesterday given the nature of the debate and given the fact that 20 minutes is the amount of time allocated for the lead speaker in a matter of public importance debate rather than the normal 30 minutes that is allocated to a second reading stage speech or to a debate of the kind that we are currently engaged in.

Senator Jenkins was on her feet speaking as the mover of the motion relating to Nurrungar. The first quorum that was called on her was called about seven or eight minutes into that 20 minutes; the count and the ringing of the bells took up four or five minutes. Approximately three minutes later a second quorum was called but two Opposition senators had left the chamber. That took another four minutes out of her speaking time, leaving her with very little time to mount the argument that she was going to put. Had the House not been counted out, as it was at that stage, something like six Labor and Opposition members would have had their full time to speak to rebut an argument that she had been unable to put in its entirety.

Yesterday's debate on Nurrungar-its existence, its purpose, the peaceful protests there over the weekend, the actions taken by the police in using mace and by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in calling in the troops-was clearly not to the liking of either the Government or the Opposition. What Senator Jenkins was saying, the issues she was raising and the questions she was asking were all clearly things both Government and Opposition senators preferred not to hear and which they did not want raised publicly-questions of who authorised the troops to be brought in; what authority the South Australian police had to act inside the base and who gave them that authority; why security was apparently as light as it was; why the Government argued that something terribly secret and meaningful could be discovered by the protesters if they got inside the base; and why, therefore, it was necessary to take the sort of action that the Minister for Defence took.

The point needed to be raised as to just exactly what Nurrungar is all about. Is it merely an insignificant part of the verification procedure which, of course, would have accounted for the fact that security was so light but which would not have accounted for the draconian measures taken either by the South Australian police or by the Minister for Defence in bringing in troops? If, however, that action was felt to be necessary, quite clearly Nurrungar was more than the Government has been saying, namely, a low key verification system. It was quite clearly then something far more important in the scheme of Star Wars, making it quite possibly a first strike base. Then one has to ask why the base was not more properly secured.

Those questions were obviously the sort that the Opposition did not want raised and that the Government did not wish to have to answer. So twice during the first 15 or so minutes of the debate the Opposition called a quorum. On the first occasion, a sufficient number of senators answered the quorum bells for the debate to continue. The second time, through a neat and timely piece of collusion between the Government and the Opposition, too few people came into the chamber and, indeed, some were actively discouraged from entering by the party Whip. What clearly happened was that the Government saw the opportunity presented to it by the Opposition and grabbed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Leader of the Australian Democrats has just alleged collusion between the Government and the Opposition with respect to withholding of a quorum. One of the points I made when I suggested that Senator Haines should not speak on her motion to suspend Standing Orders was that she might talk herself out of our support. I must say that I take particular exception to Senator Haines making that allegation when I have given her, her Deputy Leader and her Whip the clearest possible personal assurance that there was no collusion between the Government and the Opposition. And I repeat that now. In those circumstances, I find the statement unparliamentary. It is certainly thoroughly objectionable to me and to the Opposition and I seek for it to be withdrawn.
—Order! There is no point of order. Under the Standing Orders, it is a debating point which Senator Haines made.

—Thank you, Mr President. Whether Senator Chaney believes that there was collusion or not, I would point out that collusion does not have to be willing. The simple fact of the matter, as I continue to say, is that the opportunity was presented and the Government took it. The fact is that had the opportunity not been presented the Government would not have been in a position to act upon it. The Opposition provided the weapon and the Government used it and that is quite simply what occurred yesterday. The Opposition gave the Government the opportunity to take action which is almost unprecedented in this place-to call a debate to a premature close by willingly excluding its members from the chamber. Before the second quorum was called, all remaining senators except Senator Knowles and Senator Newman, who called the quorum, left the chamber. If that is not providing a neat opportunity and begging for it to be picked up, I do not know what is. We do not need to have an overt conspiracy for there to be a conspiracy of interests and that certainly is what we saw here yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: The second quorum was able to be counted out because there were too few Opposition senators in here, several of whom I saw in the passage moving away from the door when they realised that it was a quorum. Honourable senators should ask Senator Durack how close he got to the door yesterday before he turned around and went away again. There was at least one Liberal Party senator in my view who got to the door during the ringing of those bells and turned around again. In case we hear that oft repeated remark that it is the responsibility of the Government to maintain a quorum in this place, may I remind honourable senators that Odgers makes it perfectly clear that it is the responsibility of the Senate as a whole to maintain a quorum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't quote that scab Odgers.
—Senator Schacht does not like me referring to a previous Clerk of this place whose Australian Senate Practice is--
—Senator Haines will ignore the interjections.

—According to Australian Senate Practice, which is what we usually observe in this place, it is the requirement of the Senate as a whole to maintain the numbers in this place. Therefore, individual senators cannot excuse themselves from involvement in all of this. In any event, as it happened, the Government was busy excluding its own senators with Senator McKiernan standing part way between the Democrat benches and the Hansard table, making hand signals to those Labor senators who were about to come in the glass doors and hustling them out. Indeed, those senators were still hovering around the corridors and passages after the Senate had been counted out.

SPEECH.PARA: What we saw in here yesterday was, in fact, an absolute travesty. What a way to run a supposedly democratic institution-keeping people out of the chamber in which debate is supposed to take place. Anyone in Australia who thought there was still a shred of commitment to free debate, democratic expression of opinion and civilised rules of behaviour in this Parliament, has been disabused of that belief as of yesterday. To stop a legitimate debate on Nurrungar, the Government was prepared to use the childish behaviour of the Opposition in calling quorums to manufacture an adjournment. It should not try to argue that it was because Estimates committees were being held up. Estimates committees were held up last week, on both days on which they sat. In any event, the primary responsibility of this chamber is to debate issues as they arise. That is why we have standing order 64. Opportunities are listed daily on the Senate Notice Paper for individual senators to raise matters of public importance.

If it was good enough last week to hold up Estimates committees for a debate on the pilots strike, it was certainly good enough this week to hold up Estimates committees in order to debate the events at Nurrungar over the weekend.

I point out that early in the morning we made an offer to the Government to limit that debate to four speakers. That is not abnormal in this place. We quite frequently make agreements between the parties to put a speaker aside or to curtail debate in order for other business to be brought on.

I think the personal invective that has been directed at another senator in this place, Senator Vallentine, indicates just how much personalities come into what is supposed to be a rational behaviour pattern in this chamber. How can we, as representatives of the electorate, claim to be upholding democratic processes if we allow the sorts of procedures that happened yesterday to occur, if abuse is hurled across the chamber at somebody simply because another senator's views are different from those held by others in this place? I thought the whole democratic electoral system was about allowing a diversity of opinions to be expressed in this place without people being hounded either in the chamber or out of the chamber.

The electorate, I would have thought, had the right to expect behaviour of senators in this place that was a little above kindergarten level, yet that is what we have seen here today and yesterday. People have drowned out other speakers and the device of counting the Senate out has been used to curtail a debate. What we saw yesterday was a gag, pure and simple, and one to which the Opposition, despite its ritual protests about gags and guillotines in the past, was at least an accessory. Had it not called for quorums to be formed, the Government would not have been able to engineer the adjournment of the Senate. Indeed, had Liberal and National Party senators answered the quorum call in any numbers, instead of hovering in passages and lobbies, as Government senators were doing, the business of the Senate would have proceeded.

I understand that Senator Knowles tried to convince at least one person from the Channel 10 Good Morning Australia program yesterday afternoon that it all happened because Liberal senators did not have time to come back to the chamber. That was what I was told by the person at Channel 10 to whom she alleged to have spoken. Her colleagues, it was claimed, had all gone to meetings and did not have time to get back for the second quorum call. It seems to me that if that is what Senator Knowles said, it simply compounds the nonsense that went on yesterday. The reason we extended the time for which the bells would be rung for a quorum when we moved into this enormous building, from three minutes, which was the case in the old House, to four minutes here, was so that people could get from the furthest place in this building to the Senate chamber without missing a division or a quorum call.

TALK.START.PARA: —How often do you answer the quorum bells, Senator Haines?
—I make it a habit to answer quorum calls, Senator, and I will continue to answer quorum calls. I think as the leader of a political party in this place it is my responsibility to act responsibly.
—How many Democrats came into the chamber yesterday in response to the quorum call?

—Senator Stone asked me how many Democrat senators answered the call. Six out of seven Democrat senators were in this place in answer to that quorum call, compared with two Opposition senators at the beginning of the call, and I think another five later. I have not checked the names that were listed a little later; certainly there were considerably fewer than the 34 senators that the Liberal and National parties have between them. As for the argument that they did not have time to get back from wherever they were, we allowed four minutes for movement in this place for a division or a quorum to ensure that, no matter where people were, unless they got stuck in a lift or unless their bells were wired the wrong way around, both of which have happened in this place, they would have the opportunity to get from wherever they were to here if they wanted to. The fact is that they did not want to, so that at least is a nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who argues, as I said earlier, that it is the role of the Government to maintain a quorum is asserting something that is simply not supported under the rules. I refer people to Odgers on page 196 of Australian Senate Practice in which he states quite clearly that that responsibility rests with the Senate. That includes those honourable senators lurking in passageways and lobbies. Indeed, in the House of Commons, when quorum calls were still allowed, the very fact that members were standing in corridors near the chamber was given as sufficient reason for the Presiding Officer not to make a count, especially if the reason for calling the quorum was deemed to be frivolous.

If we pride ourselves on following the precedents established by the House of Commons-by and large that is what we do-there is no doubt at all in my mind, first of all, that the second quorum, called as it was so quickly after the first one during Senator Jenkins's speech on Nurrungar, was frivolous, and probably malicious as well, although that does not rate a mention by Odgers, and, secondly, that there were sufficient people hanging about in the lobbies or corridors around this chamber for the numbers to have been made up. The precedent from the House of Commons could-I will not go as far as saying should-have been followed and the Acting Deputy President could have refused to make a count the second time a quorum was called. He did not and so the farce continued.

Clearly, the aim of the Opposition in calling quorums was to prevent Senator Jenkins from speaking, or at least from speaking for her full time. The Government used this tactic to end the debate altogether, at least for that day. It was possible, of course, under the Standing Orders for the whole thing to be re-run from the point at which it finished. But that, I think, was superseded by the abuse of procedure that we saw happen in this place yesterday. By deliberately discouraging Labor senators from entering the chamber, the Labor Whip abused the normal procedures of this place and the normal procedures of his office. The reason parliaments have Whips is in order to get as many people as are required where they should be. In the case of quorums and divisions honourable senators should be present when required. We allow pairing, certainly, and the Whips ensure that that is maintained. The only people who have any justification at all for not being in the Senate chamber for either a quorum call or a division are those who are absent or who have been paired.

To see Senator McKiernan standing in the middle of this Senate chamber actively waving Labor senators out of this place or away from this place was one of the most astonishing things that we have ever run into in this place. As for the behaviour of Opposition and Labor senators in effectively gagging a debate on a matter which is of considerable concern to the people of Australia, I can say only that, if that is their attitude to democracy, we are going very much the way of dictatorships and banana republics. We all know what the numbers do in this place: if one has the numbers one wins; if one does not have them, one loses. But to have a gag imposed in this way is, I think, unique to this House since Federation. That means that we have seen officers of political parties in this place, and the Senate as a whole, hit the depths of propriety and challenge the very reason for having a Senate, having a parliament, having debating opportunities for individual senators, and indeed groups of senators for that matter-opportunities presented to them under the Standing Orders so that they can raise matters of importance to themselves and to the country.

Senator McKiernan is deserving of censure for the part that he played yesterday in ensuring that there were not sufficient numbers in this Senate to ensure that the debate and the proceedings of this chamber could continue. But the Opposition is not without blame in that it provided, wittingly or unwittingly-and in the case of Opposition members I sometimes wonder where their wits are anyway-the Government with the opportunity to use that particular gag procedure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on 2 October an article in the Melbourne Herald quotes Senator Norm Sanders, sitting up the back there, as saying that he is a great fan of bogong moths. He goes on to say `the moth symbolises the ineffectuality of much that happens in Parliament House'. He must have been talking about Senator Janine Haines's performance today, because this morning is stunt morning. First of all, Senator Vallentine reads up Odgers' Australian Senate Practice on how to get thrown out of this place. She then comes in, almost gets thrown out, has Senator Chaney intervene, but then carries on again and in the end we all had to throw her out. So that was the first part of stunt morning.

SPEECH.PARA: We also knew that this motion was probably coming up and that a further stunt would be run. But I do not criticise that. A bit of group therapy is always good for everyone; we need a circuit breaker in this place. When we are arguing with each other and things get very heated, a censure motion or something like this washes the slate fairly clean, and after a few hours of grumbling we can get back to negotiating, talking to each other and no-one bears a grudge more than a day or two. So the motion that Senator Haines has moved today is very much a healing motion rather than a disruptive one.

But let me go back and put a few truths on the record in case anyone was misled by the very smarmy speech by Senator Haines. First of all we were operating yesterday under threats. Because we would not put poor little Senator Vallentine on the speaking list-she being one out of 76 in this chamber-we were threatened with disruption by that senator. That was the first operating principle that we were operating under yesterday, because we would not put Senator Vallentine on one of her pet projects. Independents in this chamber get a better run than anyone else. They get extra staff; they get phones to their desks; they get consulted. I pity some of the poor backbenchers on both sides here; they never get the same amount of speaking time or the run that Independents get in this place. So let us hear none of talk about the `poor old Independents'. They get a damned good run in this place, and Senator Vallentine, because she did not get her way once, threatened yesterday to disrupt this chamber.

Now I turn to the second great hypocrisy, and coming from Senator Haines it was a beauty. Does she deny that she approached me in the past suggesting a quorum be called in this place to have it collapse. Of course she has. I specifically remember the time and her speech to me on that subject. So she has done that in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I would not mind Senator Ray crossing his t's and dotting his i's on this one and telling the Senate and me just on what occasions I have ever asked for a quorum to be called to count the House out. In fact, on a number of occasions--
—Order! Senator Haines, that is not a point of order and there are appropriate forms for you to claim that you have been misrepresented later.

—Mr President, that could have been put to me in two contexts. I will say this for Senator Haines. It could have been a sort of a flibbertigibbet comment in the corridors as she passed me by; I took it seriously at the time. They come in here and say `This is unprecedented'. This place has been deliberately counted out three or four times in my memory. I remember the Carrick government trying to count the place out over the Tasmanian forest issue, at around about 7 or 7.15 at night. Senator Haines would remember that. The Democrats and the Labor Party kept the quorum. On the adjournment, this place has been counted out deliberately before. So there is no precedent involved here, and again I say I can remember that conversation. One of the only abilities I have is a good memory, and I can remember the conversation she had with me-`Oh, get someone to call a quorum and count the joint out so we can all go home'. And then she came in here today wanting to censure another senator for something she has done herself.

SPEECH.PARA: I really should relate the history of this matter of public importance, because it is a very interesting one. I was sitting in my office yesterday and in came a matter of public importance dated 3 October 1979 from Senator Vallentine. I took some notice of the fact that someone had managed to whack it in 10 years ago for discussion that day. But it was in Senator Vallentine's name. Let us have the truth about what happened in the following two hours. I do not know, but let us postulate what happened. They got dirty over there in the Democrats and said, `You can't pinch our key plank; it's our turn to bring forward an MPI'. What happened? The same matter of public importance-it had the same wording-appeared under the name of Senator Jenkins. The same matter appeared, word for word. That happened because Senator Jenkins and Senator Vallentine are key poll rivals in the Western Australian Senate election next year, and the Democrats needed priority. I do not blame them; there are more of them here. They have been on these issues longer than the Johnnies-come-lately on the opposite side. So what did they do? They pinched the matter of public importance. How did they do it? I postulate: Did they threaten? Do they deny that they threatened not to stand in their places and leave only two people standing for this debate? Of course they did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have another go.

—I have been asked to have another go. Hypnosis is the only other suggestion I can make. Surely Senator Macklin cannot say, through the eloquence of his Leader, that he convinced poor little Senator Vallentine to give up the thing.
—It was collusion.

—Senator Knowles says that it was collusion. Never! So we had this sorry spectacle yesterday of the peace camp and the Parliament totally at war with each other. Who had the monopoly right over peace? Who had the monopoly right to discuss these issues? Senator Haines said that we were not willing to debate this matter. Let me say that we put up eight speakers. We were happy to have eight speakers, not four, as the suggestion went. Every Government speaker-Senator Schacht, Senator McMullan and I-was here throughout the debate. We had spent time preparing for this debate and had had briefings. We were quite happy to have the debate, as it looked like it was going to transpire. We were sure that we were going to come right over the top of those opposite and belt the living daylights out of the rubbish they were putting forward. So I do not accept the charge that this place collapsed on the basis that we were afraid on this issue. We are not afraid on this issue at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move to the Government's duty on quorums. In general it is our duty to maintain the quorum in this place-not the Opposition's; not the Democrats'. That is a very strenuous problem at the moment. As I have had to point out in this chamber before-not that it relates to yesterday's events-the quorum is 26. We have 32 members in this chamber, including the President and nine Ministers. So not even the back bench can maintain a quorum in this place. Quorums are a second problem inasmuch as the time it takes to get from the Executive wing to here-as most people who have been to my office would know-is three minutes. Quite often when quorums are being called one can have a meeting that one has brought people from all round Australia for and talk to them for 10 minutes out of the hour that was allocated. But there is a precedent that says that the Government does not always have to keep a quorum. We know that those circumstances existed in the past. In a moment I will come to whether or not the precedent was justified yesterday. But there is a precedent for the particular actions of the Government.

Let me move to another ridiculous point. Senator Haines alleges that there was collusion. Senator Haines must be as blind as a bat if she did not see the reaction on this side of the chamber when the first quorum was called, when virtually four minutes of Senator Jenkins's speech was disrupted. We on this side all reacted with anger to the calling of that quorum, because we could see what was about to happen; we are going to have three quorums during Senator Jenkins's speech. She was allocated 20 minutes. Because she takes so long to wind up in a speech, she had not even reached the main subject yesterday. So we were going to have 20 minutes, 12 minutes of which was going to be taken up by quorum time and a build up, never getting to the substance of the thing. A lot of us said, `Well, that's enough; why should we have to put up with this?'.
Let me move to the second point made by Senator Haines. Senator Haines says the Liberals left the chamber.
Senator Jenkins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins has given some good speeches here, but the one she made yesterday was not the most inspiring. If I were not on duty, I would have left too. There is no evidence to suggest that the conservatives on the other side left the chamber for the purpose of calling a quorum. I think there were about 11 or 12 people here at the time. Therefore, there was no need for one or two to leave if we wanted to call a quorum for any particular point. Again, I think that was just a bit of dross in respect of the honourable senator's speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The question has been raised about Estimates committees. I want to spend some time on this because this was central to our thinking. Note that I use the word `our'-not Senator McKiernan's-thinking on this subject. When a second quorum was called, we said, `Well, why should we be dragging people all over the building for the rest of the afternoon?', knowing that the two hours that Senator Jenkins had deliberately decided to take up yesterday-she took it off Senator Vallentine-would be added to the time taken last night by the Estimates committees. It is well known that Estimates Committee B went to 2 o'clock in the morning. Estimates Committee C finished at 10.30, mostly because the Minister concerned was ill. It probably would have gone longer, but in deference to the Minister the Committee was able to cooperate and get its work done.

It is all very well for people to come and say, `We're going to add in an MPI'. I noticed Senator Jenkins at an Estimates committee meeting yesterday; I was most appreciative of the fact that she was attending out of hours, so I do not lay this charge against her. But it is basically members of the Government and the Opposition who have to sit here till 2 o'clock in the morning while the rest snuggle up at home sound asleep, getting their beauty sleep. This issue could have been raised today by way of a matter of public importance or, I guess, on the adjournment. But a whole series of events convinced the Government that it was not worth keeping a quorum in this place: firstly, a desire to get the Estimates committees under way; secondly, the unseemly spectacle earlier in the day of the two peace groups going to war over who would get the matter of public importance; and, thirdly, what a waste of time it was going to be if nearly every speech, except for the side that calls quorums, was going to have eight or nine minutes taken out. We do not call quorums. So, Senator Jenkins was going to have 10 minutes out of 20 and I would probably have got 10 minutes out of 20. It was becoming a pointless exercise and I do believe that the use of quorums in those circumstances is unjustified.

The calling of quorums is justified under a number of banners-usually someone is not here, someone is being particularly obnoxious or someone is being punished for a prior offence. But just to use it to cut eight or so minutes out of a substantial speech reduces this chamber to nothing more than a farce. The moment someone puts a lucid argument and makes points, what happens? A quorum is called, the debate is interrupted and this chamber does become extremely ineffectual.

Senator Haines said, `People ask me why I am leaving this intelligent chamber and going to a less intelligent chamber', but then went on to berate the intelligence of this chamber. I am not going to go through her motives as to why she is leaving this chamber. We will leave that for another time and another debate. But, really, the intelligence of this chamber varies. When it is good, it is very good and when it is bad, it is awful. So far in five weeks we have amended one piece of legislation-a health Bill-to such an extent as probably to render it useless. We have done nothing else, and on we wander. So do not--

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC debate has been serious and worth while.

—Yes, we have a serious debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, but we can never seem to get to it. I do not allege conspiracy or filibuster-I just believe that we are struck down with bad luck on the ATSIC Bill; just bad luck! It is like the string of nine premiership losses suffered by Collingwood, Mr President-just a bit of bad luck on the way through!

SPEECH.PARA: I come only to the final point before I sum up. I find the latter part of this motion quite strange. First of all, it alleges that the conduct of Senator McKiernan was an abuse of the parliamentary process. This chamber will probably agree with that-no court of law would; no court of law would take notice of a couple of hand signals. For all the honourable senators opposite know, and we know better, a good defence lawyer would say that he was trying to swat a few bogong moths when he was waving his hands. Nor does it know and nor has it assumed correctly that it was Senator McKiernan alone that made that decision. Quite clearly it was not.

I urge that if this motion is carried my name be placed at least at equal billing with my good colleague from Western Australia, because it will be well deserved. I am pretty miffed that I have not been censured yet. After all, we would censure anything. Lately, if one moves in this chamber one gets censured. It is the latest stunt. If a Minister does not answer a question, he gets censured. What honourable senators have done, of course, as I have pointed out before, has totally devalued the censure motion. A fluid combination of opportunistic numbers decides that X will be censured or Y will be censured. Occasionally a clever move will be made, such as one by Senator Macklin a few weeks ago, who stymied two censure motions in one go by including both sides of the chamber. Once again, it just depends on the fluidity of the numbers. The censure motion means absolutely nothing.

On point five, and certainly on point two, Senator McKiernan was not abusing the parliamentary processes of the Senate. That has not been established. Anyone who votes for the motion does this place a disservice because that has not been established here. The processes of the Senate have been variable in the past. Both the Carrick led Senate team in 1982 and, on at least three occasions, the Government have deliberately cut short the sitting. No censure motions were moved on any of those occasions. But because the peaceniks-the Democrats-have got a bit miffed, they want a bit of group therapy, they want a circuit breaker put in. What happens? They censure poor old Senator McKiernan. We can see how distraught he is at the prospect of being censured. It is a legitimate tactic open to the Government, one it would not use very often, but one which I think we used under provocation yesterday.

I sum up by saying that this was not preplanned. We had all our speakers ready for this debate and we were quite confident that we were going to give the Democrats a creaming. Whether that confidence was justified, we will never know, or we may find out next time the matter comes up. There was no collusion between the Government and the Opposition, none whatsoever. Our decision was made on the spot; whether it is right or wrong we are sticking with it as a decision. Senator Haines may deny that she suggested to me once that we could call a quorum and collapse the Senate. All I can say is that that is my clear memory of a conversation I once had with her. I ask the rest of the Democrats whether any of them has ever suggested the place be collapsed by way of quorum. Senator McLean says no. Senator Macklin is trying to search his memory. Probably he is pretty certain that he did too. They are willing to put on the record a censure of a senator for something they have contemplated or suggested themselves. History will judge Senator McKiernan to be a more consistent person, if this motion is carried, than the Democrat senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the general thrust of this motion, although it will move an amendment in relation to the latter part of it. Before I do that I want to put on record something about the behaviour of the sanctimonious Democrats in relation to quorums and count-outs. The last time this place was counted out was on 1 June 1988. On that occasion 23 senators were present at the time of the count-out. Not one single member of the Australian Democrats was present. The time before that was on 10 December 1987. There were 23 senators present at the time of the count-out. Senator Coulter was here; not one other single member of the Australian Democrats was present. The time before that was 19 February 1986. There were 18 senators at the time of the count-out. Senator Vigor was present. He probably had been there since the bells rang for prayers that morning, but not one other member of the Australian Democrats was present. The time before that was 29 May 1985. There were 25 senators present at the time of the count-out, and not one single Australian Democrat. The previous occasion when this occurred was on 21 May 1985. There were 14 senators present at the time of the count-out, and not one single Australian Democrat was present.

SPEECH.PARA: On the last five occasions that the Senate has been counted out for want of a quorum, since May 1985, Senator Haines and Senator Macklin were not present for one of those last five count-outs. When we come to the question of who actually turns up to answer those quorum bells, if we look at each of those occasions when quorums have been called in the last couple of years, we will find that it has been the Opposition parties which have consistently attempted to keep the quorums in this place. On 1 June 1988-as I say, 23 senators were present at the time of the count-out-of the 23 senators present, 21 were members of the Liberal and National parties; the other two were the President, occupying the chair, and the Whip, Senator McKiernan, who was on duty in the chamber at the time. During the previous count-out, of the 23 senators present, 16 were members of the Liberal and National parties and two were members of the independent group-Senator Vallentine and Senator Wood. It must have been an odd day because it was after 10.30 p.m. and Senator Vallentine was still here, so there must have been something in particular going on at the time.

These examples simply reflect on the moral outrage shown by Senator Haines today, because on the five previous occasions when the Senate has been counted out, Senator Haines's name does not appear in the Journals of the Senate as having attended to her responsibilities in the terms that she has described today-her deep and abiding commitment to answer quorum bells whenever she hears them rung. I do not know, like Joan of Arc, what sorts of bells or voices Senator Haines responds to these days, but if she wants to put herself at the stake, like Joan of Arc, on these particular issues, we are perfectly happy to accommodate her.

Senator Ray has not done much better. We know that these days in the United States when one faces a murder charge one can plead the so-called `twinkies defence', `I was affected by eating junk food, Your Honour; I am not responsible for my actions'. Senator Ray has introduced into this chamber the latest version of that, the bogong defence: `It was the moths that done it'. As far as poor old Senator McKiernan was concerned, all he was doing was waving at these poor little creatures as they moved about the table; it was not so much a matter of `out, out, damned spot' as `out, out, damned moth', and all of the poor benighted members of the Labor Party gazing like waifs through the glass doors thought in fact that they were being instructed to go away when in fact it was only the moths who were the centre of Senator McKiernan's attention in this matter. The bogong defence will have, I suspect, its run on many occasions because it has now become a term of art that Senator Ray has introduced in this matter.

I want to go, however, to a couple of the substantive points raised in relation to the alleged collusion between the Government and the Opposition to count out the Senate yesterday. Collusion is defined in the dictionary as `a secret agreement for a fraudulent purpose or a conspiracy'. I say to the chamber quite directly that there was no discussion of, collusion in, assistance with, or facilitation of the Government's desire to adjourn the Senate yesterday on the part of the Opposition; far from it. In exactly the same way as Senator Ray has indicated the Government's interest in debating the matter of public importance, the Opposition parties, when originally presented by the Democrats and by Senator Vallentine with a speakers list of four people-a Democrat, Senator Vallentine, one from the Government and one from the Opposition-regarded that as so totally unacceptable that we insisted, as did the Government, on having a proper debate. We had Senators Newman, Tambling and MacGibbon ready to participate in that debate.

We regarded it as an outrage that parties representing Senator Vallentine's couple of per cent and the Democrats couple of per cent of the vote, should believe that they were entitled to 50 per cent of the speakers on an important and significant matter touching on our national security and defence. It was, in fact, very much at our insistence that the debate was expanded and provision was made for three Opposition speakers on that particular matter. We were ready for that debate, willing to participate in it and looking forward to participating in it.

As to the actual matter of the quorum and the messages sent out, may I say to the Senate that on the second occasion that the quorums were called, a message was put on the pager by our Whips in these terms: senators required to make quorum. It was only at that stage that it became apparent to a large number of people that there was an attempt on the part of the Government to close down the chamber yesterday. That message that Opposition senators were required to attend the Senate to keep the quorum was placed on the paging system by the Opposition Whip and senators were summoned to the chamber. Senator Knowles has quite rightly explained the difficulties that were occasioned as far as that was concerned and the fact that there was a failure on the part of the Government to honour its obligations to keep the numbers in the chamber. In fact, this led to the chamber being closed down.

Now I make a couple of points in relation to the general thrust of this motion. The first parts of the motion-that is to say, paragraphs (a), (b) and (c)-are parts of the motion that the Opposition parties will support. We believe that it is important to establish that the count-out is not a device to be used by either a one-party majority or a majority consisting of the Government and the Democrats or the Opposition and the Democrats-whatever it happens to be-to prevent the minority parties or any individual senator from properly participating in the debates and exercising their rights to speak in this chamber. It is important that the quorum and the count-out should not be seen as a device to actually terminate parliamentary debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the quorums that were used yesterday to take eight minutes out of a 20-minute speech?

—Senator Ray makes the point about the use of quorums during particular debates. If senators believe that matters which are to be brought before the chamber are of such compelling interest that, in fact, they command wide attention, then, in fact, it is quite legitimate for people to be summoned to the Senate chamber to listen to them. That device is a legitimate one. As Senator Chaney rightly points out, it has been the practice of the Labor Party in government to empty this chamber whenever possible of Government representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray will recall that the other day, during the course of a debate on a piece of legislation regarding pharmacy, I had to draw attention to the fact that there was not a single Minister present in the chamber. Senator Ray had to make arrangements to find a Minister to come into the chamber. It is frequently the case that when we open in the morning with prayers, the Labor Party members do not turn up. The Labor Party deliberately keeps the chamber as threadbare of numbers as is possible. It is a proper and legitimate device to ensure that people will come to the chamber to observe what is required in terms of duty in the chamber. But the count-out, as a deliberate device to stifle and prevent a minority viewpoint being expressed, is not a legitimate device. We do not accept it as a legitimate device and it is for that reason that we believe the first part of the motion should be supported.

We, however, accept the argument put forward by Senator Ray that Senator McKiernan was merely an agent acting under instructions from his weightier leader and, in fact, he was simply part of a conspiracy-a collusion between himself and Senator Ray-for the purpose of facilitating what the Government saw to be the business of the day. We will therefore move that paragraphs (d), (e) and (f) be deleted from the motion and the following substituted in place thereof:
(d) notes that it is the clear responsibility of the Government and its Whips to maintain the quorum in the Senate and censures the Government and its Whips for their failure to do so.
That, I believe, is the correct procedure. It accommodates Senator Ray's desire for a bit of self-flagellation in the matter and we are happy to include it in the terms of the censure motion.

I make the point in conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we were prepared to participate, and indeed were participating, in the debate which took place. The decision to close down the chamber was clearly made by the Government as a strategic decision. When it became apparent to us that that was the tactic, our Whips took necessary steps to attempt to notify the people in our parties that they should report to the chamber. Indeed, in the chamber at the time of the count-out were both the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, and his deputy, Senator Lewis, so those people most adjacent to the chamber and those people with the senior responsibilities in the chamber attended as soon as a message was made available to them by the Whips. In fact, our Whips were here and Senator Newman, the next speaker in the debate, was present at that particular time. So I make that point: we wanted the debate to continue; we regarded it of sufficient importance to have taken the necessary steps to ensure it was not simply restricted to the Democrats, Senator Vallentine and one speaker a side from the major parties in the chamber.

I make the point that we do not believe that the count-out is a legitimate weapon to be used to prevent minorities or individual senators from expressing their point of view. It has been a deliberate strategy on the part of the Government to keep the numbers of Ministers and Labor Party senators in the chamber to a minimum. We object to that and we have used the quorum as a device to make sure that that is not something which goes without being noted.

I make the point that the Democrats' own record of attendance in the Senate when the count-out has previously taken place is absolutely appalling. Let me repeat that record. It needs to be on the record. On 1 June 1988, not a single Democrat was present; on 10 December 1987, Senator Coulter was present; on 18 February 1986, Senator Vigor was present; on 29 May 1985, not a single Democrat was present; and on 21 May 1985, not a single Democrat was present. Not on any of those occasions was Senator Haines present-not once. In terms of the matter before us that needs to be put into the perspective in the way I have done.

I believe that the arguments which have been put forward by Senator Haines in relation to her excuses about collusion are quite unsustainable. I note for the record, Senator Ray having made it perfectly clear, that the idea of the use of the count-out as an illegitimate device to close down debate which the Government does not like is one which the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines) has in fact suggested to the Manager of Government Business or has at least made passing reference to in terms of Senator Ray's earlier description of it. The sheer hypocrisy of the way in which Senator Haines has dressed up this motion is absolutely transparent. I move:
Paragraphs (d), (e) and (f), leave out the paragraphs, insert the following paragraphs:
(d) notes that it is the clear responsibility of the Government and its whips to maintain the quorum in the Senate; and
(e) censures the Government and its whips for their failure to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I will not detain the chamber for very long on this matter but I do feel a need to say a couple of things about it in the light of what has been going on here this morning and, indeed, what went on here yesterday. This morning we have heard Senator Haines whipping herself into a fury, and I think it is fair to describe it in that way, about what she has described as collusion between the Government and the Opposition to have the Senate counted out yesterday. I simply wanted to say to Senator Haines that that is totally untrue. It is a total misconstruction of the events of yesterday afternoon. Not only do I think Senator Haines's remarks this morning leave a great deal to be desired but also I have to say that I think Senator Ray's defence of the Government's position yesterday leaves even more to be desired.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday we had a matter of public importance eventually placed on the Notice Paper by Senator Jenkins, it having originally been proposed, as Senator Ray quite accurately pointed out, that a matter in exactly the same words would have been placed on our paper by Senator Vallentine. That was eventually replaced, as I say, by Senator Jenkins's motion.

That motion was on the matter of the disgraceful events which occurred over the weekend at Nurrungar-the childish, immature behaviour of a group of people at and around the installation there in central Australia. I must say in passing that Senator Jenkins, who I understand was personally involved in that, has not exactly covered herself in glory in the process. Therefore, when that matter was raised in the Senate yesterday afternoon I certainly, and I make no bones about saying so, rose to my feet and left the chamber because I simply cannot bear to sit here and listen to the hypocritical cant that comes from these people here on my left on matters such as the joint installation at Nurrungar-total cant. Having said that--

TALK.START.PARA: —We had the right to be heard.

—Senator Coulter quite rightly takes the words out of my mouth. But having said that, I wanted to go on to say that, there having been a matter of public importance placed before the Senate, I would be the first to agree with Senator Haines that of course that matter should have been heard out. The debate upon it should have been heard out. I am not in any way dissenting from that point of view. Of course it should have been.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly agree, therefore, with that part of Senator Haines's remarks which criticised the Government very strongly for not allowing that to occur. But let us now come to what actually happened because I think that is the pith of yesterday's events. We have had in this context, as I say, these tendentious accusations from Senator Haines and her vociferous colleagues of collusion between the Government and the Opposition on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should not judge others by their own behaviour.

—As Senator Walters quite rightly points out, they should not judge others by their own behaviour. The fact is, as I said a moment ago, when this matter came on I left the Senate. I certainly was not going to sit here and listen to Senator Jenkins rabbit on about these matters. I was actually in my room; I had a visitor. We were talking about the matter under discussion and the bells rang. I noted the fact that the bells were ringing and I presumed, rightly as it turned out, that it was a quorum. Indeed, in due course `quorum required' appeared on the screen on my television set; so I knew again this was as I thought: a quorum was proceeding.

SPEECH.PARA: I operated, as one would normally expect, on the assumption that the Government would form the quorum, as it is its duty to do, and therefore took no notice of the bells. A little while later my beeper sounded in my pocket. When I pressed the appropriate buttons a message came up on the screen which said, `Senators wanted in chamber to make quorum'. I thought this was very strange, and that I must be picking up a Labor Party message on my beeper; so I took no notice of it again. I went on talking to my visitor and a bit later two things happened. I began to notice on my screen a few people on our side coming in, including Senator Chaney. I know Senator Chaney came in, I cannot remember now who the others were, but a number of people came in and I thought, `What the blazes is going on?'. At the same time I got a second message on my beeper that Opposition senators were wanted in the chamber. There was a difference between the two messages-the second one was that Opposition senators were wanted in the chamber to form a quorum. By that time, of course, it was all over. By the time I got out of the door the bells had finished ringing.

That was the series of events as they personally affected me, and any suggestion from Senator Haines or anybody else that there was collusion between the Government and the Opposition is not merely untrue but almost unparliamentary, as I think Senator Chaney said earlier, in view of the personal assurances that I understand he has given-and I certainly also would have given-to Senator Haines on the matter. I suggest to Senator Haines that instead of coming in here this morning and detaining us with a vast amount of rodomontade on all sorts of irrelevancies and false premises-the falseness of which has indeed been duly exposed by my colleague, Senator Puplick, in terms of the Australian Democrats' own record on these matters-she might have done well to remember the old adage that if one has to choose between conspiracy and a stuff-up, one always chooses the latter. There is not the slightest doubt that yesterday was a confusion, let us say.

I assure Senator Haines, through the Chair, that there was certainly no conspiracy. But there was a kernel of truth in Senator Haines's remarks, as I have already said, in accusing the Government of not only allowing but also actively moving to ensure that the Senate was counted out. That is the single element of Senator Haines's remarks with which I agree. I would describe that as a pretty cheap shot by the Government. I agree also with Senator Ray's comment that it was not just Senator McKiernan who should have been blamed, because I understand it was Senator Ray who initiated it. Instead of having a censure motion on Senator McKiernan we could certainly have had a censure motion in the terms which have now been suggested by way of amendment by Senator Puplick and for which, of course, I propose to vote. If we had had a little more commonsense from Senator Haines and a little less hot air we might have been at this point a lot earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Opposition has indicated that it intends to move an amendment. I am not quite sure whether the terms of the piece of paper that I have here are the ones that Senator Puplick actually read out. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is the clear responsibility of the Government and its Whips to maintain the quorum in the Senate and censures the Government and its Whips for their failure to do so.

I indicate that we will seek to amend that amendment to leave out the first occurring `the Government and its Whips' and substitute `or senators' because it is our view that the obligation to maintain the quorum is an obligation of the Senate. I also indicate that whether or not the Government supports the amendment we will oppose the deletion of (d), (e) and (f) of Senator Haines's motion.

I want to raise a number of points that have occurred so far in the debate, but prior to doing that, as I have indicated on a number of occasions in the past, I think there is an amazing lack of logic in the way that this House conducts its business with regard to quorum issues. For example, when a senator draws attention to the state of the House and the presiding officer indicates there is no quorum present, it is not possible to conduct the business of the House. However, in an amazing lack of logic, what happens at that stage is that the clock keeps going. A much more reasonable and operational exercise would be for the clock to stop along with everything else and, when the quorum is formed, that person's time would start again. In other words, the time taken to form the quorum would come out of the time of the House; it would not come out of the time of the person speaking at that time. It has nothing to do with the person addressing the House. It is not the fault of that person that there is not a quorum.
Senator Vanstone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I exempt Senator Knowles from that. When she is speaking, there is a good reason to call a quorum. There is no standing order governing the practice. It just happens to be done that way. It is about time this chamber resolved that that is an absurd way of proceeding. There is an absurd lack of logic. When a quorum is not present, the person speaking is not allowed to continue to speak and, therefore, he should not have to forfeit the time taken for a quorum to be formed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick, having delved into his myriad of files-or probably somebody else's myriad of files-drew out the fact that the House has been counted out on a number of occasions in the past. Of course, that was done during an adjournment debate. As all honourable senators here are very much aware, when the motion is put, `That the House do now adjourn', no new business is able to be introduced. In other words, that time is then devoted generally to speeches on matters of constituent interest. However, there is no responsibility on anybody to adhere to that. That is the very real reason that Senator Puplick was able to say that the Opposition does well under this operation because the majority of speakers in the adjournment debate are from the Opposition. Members of the Government are not likely to stand up and lambast their own government. At least, they do not do it in here; they generally do it on television.

The exercise in which Senator McKiernan engaged on behalf of the Government was facile. It is quite simple to find out whether or not he was waving off the moths or waving off his own people. That is for Senator McKiernan to tell the chamber. Presumably, since his name is mentioned, he will engage in this debate and he will tell the chamber whether or not he was in fact directing his senators to stay out. I invite him to do so because, fairly obviously, he was indicating to his senators to stay out. He knows he was doing that. I have no objection to linking Senator Ray to that. It was fairly obviously a direction from Senator Ray. Everybody in here knew that Senator Ray had directed Senator McKiernan to do it. But if Senator McKiernan was silly enough to take the advice and do that, he has to take the responsibility.

Senator McKiernan, as the operational Whip in the chamber at the time, has to take the responsibility for his actions. I am quite sure that he always takes responsibility for his actions and does not shuffle them off onto Ministers. Hence on this occasion he must take responsibility for whatever he was doing. Our motion indicates that at that time Senator McKiernan was clearly signalling to Australian Labor Party senators to remain out of the chamber. If he does not believe that, and believes that he was merely standing on the floor here waving his arms around because he did not have much else to do at the time, he can say that-not only to this chamber, but to the rest of his constituents in Western Australia. I am quite sure that when next there is an election for the Labor Party Whip in the Senate, they would prefer that somebody other than a person who stands in the chamber waving his arms aimlessly is elected. What he was doing was quite clearly directed at Western Australian senators. I invite Senator McKiernan to come into the debate and to say clearly whether or not he was directing his senators to stay out of the chamber so that we may all be clear that the Government was engaged in that exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —And, if so, was he doing it at Senator Ray's directions?

—I am sure he was doing it at Senator Ray's directions. Senator Ray clearly indicated to the chamber that he was not about to say whether he had directed him or not. He used a hypothetical exercise, but Senator McKiernan is the only one who can tell us what actually happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point made by Senator Ray by way of defence-and I must admit that I do enjoy Senator Ray's defence of the indefensible; it is always entertaining and worth listening to, I suppose, in that sense-was that it was going to be a retribution exercise with regard to Independents. I operated as a whip for quite a number of years in this place, during which time most of the rules which now apply were developed. I first became a whip when my Party gained the balance of power in 1981. At that time, not only were we not allowed to call for quorums to be formed, but also we were not permitted to engage in almost anything in debate. By a reasonably hard won exercise, the Senate adjusted to the presence of a grouping of senators from other than the major parties.

In regard to matters of public importance, there was a standing agreement-it may have been abrogated since I left position of the whip-that when a matter of public importance was introduced either by ourselves or by the Independents on an issue on which we agreed there would be at least a couple of speakers representing our point of view and the rest of the speakers would be from the Government and the Opposition, representing the opposing point of view. Senator McKiernan can enlighten the Senate as to whether that arrangement also has disappeared.
