The other arrangement that was agreed to was a reasonable distribution of matters of public importance and non-government business time. During my early years as a whip it was absolutely chaotic. A general agreement was reached whereby the time available for matters of public importance, urgency motions and non-government business would be distributed among the various groups in this place in direct proportion to their numbers. Hence, an Independent had a one in 76 chance of having a matter of public importance discussed. That worked out to be about once in the life of a parliament. Our chances were seven in 76, and so it goes on. The allusion to two hours by Senator Ray is probably better dealt with by my Whip since I was not involved in any of those discussions. When Senator McKiernan joins the debate, I invite him to inform the chamber whether both of those general operating rules have now disappeared. If they have not, I believe that what occurred yesterday represents a direct breaking of those types of agreements.

It becomes obvious, I think, to everybody in this place, if ever they bother to add up the figures, that the processes in this chamber can break down pretty rapidly unless there is reasonable agreement across parties as to how we conduct business. Undoubtedly, from time to time, in the heat of the moment those types of agreements will break down. It may be that yesterday was one such time. If it was, I think it needs to be rectified, but if it was not-if, indeed, it was a deliberate and new attempt to institute something that has occurred a number of times previously, all during the adjournment debate, all late at night, in an attempt to bring a particular debate to a halt-fairly obviously, this chamber will become unworkable in the future. It is interesting to go back over the various occasions that Senator Puplick referred to. Senator Puplick mentioned various adjournment debates, but did not tell us he was here on all of those occasions. I am sure he was; probably holding up the exercise--

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing is for sure-you were not here.

—Senator Lewis, I have absolutely no intention of being here at 3.30 in the morning to listen to Senator Walters carrying on, whether she is talking about something that is of interest to her or not. I am quite happy to indicate that I have no interest in and intention of doing that.
—No sensible person would.

—That is true, Senator. The exercise that we had yesterday was not on the adjournment when no new business could be introduced. It was on a matter of public importance introduced under the Standing Orders of the chamber and at any time new business was able to be introduced. What we are confronting is an abuse of the processes that have occurred here. Senator McKiernan, either on his own behalf or induced by Senator Ray, engaged in a silly exercise yesterday, either waving his arms around aimlessly as he stood in the middle of the chamber or directing his senators to stay out when there was a call under Standing Orders for a quorum to be formed.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray, by using his defence which Senator Puplick referred to as the `bogong defence', has, I think, cast very serious aspersions on Senator McKiernan's sanity. That can be retrieved only by him telling us the real reason he was waving his arms, which fairly obviously was to keep his senators out of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, are you moving the amendment that you foreshadowed which was to take out certain words?
—Yes, Mr President.
—As I see it, the amendment is to take out the words `the Government and its Whips' from the amendment moved by Senator Puplick and insert `all senators'. Is that correct?

—To take out `the Government and its Whips' first occurring and substitute `all senators'. If so amended it would read `It is the responsibility of all senators to maintain the quorum and censures. . .'.
—That is what I thought.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed paragraph (d), leave out ``the Government and its whips'', insert ``all Senators''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped not to speak in this debate because we have now taken up an hour and 40 minutes of fairly scarce legislative time that I had hoped would have been spent restarting our consideration of the ATSIC legislation. In light of the fact that the Australian Democrats have indicated that they wish to move a further amendment to the amendment that has been put forward by Senator Puplick on behalf of the Opposition and in light of a couple of the comments made by Senator Macklin, I wish to make some further response. I reject totally the suggestion which was implicit in what was said by Senator Haines, and I think more explicit in what was said by Senator Macklin, that to participate in counting out the Senate on the adjournment is in some way superior to doing so in the circumstances which applied yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Australian Democrats are putting forward is that senators have certain rights of debate and one of the rights is to bring forward a matter of public importance which normally ensures that for two hours a group of senators gets a chance to speak on a selected topic. For the private senator, the senator who is operating in this place without perhaps the support of his or her party or who might be without a party, the adjournment debate is in fact an essential part of the political armoury. It is the private member's ultimate guarantee of an opportunity to speak. I believe that to suggest that the adjournment debate is not important is quite wrong and ignores its importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins doesn't think it is important.

—A number of my Opposition senators are assisting me. They keep pointing out that the Democrats-and Senator Jenkins is a Democrat-the nuclear disarmers and so on are frequent users of the adjournment debate. I would simply say in response to Senator Macklin that I do not believe that it is desirable to be counting out the Senate on the adjournment to silence senators notwithstanding that it is very irritating to be here late at night listening to debates that perhaps are not of particular interest to us.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I want to make concerns the calling of quorums. It was touched on by Senator Puplick in his comments on behalf of the Opposition. In the last six years we have seen a quite intentional attack on the institution of parliament and an attempt made to reduce the value of debate in this and the other place. If a serious matter is addressed by the Opposition in either chamber, it is almost universally the case that the Government senators, or in the other place the members of the House of Representatives, will absent themselves from the chamber. That is no more than a technique to reduce the apparent value and importance of the debate which is taking place. I believe that it is part of a clear intention on the part of the Australian Labor Party to reduce the value of the Parliament.

In those circumstances, I think the calling of quorums is very legitimate. The suggestion from Senator Ray that it is unfair to remove minutes from a speech of limited duration has some merit, but it need have no merit at all if the quorums are being kept in an adequate way. In other words, the amount of time that is taken for a speech is a function of the failure of senators or members in the other place to keep the House.

That brings me to my third point, which is that I think it is the primary obligation of government to keep the House. Opposition senators have consistently said, `We will sit when the Government requires us to sit', and we have done so. When in government we accepted it as our primary obligation to keep a quorum. Those senators who were here under the leadership of former Senator Sir John Carrick will recall his absolute requirement that there be a quorum of Government senators available to ensure that the Senate could be kept. That was seen as a clear responsibility on the part of Government senators and it was imposed upon us.

In those circumstances, I think that the amendment moved by Senator Puplick is the appropriate amendment, and we would withstand and resist the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. In doing that, I would make it quite clear to the Australian Democrats that, if at any future time I think that the calling of a quorum is being used as a means to prevent debate, I will, as I did yesterday, respond to the quorum call. I do not normally respond to quorum calls. I have come to the door of the Senate and left because I have found that the bells were ringing not for a division but for a quorum. I have done that in the belief that the primary obligation to keep the quorum is with the Government and that since it is normally in the Government's interest to do so that will occur. When I received a message from the Whip yesterday that it appeared the Government was going to withhold a quorum I immediately came to the chamber and Senator Austin Lewis, the Deputy Leader, came with me. We happened to be close to the chamber. As has been documented three times now-this is the third time-a second message was put out to Opposition senators to indicate that they should respond to the quorum.

I again make the point that I made in the course of Senator Haines's speech when I took a point of order. When there have been such clear assurances on the part of the Opposition that we had no part in any cooperation of any sort with the Government in bringing about the termination of the Senate sitting yesterday, I think it is an extraordinary breach of the conventions of this place that our word is not accepted by the Democrats. If a senator makes a bald assertion of that sort, I think the proper requirement of this place is that the senator is accepted as telling the truth. I find it quite offensive that there should be any doubts about this matter when those clear assurances have been given.

I agree that it was unfair to single out Senator McKiernan as the villain. He was in this case the monkey rather than the organ grinder. That was made quite clear in the speech which was given by Senator Ray. I say that as an ex-Whip and without any malice towards Senator McKiernan. I have done a bit of monkeying myself in this chamber with a very effective organ grinder in former Senator Withers as our then leader. We commend our amendment and oppose the further amendment moved by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of Senator Macklin's amendment to Senator Haines's motion. I must say that yesterday's events were a first for me in the time that I have been in this place, although it was certainly not the first time that I have seen debate gagged on important defence issues. While I certainly do not say that there has been collusion between the Opposition and the Government on this matter, I think there was a very convenient overlap of interests which allowed Senator Newman to call a quorum and Senator McKiernan, acting as the monkey for his organ grinder, to wave his fellow senators away from the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: This incident reminded me very much of what happened on 22 November last, after the Government announced its decision to extend the leases on the Pine Gap and North West Cape bases. The decision was announced in some secrecy and the following day, when we debated it in this chamber, the Opposition carried the Government's arguments for it. Not one single Government senator spoke in the debate. Of course, the Australian Democrats and Independents were left to provide the real opposition to the decision in this place.

If a quorum had not been called yesterday and the Senate had not been counted out, we would not be debating this matter today. We would be able to get on with the consideration of the very important Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation, which awaits us and which has been hanging around this chamber for a very long time. It was a most disgraceful episode yesterday. It was nothing but a waste of the Senate's time to have to raise this matter today, but the reason that it has to be raised in the Senate-and thanks for giving us the opportunity on a broadcast day-is that the matter of Nurrungar has been a matter of great public interest. It is a matter that has achieved a lot of publicity in the newspapers recently. It is a matter on which 500 Australian citizens have been arrested at a place that was very difficult to get to because of the pilots dispute. Those 500 people represent very many more in the Australian community who are extremely concerned about this particular issue.

There has been serious criticism of the Government in the newspapers over this matter. The Opposition is not going to criticise the Government on this matter; in fact, the Government and the Opposition have a very bipartisan approach to defence issues. It is left to the Democrats and Independents to carry the real arguments against bases such as Nurrungar, Pine Gap and North West Cape. This is what the Sydney Morning Herald said in yesterday's editorial, the heading of which was `The fault at Nurrungar':
By its unbelievable clumsiness, the Government managed to turn a picnic protest at the Nurrungar military communications base into a politically damaging event.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The motion before the Senate at the moment is actually a censure motion and not a motion debating Nurrungar. I believe that Senator Dunn is now debating the issue of Nurrungar and I ask you to call her attention to the present debate.
—The issue before the Senate at the moment is a censure motion and I would ask Senator Dunn not to stray from the subject of that censure motion.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am actually addressing the second part of Senator Haines's motion which relates to the public importance of the question. I am giving quite good illustrations, I think, of the indication of public importance, particularly the fact that it made it into the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald. The fact that the Government chose to use troops against Australian citizens for the first time in Australian history is a matter of great public importance and should be debated in this chamber not only in this motion but also in the matter of public importance that was raised yesterday. The whole question of how Western democracies deal with peaceful protesters is one that needs to be debated at length. We cannot continue to have this subject gagged by the Opposition and by the Government in a collusion of interests. I have no hesitation in saying `a collusion of interests', because I have seen that happen time and time again in this chamber. In America the civil guard, which is not a military force, is used. There is no question of the use of a civil guard in Australia because there is none.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. You have already ruled on the point of order I want to raise. It would seem to me that Senator Dunn is speaking in defiance of your ruling and I wonder whether you might bring her to order.
—No, I do not want to restrict debate. I remind Senator Dunn again of the ruling I made. I will listen to her speech.

—Thank you, Mr President. I seem to remember that Senator Ray was referring to some Victorian Football League subject during his contribution to the debate and there was no point of order taken in relation to that. Again, this is another example of the way in which the Government and the Opposition have a collusion of interests in gagging debate on these important matters.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Dunn has used the word `collusion' in relation to something Senator Crichton-Browne has said. Senator Puplick defined the word `collusion' in his speech. That word as defined is quite unparliamentary and the reference Senator Dunn has made refers specifically to what Senator Crichton-Browne has said. On those grounds, I believe it is unparliamentary and it should be withdrawn.
—I ruled earlier that the term used was a debating point and I will stick with that ruling.

—I will go back to point (a) and Senator Macklin's proposal that the time taken for a quorum be taken out of the chamber's time and not out of the speaker's time. I certainly support that proposal very strongly because it would eliminate the way in which the calling for a quorum has been used as a tactic to eat into an individual speaker's time. Given that we as Independents and Democrats do not have the same sort of access to parliamentary time as the Government and the Opposition have, I think we would see a very sharp decline in the number of quorums called as a result of this kind of ruling on your part, Mr President.
—Tell us how you got here.

—I got here because the High Court put me here. Point (c) of Senator Haines's motion notes that the Government would have good cause not to want a motion of this kind debated because of its implications.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a parallel instance which occurred in this chamber yesterday in relation to a question I asked Senator Ray on Nurrungar. In that particular question I asked the Minister some questions in relation to the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of 22 November last year relating to this American base in South Australia. In his response to me yesterday he sidestepped the issue. I asked him why the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) persisted in repeating that the base was used for arms verification purposes only when our eminent arms analyst, Professor Desmond Ball, had called this statement by the Prime Minister hyperbole.

I went on to quote the statements of two United States military generals and asked Senator Ray directly whether he disagreed with those statements. He sidestepped the issue by merely referring me back to the statement made by the Prime Minister on 22 November 1988. He tried to sidestep the issue further by bagging Jo Vallentine in relation to a matter that relates particularly to point (c), a fundamental question in relation to Nurrungar, that is the difficulty of getting information due to the military secrecy which surrounds these bases. Senator Ray was referring particularly to information that Senator Vallentine was trying to extract about the possibility of a melt-through on a nuclear-powered submarine. This illustrates perfectly the difficulty of getting that information. Had Senator Ray wished, he could have just as easily referred to the difficulty of the Senate standing committee getting just this information. Also, he could have pointed out that the committee did not finally discount the possibility of a melt-through on such a submarine.

I have one or two points left about the difficulties in relation to Senator Haines's motion which I would like to put to the chamber. In relation to point (d), I was sitting here yesterday watching with dismay what was happening and being reminded of last November, when I saw Senator McKiernan approach the back of the chamber. I could not see a single moth near him and I certainly could see none down around his hip where he was waving. Perhaps it was a moth on the ground that he was waving to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a mosquito, actually.

—It must have been a mosquito or a gnat. I certainly challenge Senator McKiernan to say something about the rather odd hand gestures that he was making yesterday. Senator Puplick said that the Opposition was prepared to debate this matter yesterday. There was one Democrat on the speakers list, Senator Jenkins, who had put the motion. The rest of the speakers on the list, Government and Opposition speakers, would have been indistinguishable from one another. The Opposition would not have been doing any opposing on that.

—I wish to raise a point of order in terms of the latitude which Senator Dunn is taking in talking to a censure motion which deals with the specific question of the count-out of the chamber yesterday. We have now had the best part of 10 minutes debate on the issue of Nurrungar, the joint defence facilities, nuclear ships and all the other bits and pieces, which I put to you, Mr President, are simply not relevant to the fundamental issue which is before the Senate, which is the censure regarding the close-down of the chamber yesterday. If this is to be a free-for-all debate on the issue of the matter of public importance which was listed yesterday, in fact that is an interpretation of the Standing Orders relating to a censure motion which makes the whole thing totally meaningless.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I would point out to Senator Puplick that points (a), (b), (c) and (d) all begin with the word `notes'; that they raise the question of what happened yesterday-namely, that a quorum was not present and that a matter of public importance debate on a particular issue was being pursued; that they raise the question of why the Government would have wanted that motion not to be debated yesterday; and that they note the actions of Senator McKiernan in ensuring that senators from his side of the House did not come in here in sufficient numbers to make up that quorum. The subsequent two parts of the motion certainly call for a censure. However, it is worth pointing out that the first four parts are as integral and important a part of the motion we are debating today as the two parts relating to the censure of Senator McKiernan and I would ask you to allow Senator Dunn to discuss those points.

—I allowed Senator Dunn to make remarks about Senator McKiernan's action but I would like to point out to the Senate that the terms of the motion are really incidental to what we should be debating. I would ask Senator Dunn to talk to the censure and not debate the general issue of Nurrungar.

—I presume that I would, during this debate, be allowed to answer matters that have been raised by previous senators when they spoke on the subject. Senator Puplick talked about the Opposition senators who were prepared to speak on the debate yesterday without a point of order being raised against him; I would expect the same. I will conclude my remarks by referring to the speakers list. I have made the point that as there would be very little difference between the Government and the Opposition, it becomes even more important to have Independents and Democrats speaking on these important issues and raising motions such as the one that Senator Haines has raised today.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier on Senator Ray went on at length about how Independents get a good run in this place. If Senator Ray was able to speak on this matter, I expect to be able to speak on it without a point of order being taken against me. I merely wish to make the point that in the absence of any genuine opposition to the Government on its defence policies and in view of the public interest in this matter, as was shown in Sydney Morning Herald article of yesterday, it becomes all the more important to give Independents that opportunity to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I have sat here, as no doubt you have, and listened with such patience as I could muster to Senator Dunn quite deliberately transgressing the Standing Orders by talking not to the matter of substance in the motion before the Senate, which is a censure of the Government or, as it was originally drafted, of Senator McKiernan, for certain procedural events which occurred yesterday. I have not heard Senator Dunn address that question at all during the whole of her remarks; she is certainly not addressing it now. I ask you to rule her out of order.

—Mr President, I wish to speak on the point of order. This morning the Senate was asked to suspend Standing Orders to allow Senator Haines's notice of motion to be moved. I believe that any honourable senator should be allowed to address the terms of the motion that are, in fact, before the chamber. Quite frankly, I think the fact that part of that motion includes a censure is incidental. The Senate gave leave for this motion to be debated. If it had not wished the entire motion to be debated, I suggest it would have sought to delete various items and said, `No, we will discuss only (d), (e) and (f)'. As it was, it allowed (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f) to be debated. I think that Senator Dunn is entitled to address any part of the motion of which Senator Haines gave notice this morning.
—I will not allow Senator Dunn to re-hash the whole argument of the notice of motion. I take it that you have concluded your remarks, Senator Dunn?
—Yes, I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three things which enable this place to function effectively: the Standing Orders; longstanding agreements arrived at between senators and Whips; and short term agreements arrived at at Whips meetings each morning. They are the glue which holds the process together. As Senator Macklin said, occasionally when that glue becomes unstuck, we move into a period of non-cooperation and things founder. Senator Ray suggested that yesterday the glue came unstuck, things became messy and there was a state of war between the peace lovers in the Senate. In fact, he misrepresented the events of yesterday. I would like to put the record straight as to what did occur prior to the matter of public importance discussion yesterday afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine proposed a matter of public importance which was accepted at the Whips meeting. At the Whips meeting it was suggested that four senators speaking for 20 minutes would be satisfactory. Later in the morning Senator Reid, the Opposition Whip, rang me and drew my attention to the fact that if we proceeded with Senator Vallentine's matter of public importance we would be contravening an agreement between the Independents, the Opposition and the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not an agreement with the Opposition.

—No. It was an agreement by which we proceed in this place. Senator Schacht should be patient as this answers his earlier question. The fact was that Senator Reid rightly drew attention to the fact that Senator Vallentine was exceeding her entitlement under an agreement. The way out of that was for us to assume the matter of public importance as being ours, which we did. But this was done in a quite amicable way. It became our matter of public importance and, therefore, Senator Vallentine had to withdraw hers. We had to submit ours, which we did.
—Identical wording.

—Identical wording. As I said to Senator Ray, in a discussion we had in the vestibule, we identified with the issue. The wording was quite acceptable to us, and so it became our matter of public importance. Under another agreement that we normally have, under those circumstances we would have had two speakers on the list. That is the normal practice. That was not the case when the speakers list appeared. On our interpretation or perception of the situation the speakers list had become loaded. Originally, at the beginning of the day, there was a subtle agreement that the speakers list comprise four senators speaking for 20 minutes, but by this time it was in fact a speakers list which was loaded against a matter of public importance which was ours, and so we started to react. I think that it was a fairly reasonable reaction. The glue had started to become unstuck. Senator Vallentine was going to be our second speaker and was acceptable to us as a second speaker. However, the glue was becoming unstuck and the pattern of interaction was beginning to change. It started to get out of hand and by the end of the day it was a disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the sequence of events. There was no war between the peace lovers. In fact, there was a quite amicable arrangement by which an issue with which we all agreed was brought before the Senate under a most important standing order under which, in fact, we are enabled to carry out our duty-that is to pursue matters of public importance. We saw this as a matter of absolute and profound public importance. Let me explain why. Outside the chamber in the previous 48 hours we believe we witnessed a profoundly important breach of democratic right. We saw it in those terms and, therefore, we brought it to the chamber as a matter of public importance. We hoped to debate it, only to find that we were confounded in that process by another equally significant breach of democratic right.

I have not been in this place very long; so, frankly, what has prevailed here previously is fairly irrelevant to me. But, as a newly elected senator, I am both alarmed and offended by what occurred here yesterday. It was simply an offence against my exercising, on behalf of my constituents, what I am elected to do. The questions of collusion, gesture and all the other things are secondary to that absolutely vital issue: we were attempting to have debated in this chamber what we saw as a breach of the most fundamental of democratic rights in this country; in other words, the arrest of innocent protesters by police, supported-to use the words of the Minister who was asked a question about it yesterday-in that process of arrest by troops using offensive weapons. To that we reacted strongly. We react equally strongly to the second breach of democratic rights. It was an offence against this chamber, an offence against the Parliament, and was unacceptable. Those who carried it through deserve censure. We truly see it as having been an abuse of procedure. If we, as a chamber, are prepared to accept it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Procedure laid down where?

—Senator Ray has defended it today. The offence is compounded also by the fact that it has been defended here today as being appropriate procedure. Senator Haines's motion was totally appropriate. The censure is appropriate and I speak in support of it. I therefore also support Senator Macklin's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, with considerable reluctance I rise to make some comments in this debate, which seems to have gone on for rather a long time. We ought to be dealing with a lot of other important things. But, in response to the last speaker, I say that it is not normal to canvass in this chamber what happens at a Whips meeting. I would not do so. The suggestion of four 20-minute speakers came to me by my clerk when I was in the joint party meeting yesterday morning. It was not a matter I had heard about previously. I asked my clerk to contact Senator McLean to ask whether or not the Australian Democrats intended to support Senator Vallentine's matter of public importance. If they did not, there was no point in my getting my speakers ready to speak in the debate. So it was important that I knew.

SPEECH.PARA: I knew that we had an informal agreement-one of the things Senator McLean has just referred to-about the order of matters of public importance and who would have priority. According to my interpretation of that, Senator Vallentine was not due for a matter of public importance at this stage. So it was important that I knew whether or not the Democrats would support her. After I got an answer as to what they were going to do, I received the request for speakers. The Liberal and National parties have 34 Opposition senators. We were faced with a proposition of two speakers from the Australian Democrats' list, one from our side and one from the Government. I do not know what the Government thought about being allowed only one out of its 32 senators, but in the circumstances I regarded one out of our 34 as not well balanced and that we ought to have had a speakers list that adequately dealt with this very important topic. I will not canvass the rest of the matters and what else happened yesterday except to say personally that there was no collusion and I do not appreciate being accused of being involved in that when it was clearly not the case. As for what happened in the morning about the speakers, we did not reneg on any commitment as to the speakers list.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

That the amendment (Senator Puplick's), as amended, be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend certain legislation relating to the Australian Federal Police, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.
SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will enable the completion of this Government's major and innovative reforms over the last 2 years to modernise the legislation which governs the Australian Federal Police to streamline and enhance its administration and management. The Bill represents one of the most significant initiatives in policing in Australia.

Far reaching proposals of the nature contained in the Bill are normally not easily accepted by the persons they will affect. It is, I believe, indicative of the sense of commitment to effective law enforcement in Australia that the membership of the Australian Federal Police, and their Association, the AFPA, have accepted the changes outlined in the Bill. On behalf of the Government I take this opportunity to congratulate both the Association and its members and to restate the commitment of the Government to the development of the Australian Federal Police not only as the premier law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth but one that can be looked up to throughout the world.

There have been some concerns expressed as to the potentially wider implication of these proposals for other public sector employment. My colleague, the Minister for Industrial Relations has confirmed that during the discussions that led to this Bill those particular concerns were canvassed. He has stated that fixed term appointment in the Australian Federal Police is a response to a set of unique circumstances and should not be seen in any way as providing a basis for moves to fixed term contract employment in other areas.

The Australian Federal Police is the Commonwealth's premier law enforcement agency. At the national level, the Australian Federal Police will be an investigative agency with a pro-active focus. The Australian Federal Police has, in recent years, been shedding non-investigative functions, such as guarding diplomatic premises, so that it can concentrate on its investigative role in relation to the fight against drug trafficking, organised crime and fraud against the Commonwealth.

This Government is also concerned to ensure that, while the Australian Federal Police continues to develop to meet the everchanging challenges confronting it, its administration and operations continue to maintain the highest standards of effectiveness, public accountability and integrity.
In January this year the Government implemented the Career Structure Review of the Australian Federal Police through major amendments to the Australian Federal Police Regulations. Those amendments:
broadbanded the rank structure to reduce the number of ranks from 9 to 5;
removed the barriers to promotion on merit and accelerated advancement by removing certain eligibility prerequisites for promotion;
ended the role of seniority in relation to promotions at any rank;
allowed lateral entry to ranks above constable in certain circumstances;
streamlined the procedures relating to promotion and promotion appeals;
provided for the appointment of non-citizens on probation; and
allowed persons who are appointed as constables, sergeants and superintendents to be paid at greater than base salary level.

While the Australian Federal Police currently has high educational standards, these amendments to the Australian Federal Police Regulations will facilitate the achievement of even higher standards to enable it to even more effectively respond to the ever increasing sophistication of criminal activity.

The Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Act 1989 was enacted in the Autumn Sittings of the Parliament. That Act inserted Part VA into the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. Part VA provides for existing and former police members of the Australian Federal Police to lose certain superannuation rights and benefits if convicted of an offence involving corruption and sentenced to life imprisonment or a term of imprisonment longer than 12 months or, if a police member is found guilty of a relevant disciplinary offence and dismissed from the Australian Federal Police, as a penalty for that offence.
A Unified Workforce

The Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides for the creation of a unified workforce. As far as is practicable, all AFP personnel-police and staff members-will be employed under the Australian Federal Police Act rather than utilising officers of the Australian Public Service who are currently appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922. Hitherto only police members have been appointed under the Australian Federal Police Act.

This change is regarded as crucial to the long-term development of the Australian Federal Police because it will greatly improve the Commissioner's flexibility in determining the overall staffing composition of the Australian Federal Police and the utilisation of its employees, both staff and police, effectively. It will also enable, wherever possible, that positions which do not require police powers, be filled by staff members which will result in a better utilisation of scarce police resources. Another benefit is that it will allow the development of a professional and dedicated workforce which is purpose-designed for the unique task of Federal law enforcement. Also it will be a workforce which is structured to encourage the sharing of a common purpose and set of values.

Upon commencement of the legislation, existing Public Service Act staff will be offered fixed term appointments as staff members of the Australian Federal Police under the Australian Federal Police Act. Alternatively, they will be able to take advantage of the mobility provisions of the Public Service Act. If they choose to be appointed to the Australian Federal Police under the Australian Federal Police Act they will retain their mobility rights within the Public Service for their first term. At the end of that term they will have the choice of electing to be credited with the accumulated adjustment payment, this is the payment to be made in recognition of fixed term employment and which I will later describe in more detail, or they may choose to return to the Australian Public Service.

All police members will be taken to have been appointed under the fixed term system provided for by the Bill unless they notify the Commissioner that they wish to resign from the Australian Federal Police.
Chief Executive Powers

The Bill provides the Commissioner with Chief Executive powers in relation to the composition of the Australian Federal Police and the terms and conditions of service of police members, other than himself, and of staff members. The Commissioner is given the power to determine terms and conditions for all members and staff members subject to the Minister giving the Commissioner general policy guidelines. In relation to members who are not Deputy Commissioners, senior executive commissioned police officers or senior executive officers, the Industrial Relations Commission will continue to determine most terms and conditions through awards. There are certain limits on the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission because of the Government's recognition of the unique nature of the Australian Federal Police as a disciplined force comprising police and staff members.

While the Commissioner will be provided with chief executive powers over the terms and conditions of employment of the force, staff members' employment (other than senior executive level staff members) will continue generally to be governed by Industrial Relations Commission awards. In addition, on such employment aspects as promotions and invalidity retirement, staff members will retain the right of appeal to the Merit Protection and Review Agency which will have a recommendatory power in relation to the Commissioner's decisions in these areas; the MPRA will also be given a recommendatory review role for SES level non-appealable promotions. In respect of disciplinary matters, staff members will have the right of appeal to the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal now afforded to members. In respect of general non-economic grievance matters, staff members, like police members, will have recourse to an AFP review panel especially established for that purpose. The panel will make recommendations to the Commissioner.
Fixed Term Appointments

The Bill abolishes tenure and replaces it with a fixed term appointment system for all police members, including deputy commissioners, and staff members of the Australian Federal Police. The very nature of policing lends itself to a fixed term tenure system. The stress of policing often leads to burnout among members who do not want or cannot progress to management positions. The fixed term appointment system will enable police members and staff members to leave the Australian Federal Police and enable the Commissioner not to re-appoint police members or staff members who are not performing at the required level. There will be an administrative appraisal system to recommend whether a police member or a staff member should be re-appointed on the completion of a term appointment. It is noteworthy that the Fitzgerald report has also recommended that term and contract appointments be introduced for the Queensland police force.
Australian Federal Police Adjustment Payment

The Bill provides for the entitlement to an adjustment payment which recognises the fact that the person's appointment is for a fixed term. The Australian Federal Police adjustment payment will be 12 1/2 per cent of accumulated salary over the period of the police member's or staff member's fixed term appointment or appointments, on the basis that it will be treated as an eligible termination payment. Police members or staff members will not be eligible for the adjustment payment where they resign from the Australian Federal Police prior to the end of their terms of appointment or where police members or staff members have their appointments annulled during the period of their probationary service.
Consequential Amendments

This Bill also contains amendments to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act 1989, the Industrial Relations Act 1988, the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984 and the Public Service Act 1922 as a consequence of the restructuring of the Australian Federal Police by the Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

Currently the Australian Federal Police incurs very high invalidity costs. With the introduction of the unified work force there will be greater flexibility for redeployment of staff under the Comcare arrangements. Additionally, members will have the opportunity at the end of their fixed term appointments to make career changes with the financial support offered by the accumulated adjustment scheme, thereby avoiding the stress related illnesses so common in the force. Future cost benefits will accrue from reduction in invalidities and the absence of retrenchment provisions in the Australian Federal Police Act.

The Australian Federal Police adjustment Scheme (AFPAS) payments will be in the order of $5.4m in current dollar terms in the year 2020, based on an AFPAS payment of 12 1/2 per cent of a police member's or a staff member's accumulated salary. This payment will be taxed as an eligible termination payment. The first significant payment of AFPAS estimated at $0.8m, will occur in 1991-92. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON AIR SAFETY ISSUES ARISING OUT OF THE PILOTS DISPUTE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday I gave notice of a motion to appoint a select committee to be known as the Select Committee on Air Safety Issues Arising Out of the Pilots Dispute, seeking an inquiry into the implication for Australia's outstanding record of aviation safety of any changes to procedures or regulations introduced since the commencement of the pilots dispute and reports of mistakes or breaches of normal operational standards during the same period which could jeopardise the safety of air travellers, and that the Committee report to the Senate on or before 25 October 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: I should perhaps say that today has not been the best day for having discussions with the Australian Democrats. They seemed to be in a state of considerable perturbation all of yesterday and this morning following the matters which have been the subject of some 2 1/2 hours of debate in this chamber. This morning the Democrats indicated that they were not disposed to support this motion. I had a subsequent discussion with Senator Ray, who can of course speak for himself in this place, and he indicated that whilst the Government would oppose the motion if it were moved today, he was prepared to consider the possibility of an inquiry and would also ensure that the matter would be brought on for debate on Friday of this sitting week. I think that is a very sensible approach on behalf of the Government and I propose to have discussions with the Government about the inquiry.

I would like to make it clear that, after a period in which we have seen a good deal of stunting in the chamber for all sorts of good political reasons, the Opposition regards this as a very serious matter. It is quite clear that we have a very unusual set of airline services in Australia at the moment. There have been a series of reports, a number of which we have raised in the Senate and some of which we still await answers on, about problems of safety standards. We believe that it is an appropriate role for a Senate committee to simply examine whether the normal procedures that are laid down by the Government are being followed.

I do not wish to abuse the leave which has been given to me by the Senate, but I want to touch on the need for early reporting. The Opposition's concern is simply that the important time to ensure that safety standards are imposed is now. We do not see this as an academic exercise, but rather a severely practical exercise at a time when, as I say, the airline system is under very considerable stress. I will therefore take up the matter with Senator Ray and the Minister responsible and we can deal with the matter in substance on Friday morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Senator Chaney has alluded to, we have not had discussion around the chamber on this particular issue. The Government would not normally oppose an inquiry into air safety. My main concern is with the reporting date 21 days hence and thus whether that inquiry could be a real inquiry or not. I acknowledge two points made by Senator Chaney: firstly, that there are changed circumstances now; and, secondly, that maybe some of the more technical questions could not have been answered immediately at Question Time yesterday. I think we should have discussions between the various parties in the chamber and the responsible Minister to see whether we can set up a reasonable inquiry. There was opportunity, of course, at Estimates Committee B yesterday for this to be followed up.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that Senator Chaney has forgone his opportunity this morning I will not seek to block him on Friday. If he moves for the suspension of Standing Orders to bring this matter on, we will automatically accede because we do not want him to forgo his rights in this chamber. Let us see what turns up in the next two days. We will see whether we can organise some discussions to get agreement; if not, we will battle it out on Friday.
