DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 September 1989.
ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, it is ridiculous, is it not, that we have about six minutes left before the break for lunch. I will try to start the arguments on our amendment No. 59. I remind the Committee that when we last met we had introduced that part of the argument which went to our general proposition, that this is an inappropriate clause in that it confuses the duties which properly lie with the Department with those duties which properly lie with the statutory authority. I am not going to repeat those arguments. The Committee has voted on that principle in the previous three amendments and we have lost each division. I will not go back over that.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 226 relates to two proposed amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. They are interesting and quite unusual proposals from the Government. The first is to alter the secrecy provisions that exist within that principal Act by amending section 23e. The second, subclause 226 (3), proposes a new section 64b relating to land council trust funds. The secrecy provisions are interesting. The principal Act contains at section 23e some provisions relating to secrecy. It identifies certain people as `an authorized person; a member of a Land Council; or a member of the staff of a Land Council' and then provides some protection against the unauthorised disclosure of material that those people may have learned. Section 23e then goes on further to create some exclusions from that particular duty. Section 23 e subsection (3) of the principal Act states:
Subsection (2) does not prevent the communication of information or the production of a document by a person authorized by a Land Council for the certain purpose-
to the Minister, to the Permanent Head of the Department . . .

And it is proposed now to add a new class of persons to whom those disclosures may be made. In other words, what is proposed here is that the secrecy provisions in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act which confer protection are to be diminished slightly by the addition of a new class of person. I draw the attention of members of the Committee to page 87 of the Bill we are considering and the proposal to add after subsection (3) of section 23e of the principal Act a new paragraph (ba) to provide that certain senior officers or delegated officers of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission should fall within that class of persons to whom that part of the principal Act shall apply.

What is curious is that the effect of this amendment would be to put the Chief Executive Officer and the staff of ATSIC on a par with departmental officers. We have already argued that that is one more example of the confusion in the Government's mind between the proper role and function of a statutory authority like ATSIC and a department of state such as the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. But a curious anomaly appears to arise now if one looks at the principal Act and the amendment and tries to read them together. If section 23e (3) (ba)-I am sorry to use that convoluted language, but that is what we are talking about-is inserted as proposed what will be the position of the commissioners of ATSIC? They are not among the designated persons proposed to be added. If the elected commissioners are not to be authorised to receive confidential information they may not be able to be told of matters for which the Commission has a responsibility and about which the Commission has to make decisions.

I draw the attention of members of the Committee to clause 7 (h) of the Bill we are considering. We have already discussed this clause but members of the Committee will recall that that clause enables the commissioners to take action to protect Aboriginal heritage. How are they going to do that? If some of their officers acquire these new duties and responsibilities under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and obtain certain capacities to receive certain confidential information they cannot then pass it on to their own commissioners because the commissioners are not among the people designated to receive that information. If they do receive it I think from memory they are liable to a penalty of $2,000 and/or 12 months gaol. So it is a fairly substantial prohibition against the improper release of confidential information. How will the commissioners discharge their duty under clause 7 (h), that is the clause which enables them to protect Aboriginal heritage, when their own staff, apparently-as we read it-will not be able to tell them things communicated to them by the land councils?

Before we can consider this further and come to a vote we have to have that matter explained to us by the Minister and by the Department. Later I wish to talk about the proposal in relation to trust accounts and the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account, which is a matter itself of some concern to members of the Committee, but I see the time and I therefore will try to come back to that later at a more appropriate time.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of giving people something to think of over lunch time, I say that I am advised, of course, that the commissioners do not by virtue of clause 7 (h) of this Bill obtain responsibilities under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 but I also draw the attention of honourable senators in any case to section 23e (3) (c) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act which permits the divulging and communication of information or documents to a person to whom, in the opinion of the Minister, it is in the public interest that the information be communicated or the document produced. I think somewhere there we might find the answer.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 12.45 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly--
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer to last night's hearing of Estimates Committee B in which the Minister undertook to consider whether the Government would release a legal opinion obtained from the Attorney-General's Department as to the validity of a direction given to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis. Will the Minister make the opinion available? Does he now concede that the proper processes for the waiver of fees under the Civil Aviation Act were not followed and that the direction is clearly beyond the Minister's power? Is it a fact that, despite the Prime Minister's public statement three weeks ago that the Government would waive landing and navigation fees otherwise payable by the airlines, it was not until 28 September last that the Minister issued the direction? Was this delay occasioned by the refusal of the CAA to accept any responsibility for waiving charges even though its Act specifically allows it to do so? Is it a fact that no direction at all has been given to the Federal Airports Corporation? In these circumstances, as the purported fee waivers are clearly invalid, will the Government immediately seek to recover the millions of dollars already outstanding?

—Mr President, on a point of order: I seek your guidance more than anything else as to whether this question is directed to Senator Bolkus's portfolio responsibilities. It is one of those awkward cases where a Minister fills in for another Minister in an Estimates committee.
—On the point of order, Mr President: I directed the question to Senator Bolkus because it was he who quite generously undertook to make inquiries about the opinion.

—In reply to the point of order, the matter is clearly not within Senator Bolkus's portfolio area, but I think he has been asked whether he will release a document. If he wants to answer the question I will allow it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me put this question in its full and proper context. Between 11.30 and midnight last night Senator Alston did in fact ask for the legal advice. In response to that question, of course, I--
—I did.

—Oh, Senator Newman, was it? Senator Newman had asked for it and Senator Alston, having done his tour of the Parliament that night, came in and also made inquiries about it. So we had a double-pronged question from the Opposition very late last night. Just before lunch today in running into Senator Alston I got a repeat request. I assured Senator Alston that we had been in touch with the Minister's office and that I was waiting for a response. That response has not come through, but as we said last night, we will try to get a response as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question canvassed the legality or otherwise of the action taken, arising from the advice that the Opposition has requested. As was made clear last night by departmental officers, their understanding is that the Government has acted in accordance with the law. The interpretation of section 62 (2) of the relevant Act indicates that the Government has done so. Senator Alston, as a lawyer, would recognise, probably more clearly than most people in this place, that if one wants to get a lawyer's opinion on any direction one can, but the advice on--

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you approach a reputable lawyer?

—If I were approaching a reputable lawyer, it probably would not be someone with Senator Alston's experience. In conclusion, on the premise that the advice was, as indicated by the officers last night, that the Government has acted in accordance with the law, the rest of Senator Alston's questions are not within my responsibility and are also academic.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am quite sure that it was at least 10 o'clock last night when I asked the question. Therefore, is the Minister saying that in the 16 hours that have intervened since that time--
—He might have gone to bed. He might have had a sleep.

—But I expect that the officers of the relevant Department did not. Is the Minister saying that in the intervening period he has not sought any advice as to the matters raised last night, which were very serious questions and which I think cast considerable doubt over the legality of the direction? It was in fact section 12 which the Minister will recall seemed to be in conflict with section 66. I simply ask whether the Minister is telling the Senate that nothing has been done since that time, other than his putting in a casual request for the opinion.

—In between doing the normal things that people do at night, like sleeping and then having a shower when one wakes up, as I have already responded to Senator Alston, we have in fact sought a response from the Minister. When that is forthcoming the honourable senator will get it as soon as possible.

—I refer the Minister for Resources to the latest release of the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE). I ask the Minister: Is it true that ABARE expects strong growth in mineral production and export volumes in 1988-89 which will generate increases in Australian commodity export earnings by 9 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say to Senator McKiernan that yes, it is true, and it is another example of the successful micro-economic reform engaged in by the Hawke Government. The September issue of the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly released by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics indicates that commodity exports are expected to grow strongly in 1989-90 by 9 per cent, to take our export earnings to $39.8 billion from commodity exports alone. That follows a 6 per cent increase in commodity export growth in 1988-89. Last year the growth obtained mainly because of increased prices. In the forecast period the growth will be because of a mixture of prices and greater volumes. Because greater volumes play a part it is clear that the efficiencies effected within the economy and within the mining sector, under this Government's policies, have contributed to the ability to win and expand those markets.

ANSWER.PARA: For mineral exports, the forecast for growth is even better. It is forecast at 15 per cent for 1989-90 or $23.5 billion, compared with a 9 per cent growth in the previous year. If one looks at the particular commodities one can see that in coal we are expecting growth in total exports of 103.5 million tonnes, up from 99.3 million tonnes in 1988-89, or in earnings terms this year $5.5 billion instead of $4.6 billion last year. In aluminium and alumina we are expecting exports to increase by 4 per cent this year and to reach five million tonnes. In liquefied natural gas (LNG) we are expecting $360m in earnings in 1989-90, and for that to increase three times in the next few years. Indeed, at peak production Australia is expected to supply 12 per cent of the world's production in LNG. Nickel exports are forecast to rise slightly to $780m in 1989-90 from $770m last year. Iron ore exports are expected to rise from $1.8 billion last year to $2.2 billion this year, an increase of 23 per cent. In crude oil and condensate, production is expected to reach a record level of 560 million barrels a day this year, and additional production from the North West Shelf and the Timor Sea has the potential to more than offset marginal decline in Bass Strait production this year. In gold, exports are forecast to be worth $2.9 billion this year with total Australian production increasing by 13 per cent over the previous financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: this is an absurd use of Question Time. The answer is a ministerial statement and contains an enormous amount of detail which clearly the Minister has brought in and put somebody up to ask him about. He has been going for about five minutes now, Mr President, and I raise an objection on the grounds of prolixity, if nothing else, and suggest that in the interests of an orderly Question Time you call the Minister to order.
—Order! There is no point of order, but I would remind Senator Cook that it is a very long answer.

—Thank you, Mr President. I will shortly curtail the answer, but the answer involves the giving of information. I am giving honourable senators information. They do not like the information because they do not like to see a healthy forecast for the Australian economy in the next 12 months. We expect that gold exports will be Australia's fourth largest commodity group this year and account for 7 per cent of the total value of all commodity exports. On mineral sands, we expect a rise in production of 11 per cent to earn $591m in exports this year, copper exports to rise by 3 per cent and zinc exports to rise by 6 per cent. All in all, across the sector of mineral commodities we are looking at growth and increased earnings because of better prices being able to be negotiated and better volumes being able to be traded. All those things reflect on this Government's ability to manage the economy better.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to information provided to Senate Estimates Committee B last night which shows that Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines Ltd aircraft are currently carrying only 29 per cent of those now travelling by air, which is a mere 16 per cent of their normal air passenger traffic. In view of these facts, when does the Government expect the airlines to approach anything like normal traffic capacity?
—Sixteen per cent?

—Sixteen per cent of their normal air passenger traffic. How long is the Government prepared to allow this totally unacceptable situation to continue before it takes some constructive action such as directing Australian Airlines to negotiate with the pilots or any organisation nominated by them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question again establishes the Opposition's credentials of seeking to make capital out of a very serious situation for the Australian community. I say that in the full knowledge that in the last six weeks the Opposition has changed tack nearly every week with different opinions from the Leader of the Opposition and other Opposition spokesmen about how the airlines dispute might be resolved. Every week there is a new solution. The Opposition's position is nowhere better summed up in this whole matter than by the statement 10 days ago by the Leader of the Opposition who said, `I keep on waffling about this subject'. That is the best example of leadership Opposition members have had from him because the whole lot of them keep on waffling about this subject. The Opposition should try to make less capital and be more constructive.
—On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is debating the question. I ask that you direct him to answer it or to refrain and sit down.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister can answer the question.
—The last part of the question asked why the Government did not direct the parties to do this and direct the parties to do that.
—Tell us what it said.

—The question said, `Direct the airlines to negotiate with the pilots or their representatives'. Senator Chaney is an expert on the question. He probably wrote it like he writes half the questions for the Opposition which is incapable of thinking of them itself. I am unable to say, because the duration of this dispute is not yet determined, and cannot be determined by anybody, how long the current capacity provided by the airlines themselves will be maintained. If one looks at today's announcement by Australian Airlines one sees that from 9 October it will be announcing regular schedules and offering additional flights. I am not able to say what that will represent in terms of seat capacity, but of course it will represent a substantial increase in seat capacity provided for Australian passengers. That will be in addition to the capacity provided by its competitor, Ansett, and international airlines and the Royal Australian Air Force.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the settlement of this dispute is concerned, the matter is currently being negotiated by the Industrial Relations Commission. The Commission last week said that the best thing people could do would be to stop interfering, giving advice to the parties and so on. If Senator Newman or Senator Stone-who frequently pontificates on this matter on the airwaves-would be quiet for a little while we might get a better and quicker resolution of this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen reports of the remarks by the latest Queensland Minister for Family Services about sole parents and the proposal to remove sole parent pensions for young single women who get pregnant? Do these remarks form a considered approach to sole parents and their children? Does the Minister see any merit in this proposal? How does this approach fit with the Government's child support scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the question that Senator Crowley raises is a serious one, and particularly serious if one is a child in Queensland. I have seen the call by Mrs Nelson for the Federal Government to abolish the sole parent pension.
—She did nothing of the kind.
—Senator Stone is a failed bureaucrat; let me answer the question.
—Order!

—It is a policy that can only arise from someone in the Cooper Government. It is also a policy which is based very much on prejudice and ignorance. The reality is that this Government is concerned about children and, in terms of poverty, children living in sole parent families rate the highest. They are in the greatest need in this general category. The majority of children of sole parents-in fact, 80 per cent-are children of parents who have been in a marriage which has broken down. Only 2.8 per cent of sole parents are teenagers. Let me repeat that: 80 per cent, an overwhelming majority, of those people that Mrs Nelson wants to exclude from sole parent pensions are in fact from--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Is it in order for the Minister to give a response to a question which is based upon a totally inaccurate and totally untruthful misrepresentation of remarks by a Minister in another government?
—Order! There is no point of order. I cannot be responsible for how a Minister answers a question.
—If there is any doubt about this, let me refer to an article in the Brisbane Courier-Mail which states:
—Senator Stone has no faith in anyone but himself.
—Order!
—The article states:

ANSWER.PARA: Mrs Nelson also has urged the Federal Government to phase out the benefit to single mothers over a five year period. She said this would let single mothers obtain skills and allow their children to reach school age.

There is no doubt about it. She has called on the Federal Government to do so. The Federal Government will not do so; the Federal Government's response to child poverty, particularly to children in this area, has been to pursue an integrated strategy to provide assistance and opportunities for sole parents who are amongst, as I said, the most disadvantaged and the poorest groups in the community. We have done so not only in terms of financial assistance but also in terms of assistance through the jobs, education and training program Newstart and particularly the child support scheme, which Senator Crowley asked about. I raise the child support scheme because this scheme in particular is a radical reform which has led to a massive shift in the level of maintenance available to sole parents. What the child support scheme has meant is that both the custodial and non-custodial parent will have to bear full financial responsibility for their children. There has been an increase of 40 per cent in the numbers helped under this scheme compared to those helped under previous schemes. It has been a major assistance scheme for children living in sole parent families.

The scheme itself has been operating for some time now but because of the limitations of the Federal Constitution it can only apply to children of marriages. That of course was up to last Sunday, when all States but Queensland adopted stage 2 of the child support scheme and accordingly in all States but Queensland children of parents who have not been married are now covered by the child support scheme. What this in fact means is that Mrs Nelson not only wants children in these situations-as I said, the most disadvantaged groups in the community-to get no Federal benefit but also has denied them access to resources from the non-custodial parents. It is something that on this side of the Parliament we cannot agree with.

The reason why the Queensland Government has not adopted the child support scheme, stage 2, has been literally a lack and a failure of leadership. In the last 22 months there have been five Ministers for Family Services in Queensland and there have been five other Ministers with whom they have had to meet-Ministers for justice-to work out a common position. Not only have they not been able to meet each other to adopt a response to the child support scheme, stage 2, but they have not even prepared legislation to introduce in Parliament to that effect. Even if they had prepared that legislation the Queensland Parliament meets so briefly that it would not have had time to introduce it. So the short response is: this Federal Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —What! The short response! You could not give a short answer if your life depended on it.

—You will be all right when your voice breaks. Mr President, the short response is: we are concerned about children of sole parent families, whether those families are from marriages which have broken down or otherwise. Our concern stands very much in stark contrast to the neglect, prejudice and ignorance of the National Party Government in Queensland.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Kuala Lumpur and ask him: Is it correct that the future of the people of Hong Kong and the future of the people of Fiji under the new constitution are not on the agenda for debate at this meeting? Has the Australian Government sought to put these two matters, which are quite clearly of vital importance to the Commonwealth community, on the agenda for discussion at that meeting and, if not, why not?

—I thank Senator Macklin for his question. I frankly do not know the answer. They would seem to me to be topics which would naturally be on the agenda of such a meeting but there may be other things which have been seen as having priority. I will find out what is on the agenda and if these items are not on the agenda I will find out why not.

—I direct a question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of the campaign by the Wilderness Society to have a ban placed on the importation of rainforest timber from environmentally sensitive regions of Brazil and Malaysia? Is the Minister aware of a statement by Wilderness Society coordinator, Mr Len Constantini, which claims that he is very confident that a ban will be placed on the importation of rainforest timber by the end of this year? Is there any basis for Mr Constantini's confident predictions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Wilderness Society's position on this. It does quite actively seek a ban on the imports of rainforest timber. The Prime Minister, I think, made the point in his environment statement in July that the preservation of tropical rainforests is, of course, given the countries involved, a complex one and obviously it is a very sensitive issue. It is not such a sensitive issue in Australia now, given that we have stopped rainforest logging in the wet tropics, by virtue of World Heritage listing. We have, of course, a national rainforest program now, involving an expenditure of $22m. We have allocated $1m for the Tropical Rainforest Institute in Cairns. Internationally it is much more complex and, while Australia has donated some $250,000 to a plan for a very large reserve in the Amazon Basin, there are some difficulties in looking at a ban.

ANSWER.PARA: We would need first to have all the information available. We would need to know what alternatives there are, particularly in the building industry, to the use of rainforest timbers. There are other types of timbers that could be used. There is some steel that could be used, et cetera. We would need to know what impacts would result from switching to them. So that we might obtain all of that information my Department has just let a consultancy to Coopers and Lybrand, acting with a company called Fortech. We hope that the results of that study will be available late this year or early next year. But certainly not until all the information was at hand would the Government consider any sort of ban, and I would not share the confidence that the gentleman to whom the honourable senator has referred has expressed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TOURIST INDUSTRY: EFFECT OF PILOTS DISPUTE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to the continuing devastation of the Australian tourism industry through bankruptcies, hotel closures and a long term loss of confidence in Australia as a major tourist destination as a result of the pilots dispute. What is the Government's current estimate of monetary and job losses caused by the Government's gross mismanagement of this dispute? Does the Minister still agree with the Prime Minister's original description of these losses as minor and transitory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, there have been losses in the tourist industry. One wonders how they are going to be calculated. It is not an industry in which the losses would be easy to calculate because of the secondary effects, which are much harder to see than the more obvious. In some areas of Australia the effect on the tourism industry has been dramatic and in other areas it has been nowhere near as bad. So I would not attempt to place a figure on it; I have no idea. However, the Government is at the moment consulting with the industry to look at what it believes would be an appropriate figure for a recovery phase for the industry. When all that information is to hand there will be further discussions between the industry, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, and the Prime Minister. Presumably, at the end of that there will be a Cabinet submission. I shall inform the Senate on the progress of those discussions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GOVERNMENT BODIES: SECURITY OF PERSONAL INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Recent revelations disclose that the personal details of millions of Australians have been regularly traded illegally between various government bodies on microfiche, computer discs and by facsimile machine. Among the organisations involved are the Australian Electoral Commission, the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Department of Science, Customs and Small Business. Not only this, but government bodies have passed information to banking, private investigation and credit reference circles where it is circulating freely. As the privacy provisions relied on so completely by this socialist Government are being so flagrantly and constantly broken, will the Leader take action to institute criminal prosecution against the perpetrators in an attempt to restore our confidence in the system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, of course, has been very concerned about allegations of leaks from various departments and government instrumentalities. Investigations have been initiated by the Australian Federal Police. In respect of the question of the Department of Social Security, the Privacy Commissioner is investigating the matter and the Government will provide any necessary assistance to that investigation. Severe penalties can, of course, be applied to persons who have not handled properly personal information given to the Government. The Government will consider the findings of the investigations, both by the Privacy Commissioner and by the Federal Police, and take any steps necessary to prevent a repetition of such breaches.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the Customs matter, to which Senator Sheil adverted in his question, inquiries have already revealed that there are some 26 places involving various departments, overseas agencies and so on, from which that information could have been illegally obtained. So such investigations as that I imagine will take a little time. But the Government is certainly concerned about the matter and every possible effort is being made to track down the perpetrators.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I ask the Minister to outline what action is being taken to ensure that imported foods comply with Australian food standards and do not pose a health risk to Australian consumers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question. The question of the safety and wholesomeness of imported food is an issue which has been addressed by government for quite some time now. In fact, it also has been the subject of an inquiry by a working party for quite some time. Recently four Ministers-the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and I-responded to the problem with a comprehensive overview of the situation which addresses the sorts of problems that exist now and tried to lay down a program for future action in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: A whole host of problems have arisen in this area. I must say that a small proportion-not a major proportion-of imported food poses a serious health risk and problems in this area have arisen from products as diverse as Peter's Drumsticks to Kraft beefsteak and vegies. In terms of contamination, some of the problems have been listeria, glass fragments, salmonella and so on. So, as I said, there has been a significant risk from a small proportion of imported food.

The Government found that the currently operating arrangements were not adequate to ensure either the safety or the wholesomeness of imported food and it also felt that they do not provide an adequate level of protection to consumers. At present, only a small number of high risk foods are systematically checked at the point of entry and, as for the rest, there are random checks at the point of sale by either State or local officials. We have judged that this sort of response has been inadequate to address the problem. In terms of new arrangements, the Government has been concerned to get in place a uniform and effective program based on full recovery which could also act as a deterrent to importers, make sure that they play the game by the rules and ensure that all food sold in Australia complies with Australian food standard regulations.

We have also been keen to ensure that we have not deviated from trade obligations and our proposal puts us very much in line with what operates in New Zealand, the United States of America, Canada and the United Kingdom. Under the new arrangements, an imported food risk advisory committee with representation from government departments, scientists, industries, importers and consumers will classify imported food for testing. There will also be further discussions with exporters and importers in the States. The new system will apply to both processed and unprocessed food and products will be classified as high, medium or low public risk. Obviously, those of high risk will be subject to inspections on arrival in Australia. As for the others, there will be systematic checking as is necessary. The Government believes that our response in this area, for the first time, presents Australian consumers with a comprehensive and uniform response to an area which has been of concern to quite a number of people in the community. Uniformity across the country will ensure that importers, manufacturers and others have only one set of laws with which to comply.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it true that at least five, and possibly seven, examiners of airmen have resigned from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in the past few weeks? Given that the role of examiners is to examine pilots and maintain safety standards in the airlines, how can this relatively high loss be tolerated without compromising the safety of the travelling public?
—Mr President, I do not know how many examiners have resigned in the past few weeks.
—What do you know?

—Senator, let me make it quite clear that the Civil Aviation Authority has taken all steps within its power, and they are considerable, to see that safety regulations and provisions relating to the airlines are maintained at the highest possible standard. It may be the burden of Senator Crichton-Browne's political message to come in here with leaks from the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and any bit of scuttlebutt it likes to put out and ask questions about it and then suggest that it is not good enough.
—When did I do that? Give me one single question I have asked on the subject.

—The implication is there in the interjection which Senator Crichton-Browne has just made. There have of course been a great deal of uninformed comments on the arrangements that have been made by the Civil Aviation Authority and these allegations are, in a sense, part of a concerted campaign to destabilise public confidence in an attempt by the airlines to provide the necessary services. If that occurs there is a danger that the efforts of the airlines to rebuild their services will be undermined. I want to make the point that through various public announcements the Government has bent over backwards, including releases from the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Ros Kelly, and the Civil Aviation Authority itself, to assure the public that the Civil Aviation Authority will not authorise any operation in Australia unless it is completely satisfied about the safety of that operation. The head safety regulator, Mr Colin Freeland, held a press conference for 45 minutes in Parliament House recently. It was publicly advertised and, unfortunately, this did not get the degree of attention which one might have expected from the Opposition or, for that matter, from the media. The CAA is fully available to any quarter wanting information regarding safety aspects of current arrangements. If there are legitimate concerns I suggest that people seek briefings from the CAA on them. As far as I am aware there has not been one contact from the Opposition to the CAA on any of these issues. Senator MacGibbon's question comes up in the context of saying five or seven examiners have resigned from the CAA recently. I do not know what that means in terms of the overall composition of the work force of the CAA. I will endeavour to find out for the honourable senator just what percentage of the total examiner complement of the CAA that represents. But without information like that, the question is meaningless and just another bit of scuttlebutt.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Speaking as a liberal, not as a conservative-I put the Minister right on that point-I would like him to follow up with his questions to find out the backgrounds of those few examiners of airmen who have been signed on by the Civil Aviation Authority? Is it true that they have come out of third level operators, charter operators, and from the lesser airwork categories and, in fact, have no experience in heavy public transport aircraft or in airline operations at all?

—It is in the honourable senator's interests to suggest that sort of thing in the form of a question, as he has been doing diligently over the past week or so. I begin to wonder what his vested interest in the pilots dispute is.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister clearly is making an unparliamentary imputation. I ask him to withdraw.
—The Minister will withdraw.

—I withdraw the allegation of vested interest in so far as it applies to Senator MacGibbon personally. What I was talking about was the Opposition having a political vested interest in raising these issues of lack of safety.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JOINT DEFENCE FACILITIES AT PINE GAP AND NURRUNGAR

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I draw the Minister's attention to correspondence directed to the Minister for Defence from Senator Macklin on 2 February 1989 and 5 June, and the Minister's subsequent replies and I ask: Could the Minister justify to the Senate and the Australian people why the Australian Democrats have been excluded as a party from access to classified information on the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar, given that this material is available to Government Ministers, Opposition leaders and Opposition spokespersons on defence and foreign affairs? Can the Minister also confirm that classified visits are made not only by Australian members of parliament and United States congressmen, but by the staff of parliamentarians and congressmen as well? Furthermore, could the Minister inform the Senate why the Government considers that Senator Macklin, the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, the Democrat spokesperson on foreign affairs and a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, and I, as Australian Democrats spokesperson on defence and a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, are unfit to make a classified visit to the facilities? Can the Minister not accept that the Australian Democrats find this attitude of the Government in excluding their members offensive, illogical and totally unacceptable in a democratic society? Will the Minister, therefore, immediately extend the same privilege of access accorded to United States nationals and Australian members of parliament to the Australian Democrats?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked a series of questions, not all of which I was able to take down.
—You have been aware of them for many months.

—There were a great many, Senator. I am asked whether I am aware of correspondence last February, I think, between Senator Macklin and the Minister for Defence. The answer to that is no, I am not aware of the correspondence. I am not sure what was in it, but I will endeavour, of course, to find out. Further, as a result of what is apparently in that correspondence, I am asked: Is the fact that Democrats are not allowed an inspection of the base unacceptable in a democratic society? My view of the Democrats is shared by many here. I am not certain, however, what Mr Beazley's view is. I will ascertain that. I can only say that from my point of view the Australian Government would always want to be very careful indeed about who is allowed into secure installations. To that end, I note that members of my own Party complained about lack of access. In that sense, neither Senator McLean nor Senator Macklin could claim to be Robinson Crusoes. I will endeavour to find out from Mr Beazley why he has refused them permission, and try to let Senator McLean know by the end of Question Time or tomorrow.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that on 22 September at 3.15 p.m. an American Air West Boeing 737 aircraft, licence No. N166AW, crossed runway 12 at Adelaide Airport at 60 kilometres an hour without first obtaining a clearance to cross the runway, which is mandatory under Australian regulations? Is it a fact that this was the same circumstance that led to the tragic accident at Tenerife some years ago when two Boeing 747s collided, with massive loss of life? What disciplinary action was taken against the pilot in command?

—I do not know whether that is a fact. I do know that if the Opposition was as interested in air safety generally as it appears to be this week it would be able to ask this kind of question day after day in relation to near accidents or minor breaches of the air traffic control regulations and so on. These things happen in every country on a regular basis. Senator Messner asked me about a particular circumstance. I am not familiar with the facts. I will see whether I can obtain an answer for him.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support aware of claims by an organisation on the Gold Coast called Television Advertising Watch that prime time advertising on television has increased by over 100 per cent in the past two years? Could this increase be due to the decision by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) to repeal advertising time rules for a two-year trial period which finishes this month? If the organisation's claims are correct, is the Government satisfied that television stations have responded responsibly to the two-year trial period of self-regulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the existence of the organisation Television Advertising Watch because of a newspaper cutting which appeared in the Gladstone Observer on 14 September 1989. I am not saying I read the Gladstone Observer avidly every day, every week, every month, or whenever it is published, but the press cutting was made available to me. I am advised that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's research does not support the claim that the amount and duration of prime time advertising on television has increased by over 100 per cent in the past two years. An information paper, which is part of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's proposed advertising time on television inquiry and is to be released by the ABT in late October 1989, will provide detailed information on trends in the amount of advertising over the last two years.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed inquiry will examine the ways in which licensees have responded to the opportunity to experiment with the ad-program mixture in the last two years, during which time rules limiting the amount of advertising were removed. The trial ended on 23 September 1989. The success or failure of the trial will be assessed against criteria which were published in the ABT's report Advertising Time on Television: A Review of the Advertising Time Standards published in September 1987.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RELATIONS WITH THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA AND THE GERMAN DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button, representing in his absence the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I note that this week sees the fortieth anniversary of both the People's Republic of China and the German Democratic Republic. With regard to the former, I note the appropriate boycott by the Australian Ambassador in Beijing of the Chinese Government's defiant celebrations in Tiananmen Square on the very site of the June massacre. However, with regard to the anniversary occasion in East Germany, I have not been made aware of any appropriate protest at the equally defiant Honecker Government in its monstrous maintenance of the Berlin Wall. I call on the Australian Government now to protest the obscenity of the wall and to join with, firstly, the people of East Germany themselves who in their thousands are crowding onto freedom trains to flee the country and to pour their own contempt on the offence of the wall; secondly, the Government of Hungary in its singularly refreshing recent actions to support freedom of passage and to demolish its own international fences; and, thirdly, the protest by heads of government, including President Bush, Prime Minister Thatcher and even, it would appear, Soviet President Gorbachev.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague seeks to draw an analogy between events in China of fairly recent happening and the 40-year-old history of the German Democratic Republic and the almost continual period during that Republic's regime of the existence of the Berlin Wall. In the last couple of weeks 35,000 refugees have left the German Democratic Republic, exiting through Hungary, as Senator Teague pointed out. Senator Teague asks what protest is the Government making about the continued existence of the Berlin Wall.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, as distinct from China, we do not have an embassy in the German Democratic Republic which would logically be a vehicle for making any such protest. But I will, of course, pass the request on to the Acting Foreign Minister. No protest has been made at this time by the Australian Government as far as I am aware.

In undertaking to pass it on, I point to the enormous changes in political movements and ideas taking place in middle and eastern Europe at present. I guess many political regimes are seeking to accommodate those changes, and pressures to accommodate are being exercised from a variety of sources. I am not convinced that a protest by Australia about the 40-year existence of the Berlin Wall would add anything in terms of the forces which we would like to encourage in Eastern Europe and particularly the German Democratic Republic. However, I will pass the honourable senator's request on and if the Minister has anything to add to what I have said I will let him know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of rumours which are circulating among some in the business community that the Government intends to amend affirmative action legislation to provide for penalties for non-conformity? Is there any basis for these rumours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of such rumours circulating in the business community. I can certainly assure the Senate and the business community that there is absolutely no truth in these rumours. The Government is well satisfied with the way the affirmative action legislation is operating at the moment and, according to the latest figures we have, over 95 per cent of the 484 employers required to report in this round have done so. As I have said in this place before and as the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, has also indicated, the affirmative action legislation is working and working well. It is gaining acceptance from the business community and we welcome this. Far from suggesting that there should be penalties or any change in the legislation, I am pleased to inform the Senate that on 11 September Mr Morris, speaking at the launch of Portfolio magazine's Affirmative Action Awards, which have been introduced to provide some recognition of the excellent work that the business sector is doing in implementing affirmative action, said:

ANSWER.PARA: Already it is evident that there are many employers taking initiatives beyond the requirements of the legislation, which are breaking down the barriers to give women a fair go at work.

It is time to recognise and reward the excellent and innovative efforts which many employers are making in their affirmative action for women measures . . . These awards will highlight, to the public and other employers, the practical achievements which some employers are making.
Quite obviously, there is no truth in rumours about penalties and changes to the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Australian Government offered to accept any East German refugees during the present exodus? If not, why not? If so, how many will Australia be accepting, particularly as so many are apparently highly qualified and some may even be air pilots?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the practice of the Australian Government actively to recruit a specific set of refugees. Certainly, all people who come to this country as refugees have their claims tested individually-not en masse, not as a class, not as a region, but individually. Quite clearly, some of those people who have left East Germany, as I have seen in the media interviews, have expressed an interest in coming to Australia. If they qualify as refugees under the United Nations definition of 1951 and the 1967 protocols they will be eligible to come to Australia. Our overall program this year is to take in 12,500 refugees with a 1,500 contingency reserve, which I point out is the highest per capita intake of any Western country. For instance, the United States of America will take 125,000 refugees only in this financial year. Those people coming from East Germany probably fall into two categories: those who wish to apply for refugee status and those who wish to come to Australia under the normal migration program, who again will be treated in a non-discriminatory way.

ANSWER.PARA: To some extent the East Germans are in a slightly separate category because they have a safe guaranteed country. There are many refugees around the world who do not have that, especially in our own region, and we might initially be more sympathetic to them. Again, there is no bar on it, but the Federal Republic of Germany has guaranteed every East German citizen safe abode in that country. It has offered them citizenship and it has offered them jobs. We are not debarring anyone from East Germany. We take approximately 2,000 refugees a year from eastern Europe. The predominant group so far in the last few years has been from the Soviet Union and from Poland; most of those from Poland are eventually processed out of Italy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that, but I ask him: Is the Australian Government doing anything to facilitate their applications administratively in the way that it has facilitated applications from other areas of the world? What security, health and police clearance arrangements would be available to ensure that such refugees were genuine, and to what extent would we be required to depend on East German authorities for such clearances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, Mr President, the supplementary question contains far more meat than the preliminary question. Senator Michael Baume asked whether we will apply a special program to East Germans. No, we will not. The situation in East Germany is not analogous to that in Sri Lanka or the Lebanon; quite clearly it is not. As for the necessary checks, the honourable senator has put his finger on precisely why we treat each claim individually. It is not possible to do security checks; I am hardly likely to write to Mr Honecker and ask for a security clearance for any of the people who have gone to the Federal Republic. Of course, health checks are done. Where people cannot meet the health requirements, we try to remedy that before they come to Australia. We do not just wipe off refugees directly. The necessary checks will be done.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the last implication made was that there could be a few bogus refugees who could later be involved in other activities. If any such people are discovered, of course they will not be given passage to Australia. Indeed, I do not think they would last very long in the Federal Republic. Of course, the discovery of such people is not an easy task, as successive West German governments have found.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. Is it a fact that housing is no longer affordable for the average one-income potential first home buyer in all but one of the mainland capital cities in Australia? These figures are 18 months old and the one exception is Perth, although I understand that is on the borderline now. Is it not reasonable to conclude from this that the Government's home ownership policy is based on the assumption that young families require two incomes to achieve what has long been the goal of Australian families and the policy of successive governments? Could the Minister please advise the Senate of the consequences of this situation on Australia's population, on the tax base that will be required to sustain the aged population in the next century and on youth employment opportunities at this time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some elements of this question go well beyond the purview of the portfolio--
—It hasn't stopped you before.

—Please be quiet. Some elements of this question go well beyond the purview of the portfolio of housing and aged care because the honourable senator has asked for information that clearly is not information to which I have access. I will inquire of the Minister or the relevant Ministers and, to the extent that I am able to, will obtain an answer. The first question referred to home loan affordability. A report recently put out by the Real Estate Institute of Australia refers to the June quarter 1989 data. It should be said that the Government recognises that data and that there has been some deterioration in home ownership affordability for recent and potential first home buyers due to higher interest rates and higher housing prices. While interest rates do impact on access to home ownership and its affordability, the best action that the Government can take is to ensure that the overall health of the economy is right.

ANSWER.PARA: As we are all well aware, house prices appear to have stabilised in the past six months with median prices plateauing in most major centres. Our preliminary data for the September quarter 1989 show that house prices in outer suburban areas of Sydney have stabilised over the last 12 months at about $110,000 for all home buyers and around $100,000 for first home buyers. The Real Estate Institute of Australia's data refers to established house prices paid by all home buyers. The fact is that housing costs faced by first home buyers are lower because first home buyers purchase less expensive properties. I cannot give a breakdown on the affordability of home purchase in capital cities other than Sydney, but I will take that on board with the other elements of the question and answer it in due course.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, 3 October, Senator Short asked me a question about capacity on the airlines, seating and so on. I did answer one part of his question by saying that clearly normal services are not being provided to some parts of Australia. But in respect of the question of capacity, a paper was tabled in the Estimates Committee last night. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables from that paper. I think they supply the information which Senator Short requires.

ANSWER.PARA: The attached table (1) indicates that, on average in the three months to 30 June 1989, the airlines (2) carried 34,838 passengers per day
Second attached table shows the number of seats made available each day for the period 18 September to 2 October
this figure is an estimate based on information received from a number of sources
the usual airline reporting arrangements are not available during the dispute

(2) Ansett Airlines of Australia, Australian Airlines, Ansett's Regional Airlines and East West Airlines
SCHEDULED DOMESTIC AIRLINE ACTIVITY TIME SERIES
NB: Seats available on total network including regionals

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a Question without Notice asked by Senator Short on 3 October 1989, relating to the airline pilots' dispute.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time Senator Newman asked me a question about the safety standards applicable to the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). In answer to that question I provide the following information: the RAAF operates its aircraft in accordance with its own standards. The Civil Aviation Authority is responsible only for the civil sector. However, it could not be suggested that RAAF pilots who fly Australian defence personnel, members of the public, members of parliament, Cabinet Ministers, the Prime Minister and other dignataries are not adequate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Knowles asked me a question about French pilots in Western Australia-six French pilots flying British Aerospace 146 aircraft. I provide her with the following information: French pilots are licensed by the French Aviation Regulatory Authority. The Australian Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has validated their licences for use in Australia pending issue of Australian equivalent licences. This process has involved a close examination of their qualifications and experience in consultation with the French authorities. Such validations are a common practice by aviation authorities around the world in recognition of the international nature of the industry. The validation process includes an examination in Australian air legislation. Some of the pilots failed this test on their first attempt and were permitted to resit that examination after 48 hours.

ANSWER.PARA: For administrative convenience the CAA usually allows the pilots 14 days between examination and the resitting of it to refresh their knowledge at leisure. In the present circumstances where the pilots were able to study immediately full time they were permitted to resit after a shorter interval. This in no way compromised safety. The CAA normally requires airline pilots flying in particular jet aircraft for the first time outside controlled air space to fly 50 hours in command under supervision on the particular routes. However, this can be varied where it is considered that other factors which contribute to safety are present. These can include extensive experience in operations and/or extensive experience on the aircraft type in use. The French pilots are very experienced on the BAe146 and they have all demonstrated their competence on the routes in Western Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 October Senator MacGibbon asked me a question about an alleged incident relating to air traffic control in Sydney and a French registered Air Maritime Boeing 737. On Thursday, 28 September, at about 11 p.m., a Boeing 737 aircraft operated by Air Maritime departed Sydney for Melbourne. The aircraft had been cleared by air traffic control to fly a standard instrument departure via Wollongong, thence to Melbourne by its planned flight route. The aircraft had planned to fly from Wollongong via Shelley, to Corryong and thence to Melbourne. The aircraft was under radar surveillance by Sydney air traffic control throughout its departure. When the aircraft passed over Wollongong and turned to track to Shelley the air traffic controller, noticing this turn, suggested to the captain that, as the more usual procedure did not involve passage via Shelley, he might wish to follow the normal direct route from Wollongong to Corryong.

ANSWER.PARA: This suggested change, together with some communications difficulties, caused some uncertainty and misunderstanding between the aircraft and air traffic control for a period. This, however, was resolved quickly and the aircraft proceeded on its planned route via Shelleys to Melbourne. The aircraft was under radar surveillance at all times. There was no other air traffic in the vicinity. There was no breakdown in separation and Sydney air traffic control judged that the circumstances did not warrant the raising of a formal incident report. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) regards this occurrence as being of a relatively minor nature and that the resolution was routine and well within the capacity of the air traffic control facilities available. The operator has been reminded of the normal practices associated with a standard instrument departure out of Sydney via Wollongong. Apart from routine operational surveillance activity, the CAA does not propose any further action with regard to this occurrence. There was no error on the part of the Air Maritime crew, as has been suggested by Senator MacGibbon.

A further disturbing element is Senator MacGibbon's deliberate attempt to create a picture of an imminent mid-air collision between two commercial airliners, with great loss of life. This is yet another clear example of the despicable scaremongering that is being driven by the Opposition at the behest of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to the interjections here today.
—Will you bear the responsibility--

—Will Senator Walters accept responsibility if there is an air accident? That is what it is all about, is it not? There is apparently no limit to the depths to which Senator MacGibbon and his Opposition colleagues are prepared to descend to create panic and uncertainty in the minds of the travelling public.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I seek your direction as to whether it is proper for the Minister, in the guise of debating the matter, to cast aspersions on the integrity of members on this side of the House when there is no evidence in support of his proposition. He is simply making unfounded and, I would suggest, defamatory assertions.
—Order! I have no power as to how a Minister answers a question. I do not think at this stage that he has made any unparliamentary remarks.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Button told the Senate that I had asked him a question--
—Interjected, I said.
—And he has refused to answer it. That question was: will he bear responsibility for any tragedy that occurs during this period? As he has heard the question, will he respond?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I was making the point about the Opposition's attempts to create uncertainty in the minds of the travelling public. In terms of the allegation made by Senator MacGibbon, contained in his question, I repeat that there were no other aircraft in the vicinity of the Air Maritime jet. Consequently, there was no prospect of a mid-air collision, as has been irresponsibly suggested by Senator MacGibbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a Question without Notice asked by Senator MacGibbon on 3 October 1989, relating to an alleged breach of aviation standards involving on Air Maritime Boeing 737 with French pilots operating a scheduled Sydney to Melbourne air service.

I wish to speak briefly to reject the pathetic but all too typical response we have had from Senator Button who indulges in personal abuse of anyone who challenges him in any way. Mr President, yesterday, following his incapacity to answer any questions in the Senate, Estimates Committee B was given a table which tells us of the state of Australian air traffic. We were told by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that we have 50 per cent capacity. Senator Button corrected that last Friday and admitted that that was incorrect. What we have, of course, is what we have described as a cobbled together set of air services. The Royal Australian Air Force and the Navy are carrying 14 per cent of traffic; 32 per cent is being carried in leased aircraft; 29 per cent, or less than a third, is being carried in aircraft which normally service this sector; and 6 per cent is being carried by commuter operators, 8 per cent by Qantas Airways Ltd and 11 per cent by foreign carriers.

The simple fact of the matter is that the whole airline system is operating under considerable stress. There is no question about that; no question at all. And in the course of what has been an extraordinarily drawn-out dispute, there have been significant allegations of variations of procedures as well as allegations about incidents. One of our own senators was taken on a charter flight under circumstances which certainly, I would suggest, show that systems are being stretched beyond their capacity. I think, in those circumstances, it is pathetic and absurd to suggest that the matter of safety is not of vital concern.

The Minister, who is making accusations of scaremongering, actually has to face up to the fact that there is not much point in worrying about deficiencies after there is an accident. The simple truth of the matter is that we have a system under stress. There have been reports of accidents-and some of those reports may be seeded by airline pilots who are not employed and who have a vested interest in putting pressure on the Government. I am not sure about that, Mr President; it would not be surprising if that happened. But the fact of the matter is there are also unchallenged, verified cases of normal procedures not being followed. When a fully laden passenger aircraft does not follow the normal procedures, turns in the wrong direction and has to be corrected by the airport control, then clearly there is a risk. When foreign-speaking pilots are involved, clearly there is some additional element of risk.

Mr President, all that I wish to say is that I think the Opposition has put forward a very sensible way of ensuring that the Parliament can check the substance of this matter. Tomorrow I will be discussing with the Minister what form of parliamentary inquiry might be undertaken, if any parliamentary inquiry is undertaken. I simply want to say that the Minister's pique in having these matters raised with him and being challenged is pathetic. The Opposition will not be cowed or blackmailed out of raising matters of public interest by the bad temper of this Minister. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, the point I was making is simply this: since this air pilots dispute began, the Opposition has behaved in a patently obvious manner. Some weeks it is for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and some weeks it is against it. Some spokesmen say this and some spokesmen say that. At the end of this period of six weeks we find the shadow Minister getting up here and complaining although 21 per cent of members of the business community in this country say that they have confidence in his industrial relations policy. What a bonanza the air pilots dispute was for an Opposition industrial relations spokesman. How he has failed in dealing with that bonanza-21 per cent have confidence in the way he has handled his shadow portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline the circumstance in which I answered this question today. Look at what Senator MacGibbon said yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Tiny; come on.
—I note Senator Chaney's `sizist' remarks if he wants to get into that stuff. He talks about me. What were my efforts, Senator? Come on, tell us.
—You tell us.
—The honourable senator will not. He makes the allegation; he should tell me. Yesterday Senator MacGibbon said:

SPEECH.PARA: What disciplinary action has been taken against these pilots? Not only could there have been a collision between two commercial airliners with great loss of life, but the accident could have occurred over southern suburban Sydney, possibly over a school, and even more lives could have been lost.

That was a question to me. Let us look at the judgments inherent in that question and how much Senator MacGibbon knew about it. The aircraft was south of Wollongong; there were no other aircraft involved, but that is the sort of question which has been fed to people like Senator MacGibbon about this dispute and which he gets up here and asks. I call that despicable scaremongering and I will not back off that sort of allegation because of wimpish explanations by Senator Chaney. I will not back away from that sort of allegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 September, Senator Harradine asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice about living costs. The Prime Minister has supplied an answer which contains detailed information to the honourable senator's question and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On September 28, Senator Harradine asked me in my capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice about costs of living.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in relation to the Honourable Senator's question:

``According to the results of the ABS Household Expenditure Survey, held in the second half of 1988, average weekly household expenditure on ``total commodity and service expenditure'', a proxy for food, housing and living costs, was $506.87. The Survey also showed that the average weekly household income for the same period was $621.52.
The ABS Survey figures confirm the obvious and well known economic proposition that the proportion of income spent of basic necessities, such as food and housing, falls as income increases
for example, they show that the proportion of household income spent on the food groups was 40.6% for the lowest income group, but 9.4% for the highest group.

The MGICA/Real Estate Institute of Australia Home Loan Affordability Survey, (September edition) shows that, for the June quarter 1989, average repayments on new home loans was 35.8% of medium family income, up from 33.6% for the March quarter 1989.

The Institute's Median Established Home Price index shows that the average price across the 6 state capitals fell from $142.300 in June 1989 to $141,500 in July. The Institute has confirmed this price fall occurred after the period covered by the Affordability Survey.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to read that sentence in his answer to my question where I understood him to say--
—Order! Senator MacGibbon cannot just stand up and make a speech.
—I believe it was a grossly misleading statement to the Senate.
—There are certain procedures of the Senate in Standing Orders that you can seek to use.
—My apologies, Mr President. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister at the table to read that sentence in his answer to my question where I understood him to say that the aircraft was cleared on a standard instrument departure from runway 16 to Wollongong and Shelley because if that is so he has received the wrong advice from his Department. There were only four departures to the south from runway 16, two via Wollongong and two via Shelleys. Those two places are about 50 miles apart in roughly the same latitude and one does not fly to Wollongong and then to Shelley.
—I ask that the Minister table the documents from which he has given all the answers on the air pilots dispute.
—That is a matter for the Minister.
—Everything from the documents is in Hansard.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Puplick proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to recognise that the failure to resolve the pilots' dispute arises fundamentally from the unwillingness of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to govern on behalf of all Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the current airline pilots dispute is one of the most serious disputes to affect this country in a long time. Not only is it serious in terms of the national economy, but also it has its most serious impact in the devastating effect which it brings to the lives and to the economic welfare of thousands of small Australian businesses and to individual Australians throughout the country. It has a devastating impact upon the operators of small businesses in the tourist industry, people who happen to be bus drivers, people who are taxi drivers, people who are restaurateurs, people who are shop owners, and they are demanding to know why the Prime Minister of this country will not take the steps available to him to solve this dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Senate chamber this afternoon that that is because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is simply no longer interested in governing on behalf of all Australians and paying attention to the welfare of all Australians-he has, in fact, an entirely different agenda; an agenda which is based upon looking after his mates of a variety of descriptions-and his complete failure to govern, as I said, on behalf of all Australians. The capacity of the Prime Minister to bring an end to this dispute is without doubt. The Opposition has put forward on a number of occasions a series of suggestions about how this should be achieved. On 18 September the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, released a statement outlining a nine-point plan in which he clearly outlined the steps that could be taken in this regard. In part, that statement read:
We have never supported their stand-and-deliver demand-
that is, the airline pilots-
for a 30 per cent rise not based on productivity improvement.

That quite clearly gives the lie to the accusations made today by Senator Button and others in that regard. On 29 September Mr Peacock wrote to the Prime Minister and indicated to him the capacity that he, the Prime Minister, had to bring about a resolution of this dispute. In his letter Mr Peacock said:
. . . enormous damage has been done to the tourist industry and to the thousands of individuals and firms involved in that industry.
The Opposition has never advocated surrender to the AFAP's wage demands as a means of resolving the dispute.

He put it to the Prime Minister quite clearly that the Prime Minister's capacity as, in effect, the owner of Australian Airlines to direct that airline to enter into negotiations with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to test its bona fides was a device available to the Prime Minister to bring a resolution to this dispute which the Prime Minister manifestly refuses to take up. What the Government has done throughout this dispute is to introduce nothing more than a series of abusive comments about the Air Pilots Federation, about individuals, about the Opposition, to tie them up in a whole series of untruths. Let me give the Senate one simple example of that: the claim made by the Prime Minister that airline pilots work only an eight-hour week or 30 hours a month and that because new contracts are being offered which provide for 55 hours a month to be worked, they represent some enormous productivity gain in terms of an extra 25 hours work per month. The truth is, of course, that the pilots, by and large, fly up to 75 hours a month and that the figure which has been derived-eight hours a week, 30 hours a month-is arrived at by the disingenuous method of taking all pilots who are flying, plus all of the management pilots, plus all of the administrative people, plus all of the people in training, plus all of the people on leave, and all of the people on standby who qualify as pilots, dividing that figure into the total hours flown and making some comparative judgment as far as that is concerned.

I say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there has been a failure to settle this pilots dispute because the Prime Minister is interested only in making a series of sectional deals and sectional arrangements.
