He is far more interested in making sure that he protects the precious accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the arrangement upon which the personal future and the power base of his mates in the union movement depend, and on doing deals with his mates in the airline industry who want help from this Government at public expense to restructure their operations prior to the deregulation of the airline industry. As Mr John Halfpenny said in the Canberra Times, the current debate over air travel, for example, was less about deregulation and more about `Abelising' the Australian airline industry. The first claims are already in from Ansett Airlines of Australia for compensation of $701,035. That is the first claim on the public purse which has already been put in by Ansett. The Federal Airports Corporation is being told to waive charges. It reads about those details in the newspapers because it has not been properly directed and properly told by the Government what it is supposed to do.

We have seen the behaviour of Sir Peter Abeles in this dispute. When Australian Airlines was prepared to accept a chartering rate for Royal Australian Air Force Boeing 707 jets of $4,000 per hour, Ansett objected and, under pressure, the Air Force ended up accepting a rate of only $1,500 an hour-another one of the deals done with mates along the way. It is the protection of its union mates and the accord and the protection of Sir Peter Abeles and the other mates, which we will come to, which is driving the policy initiative of this Government.

What is that accord all about-this sort of Magna Carta of industrial mediocrity? That accord is akin to the Munich Pact of economic policy. It was negotiated between the ACTU, which at that stage undoubtedly was telling the Prime Minister that it had no further territorial demands to make on the Australian economy, and the Prime Minister, playing the role of Neville Chamberlain-weak, vacillating, compromising, `peace in our time'. It was a piece of paper with a signature on it. Like the Czechs back at the time of the Munich Pact, the only people not invited around the table were the taxpayers, the wage earners, the people of Australia whose interests were being sacrificed in this sleazy deal. We have now seen the claims by and the consequential payout to Sir Peter Abeles.

But where are the payments to the people who are really hurting? Where are the payments to the tourist operators, to the people being stood down, to the people being sent to the wall? Where are the payments to the restaurateurs who are 25 per cent down in their business? The reason they are not being paid is that they are not powerful enough. After all, we have Mr Keating telling everybody that the tourism industry is overstating its case about how difficult things are. How did Mr Keating know all of this, particularly things about accommodation in hotels. An article in the Daily Telegraph on 22 September states:
He-
that is, Mr Keating-
also said a Sydney hotel he stayed in last week had an 83 per cent occupancy rate.

Well, unless he is back into his travelling allowance rackets, there must be a pretty good explanation of why a person whose electorate is in Sydney and whose home is supposed to be in Elizabeth Bay has to stay in Sydney hotels in order to make these observations. What this country is getting progressively more fed up with is the selective deals that this Government does with its mates around the place. Max Walsh reminded us in the Sydney Morning Herald of a couple of days ago about the deal that has now been done with the banks. He said in part:
There are echoes of the meeting Mr Keating had with media barons Mr Rupert Murdoch and Mr Kerry Packer in 1986 before the announcement of the Government's changed media laws.
These changes were to prove very valuable to Mr Murdoch and Mr Packer, providing them with windfall profits of $1 billion for their television interests.

We have people around the place who cannot get funding for welfare, who cannot get funding for needed social security payments. But when Mr Alan Bond was a mate the Prime Minister could find $30m for the defence of the America's Cup so that he and his mates could get out there, slosh themselves around in champagne and denounce as bums anybody who would not take a public holiday in support of that particular mate.

I turn to the Kodak deal which is under way at the moment. We see from the article of Paul Lyneham the other day that Senator Button has misgivings about this Kodak deal. In the context of this pilots dispute, Senator Button has been in here every day, like that other famous Pilate, Pontius, washing his hands of all of the Government's economic decisions-of the Kodak decision, of all the payments that are being made in that regard.

Next there is the deal that is being done with the banks, not on behalf of the people who are more disadvantaged; they are more likely to get their housing loans from the building societies whose interests rates have already gone up as part of this particular deal. At the end of the article by Max Walsh which I referred to earlier, he says:
In economic terms, the deal stinks.

In political terms it is also on the nose. After all, the Government is giving an additional $200m to banks at the very same time that we read that the Commonwealth Bank's profits have risen from $273m to $475m a year. That shows how much the banks are in need of another $200m. We have seen the whole of the deals being done with the ACTU-the jobs for the boys; the fact that Mr Kelty supplements his income by between 30 and 50 per cent because of all of the boards and statutory authorities that this Government puts him on and pays him to be on. We have seen the capacity of the ACTU to dictate tax policy in this country; to take the Prime Minister into a hotel room and beat him up to make sure that option C does not get up as part of the tax package. The reason that we do not have the sanctions capacity in industrial relations legislation to deal with the pilots dispute is that the ACTU vetoed it a couple of years ago when Mr Willis was bold enough to suggest that there was some particular reason for it.

The whole business of sectionalism which runs through the Government is seen even in something that Senator Collins is immediately interested in-Coronation Hill. It finds a small group in the community-on this occasion the Aboriginal people-and makes it the catspaw, the tool, in order to try to set at nought the greater national interest which is involved in making a proper and rational decision. In typical fashion, this Government is prepared to play the sectional issues and it will play the Aboriginal people as the last card in the pack. It is prepared to fight to the last drop of Aboriginal blood over the question of Coronation Hill. All of the Government's mates are looked after. Senator Evans is off in New York at the moment campaigning to be President of the General Assembly. He ought to remember that that was the job given to a previous Labor Foreign Minister, Dr Evatt, before he went completely insane. Nevertheless the Australian Labor Party is prepared to look after its mates. It sent Burke to Ireland, Whitlam to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Morrison to Indonesia, Jenkins to Spain, Grimes to the Netherlands, Johnson to New Zealand, McClelland to Great Britain, Chris Hurford to New York-and there is even hope for Senator Collins if he plays his cards right.

We see the continuing manifest failure of this Government to act on the issues that are really important. Simply by redefining, by a statistical exercise, the Government says that there is no child poverty left in this country. If any of the Ministers like to get out of their dinner suits and cigar smoking, brandy swilling clubs and come round the streets of Sydney they can be shown what child poverty is really all about. We were told about the number of planes that would be flying. There is nowhere near the number of planes, nowhere near the seat capacity that was promised. The Prime Minister told us in August of this year:
I assert that before the end of the financial year interest rates will move down.
What are they doing? They are moving up. The large bulk of people in this country are having to pay.

One of the enduring features of the Hawke Labor Government will be that it will in fact rewrite the Australian political lexicon. It will turn the term `mate' from a term of honour to one redolent with sleaze. As Paul Kelly said in his article in March of last year:

The rorts perpetrated by the Labor Party's ``mates system are now an open joke matched only by the utter contempt displayed by the Hawke Government and its instrumentalities as it merrily despatches life rafts from the sinking ship.
What do we see in today's paper? We see in today's paper the record of achievement of the Hawke socialist Government under the heading: `Australia in the 80s: unequal, uncaring'. It states:
The richest 20 per cent of the population is coming closer to earning half of Australia's wealth, and most of its increased income is at the expense of the middle 20 per cent.
An inequitable distribution of wealth compared with West Germany and the US . . . Canada, New Zealand and even Great Britain

That is the legacy of the Hawke socialist Government; the government of the mates, by the mates, for the mates; a government which is in the business of redistribution from the poor and needy to the fat and greedy, and that in fact is the hallmark of this Government.

It would not surprise me that, if Sir Peter Abeles and Mr Hawke were blown up in the same aeroplane, when they got up to the pearly gates and were asked to fill in the form as to their occupation prior to entry, Mr Hawke would simply write on his form `Prime Minister' and Sir Peter Abeles would write on his form `ventriloquist'. It is about time that this Government clearly understood what it is doing and what it is failing to do. It is, above all, failing to take into account the broad national interest in the decisions which it is capable of making. It is clearly there in the business of simply governing for its sectional mates, whether they happen to be in the ACTU and its power structures or in particular lobby groups-the conservation movement, the land rights movement or whatever, whether it happens to be in the board rooms and the clubs which this Prime Minister and his cronies frequent around the place; whether it happens to be in looking after Sir Peter Abeles or Mr Harris or appointing their friends to statutory corporations; or whether it happens to be in getting a handle on the Reserve Bank by making sure that the independence of the Reserve Bank, something which has been cherished as part of the financial arrangements of this country, is progressively compromised.

This Government is simply not in the business of governing Australia on behalf of all Australians. It has had the capacity in the course of this pilots dispute to do just that, to say, `Very well; we will take the broad national interest into account. We will direct Australian Airlines to enter into negotiations and to test the bona fides of the pilots in their claims that they would go back to work, improve productivity and get the aeroplanes flying again'. It has had the capacity not simply to provide assistance to Sir Peter Abeles and its mates in the airline business but to provide support and assistance for small businesses, for the people who do not have resort to the sums of money, the capacity to borrow and the sorts of credit arrangements which the large operators have. But no, it is simply not interested in those people. It is not interested in the general welfare of the people of Australia because it has become so used to governing simply in the interests of its mates, its friends, its supporters, its sectional interests, that it has entirely forgotten its primary obligation, which is to govern in the interests of all Australians. I say in conclusion that the real hallmark of all of this is that Robert Hawke is simply too small a man to occupy the office of Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Noise has never been a substitute for substance. I am afraid I cannot rise to the same dizzy heights as Senator Puplick has today. I was getting very worried about him at one stage. I thought he was going to suffer from a simultaneous dislocation of both hips. This is the sixth time that the Opposition has run this particular rabbit around the track, and it is getting a bit wearing. I have sat here with a pad in front of me and a pen ready to make notes, as I do, to rebut argument, and I have been sitting in front of a blank page. From the start, apart from 38 cliches and a lot of very bad jokes, there was nothing else. Senator Puplick must obviously be planning for his retirement. It must be terrible being last on the Senate ticket. He is obviously going to carve out his new career writing scripts for television soap operas or something. That was a dreadful contribution to this debate. I must give a bit of gratuitous advice to the Opposition. When I was Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory we had a rule of thumb--
—Very successfully, too!

—I will match my success against that of Senator Knowles's colleague Senator Tambling any time. Senator Tambling has made history in the Northern Territory. He is the only Country-Liberal Party conservative senator ever to have stood for office who could not make a quota. He could not make a quota because the Labor senator in the Northern Territory got 1.5 quotas out of two. Interestingly enough in terms of matching political records, it was the only place in Australia where Labor increased its Senate vote. Senator Knowles might like to look at the facts instead of the rhetoric.

SPEECH.PARA: We used to have a rule of thumb on matters of public importance: if we did not think we could manage to get half a paragraph on page 35 we did not run them. It is about time the Opposition woke up to that. This is the sixth time it has run this particular rabbit around the track, and it is starting to get a bit moth-eaten. If members of the Opposition do not have anything new to say in this debate, they should sit down and say nothing, instead of simply coming in here day after day and offering aid and comfort to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, and Senator MacGibbon--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order--
—Yes. It is getting a bit much, I must say.
—Some interjections, I suppose, are allowable, but when there is a whole cacophony on the other side it might be appropriate to call honourable senators to order.
—I am sorry, I do not understand the point of order you raised, Senator Bolkus.
—There are too many interjections from the other side. I am sure that you could not hear my point of order rather than not understand it. Would you mind calling honourable senators opposite to order?
—There is no point of order, but I ask honourable senators on my left to take some notice of the normal standards of procedure for debate.

—The difficulty for the Opposition in this whole debate, in terms of the continual aid and comfort it is giving to the Air Pilots Federation, is addressing the terms of this matter of public importance directly. The problem for the Opposition and the Air Pilots Federation is that this Government is governing for all Australians. That is precisely why it is handling this dispute the way it is. It is not coming in here day after day and protecting the selfish interests of a tiny group of 1,600 Australians, which is precisely what the Opposition is doing. Of course, one of the chief champions of the Air Pilots Federation is Senator MacGibbon. Yesterday Senator MacGibbon engaged in a piece of disgraceful scaremongering. Senator Button's criticisms of that question were absolutely valid. I spend half my life flying. Last year I flew 257,000 kilometres on commercial jets alone. On top of that--
—Haven't you got anything better to do than add them up?

—I do it in the course of doing my job, Senator Vanstone. It is not easy, I can tell you, for a middle-aged person with a young family to represent a place as far-flung as Darwin. I have decided, after being a senator for 2 1/2 years, that it is a job for either very young single people or very old people whose kids have grown up. But I do it, and I do it with total commitment, Senator.
—Senator Collins, can I seduce you into the temptation to address your remarks through the Chair?

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. Perhaps I should not be provoked. The fact is that I spend many hours in the air. I also fly in light aircraft a great deal when I am in the Northern Territory. I have been involved in probably as many incidents, if one likes to call them that-and I do not enjoy any of them-as any person I know, including pilots. Twice I have been on board an aircraft that has had an undercarriage failure. Twice I have been on board a twin-engine aircraft that had engine failures on take-off. I have been on board an aircraft that had an engine catch fire on take-off from Darwin Airport. I have been on board an aircraft whose controls jammed on the final approaches to an airport at Ramingining. I have been on board a DC3 whose oil pumps and feathering pumps failed simultaneously, forcing the aircraft into a very unusual event. I have, in fact, been involved in all kinds of incidents.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the state of the chamber, so that Government members can come in and listen to this travelogue. (Quorum formed)

—Mr Acting Deputy President, before I was so rudely interrupted I was saying that I have in fact personally been involved in many incidents such as the one that Senator MacGibbon described yesterday. It is totally legitimate to raise questions of air safety in this Parliament. It is totally legitimate in the course of this current airline pilots dispute to raise the pressures that are being placed on airlines and air traffic control and the potential for loss of life. It is tragic to see what is being inflicted on this country at the moment by the airline pilots. If one wants to talk about blood on one's hands, if one wants to talk about accidents, one could probably ascribe at least some of the deaths on our roads-in fact, one in particular, I regret to say-to the airline pilots dispute. One could chase that particular rabbit a long way by talking about individual car accidents involving people who normally would have travelled by air. But it is not excusable, it is not reasonable, for any honourable senator to come in here, ignore the facts of an incident and say that there was a chance of an imminent mid-air collision between two jet aircraft over schools in the main city of Sydney when the facts demonstrate that that incident did not even come close to the description that was given to it by Senator MacGibbon. But we should not be surprised at that kind of behaviour by Senator MacGibbon.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon came into this House last week and waved a contract around. He said, `Here is proof positive that what the Federation has been saying has been absolutely right all along. The airlines are offering a 40 per cent boost to the conditions that are being offered to airline pilots'. In other words, this is disgraceful. He said that they would be getting a `15 per cent better deal than they are getting now'. The trouble is that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots has not only led every one of its members up a blind alley with nowhere to go; it has successfully led the Opposition up the same blind alley because every time the Opposition sticks its neck out on behalf of the Federation, the Federation pulls the rug out from under it.

Senator MacGibbon tabled this contract-which he could not have read-in the Senate, when I invited him to do so, as proof that it offered a 40 per cent boost in current conditions. The reality is that it does nothing of the sort. I do not know which member of the Federation gave Senator MacGibbon this contract. I was interested to see the handwritten margin note--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my handwriting.

—It is the honourable senator's handwriting, is it? Does he fly a 727? Whichever member of the Federation handed it to him said, `There you are, mate. You can go into the Senate and tell them that this offers us a 40 per cent better deal'. Both the Opposition and the Federation of Air Pilots ran that argument all last week. The truth is that this contract requires an increase from an average number of flying hours of 31 1/2--
—No, 75 hours.

—This is an average. This would increase to 55 hours a month for a 3 per cent increase in salary, with a further increase of 3 per cent. So it is a 6 per cent pay rise on 1 April 1990. If honourable senators wanted some further demonstration of the fact that this contract does not accord with the lies that the Federation of Air Pilots has been telling about it, picked up without question and run by the Opposition, I refer them to the national news on Monday morning. The Federation has been running for a fortnight, with its mates in the Opposition quite happy to come in here mindlessly believing whatever they are told by the Federation, saying, `40 per cent increase'. On Monday morning Brian `the Sphinx' McCarthy said on the national news that these contracts were a disgrace and pilots should not sign them because they `took pilots back to the conditions that existed 30 years ago'. That is simply symptomatic of the schizophrenic, amateurish, juvenile way in which the Pilots Federation leadership has been handling this dispute. As I said before, every time the Opposition sticks its neck out on behalf of the Federation, the Federation pulls the rug out from under it. I do not know whether honourable senators heard the Federation's comments on this same contract on Monday morning, but they should refer to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Federation was correct in one respect. What I suspect it was referring to was the changed conditions of service that are provided for in this contract. I will canvass some of the history of the industrial negotiations of this Federation over the last 30 years. What it is clearly referring to is the removal of the seniority and bidding system for routes, which is not in this contract. In fact, I note further-and I did make a general reference last week to the interesting changes in conditions after Senator MacGibbon so helpfully tabled this document in support of his argument; in fact, it destroyed his argument-the stand down time provisions allowed in this contract. The reason they are interesting is that the Federation, in the circular that was issued by it in October last year to its members, extolling the fact, in a three-page detailed breakdown of their award, that they were the best paid and best looked after group of pilots in the world, mentioned specifically the stand-down provisions provided in the United States of America. It said to its members, quite accurately, `We have a bidding system similar to that in North America. That is where it came from, but we have a better bidding system than they have because they have stand-down provisions so that when the planes are not flying for any reason, they do not get paid. We don't have that provision here; we are the best looked after and best paid pilots in the world'.

The reason that I mention that is to nail down the huge hole in the Opposition's arguments. It has an unbelievably simple-minded, fantasyland approach to industrial relations which it has been running in the House of Representatives today as well as in here. I listened to the debate in the House of Representatives. Some Opposition nonentity there-I do not know who it was-was debating the resolution of the pilots dispute-

TALK.START.PARA: —It was probably Peacock.

—It was probably Andrew Peacock. He extracted bits and pieces from the nine-point plan of the Opposition. This is what an Opposition member said in the House of Representatives today: `If the Parliament supports this resolution the Parliament can resolve the airline pilots dispute, and this is how it is going to be done'. The honourable member said, in effect, `Let's negotiate now and we'll have the planes back in the air in a few days'. He went on to say, `If the pilots and the airlines simply sit down and sign a contract, this dispute will be over'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the facts. The current dispute was not caused by this Government and it was not caused by the central wage fixing system. It was caused by the Air Pilots Federation, under the same kind of collective bargaining arrangements that the Opposition would like to see introduced, going to its employers in the same way that it has done for 30 years, pointing a gun at the head of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines and saying, `Stand and deliver 30 per cent on top of the best wages and working conditions and lowest productivity in the world'. For one of the few times in the 30 years since 1959, the airlines stood up to the Federation. Why did they stand up to it? I think Senator Puplick mentioned one particularly crucial aspect of this debate that is correct: this has a lot to do with deregulation. There is no question about it. The reason that the Air Pilots Federation has tried this on to the extent that it has is that this is the last big pay grab by the Federation before deregulation. It was this Government that had the courage to terminate the two airlines agreement, despite the fact that the Opposition talked about doing it for years and did nothing about it, and there will be a whole new ball game in Australian aviation when in 12 months time that deregulation regime starts.

The Air Pilots Federation has a modus operandi, which has done very well for it since 1959, of using the two-airline agreement to its great advantage. It points a gun at Ansett and it immediately caves in. TAA, or Australian Airlines as it is now, then has to pick it up. What it did in the past was quite simple: it paid the extortionate demands of the airline pilots and immediately passed those costs on to ordinary Australians by increasing air fares. That is exactly how it operated. That is still the crux of this dispute.

In terms of the Federation's hypocrisy and how we can deal with the Federation and test its bona fides, it has been running full-page advertisements saying, `We will negotiate on anything-wages and conditions of service'. Within 24 hours of those advertisements appearing McCarthy has been back on the airwaves saying, `twenty-nine per cent and not a cent less'. He has not varied that in eight weeks. In the past such techniques have worked. The only difference between this dispute and all those that have occurred since 1959 is that for the first time the Federation has had the airlines stand up to it and say no. The cause of the dispute is collective bargaining. How do we fix a dispute simply by sitting down with an employer and signing a contract? That is what the Opposition has said will fix this dispute. There is the contract. The employers are offering it to the pilots, but the pilots refuse to sign it.

Where do the Opposition and the Federation go from here? That is the real crux of this dispute. The fact is that the wages policy implemented by the Government has brought enormous productivity gains to this country. It has in fact created-it is not rhetoric; it is cold, hard fact-1 1/2 million jobs in the life of this Government. That is not something that can be simply dismissed and put aside as of no account. There have been great benefits to this community. But again I stress that the central wage fixing system, in terms of the beginnings of this dispute and the perpetuation of it, has nothing to do with what is going on currently. What is going on currently is that a bunch of blackmailers are putting the same gun to the head of their employers as they have done since 1959 and for the first time the employers are refusing to give in because, as one of them said only recently, `The trouble with continually giving in to blackmail is that the blackmailers keep coming back and doing it again'. That is a fact.

Nothing that the Opposition has put forward in this debate today, or on the previous five occasions that it has brought such a matter in here, with its simple-minded nonsense, will go anywhere to solving this dispute. I regret to say that the only way the dispute will be solved is if the Federation pilots-after the Commission brings down its findings this week on whether this contract fits in the wage fixing system, and on my examination of it I believe it will, and perhaps it will use it as the basis for the award-sit down with their employers, as the Opposition wants them to do, and sign the contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —To begin with I take up the words with which Senator Collins has just closed his extraordinary speech. Senator Collins concluded by holding out yet another illusion in the same vein as that which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been tapping so vigorously ever since this dispute began. According to Senator Collins, the solution to this dispute is to be found in the determination to be brought down, he suggests or hopes, by Mr Justice Maddern of the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC), the body that used to be called the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Recently it was renamed the IRC. That is a very appropriate set of initials because it also stands for the industrial relations club to which Mr Justice Maddern belongs. I almost choke on the word `justice' because the gentleman in question is not a judge, although he may have been given that status. Clearly he is not a judge because, in fact, this Government sacked another man in a similar jurisdiction-Mr Justice Staples-even though he enjoyed the same title. Nevertheless, according to Senator Collins, Mr Justice Maddern is about to bring down a determination which will probably turn these contracts into an award and, on that basis, hey presto, this whole terrible, tragic dispute will be solved!-if only in the light of that the pilots can be brought to see the error of their ways and can be brought to bend the knee to the Prime Minister who, as our matter of public importance says, quite rightly, has ceased to govern on behalf of all Australians. If time permits I will come back to that fantasy with which Senator Collins concluded his remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Before turning to my own prepared comments I refer to a series of misleading suggestions put forward by Senator Collins during his remarks. For example, Senator Collins said that it was getting a bit wearing that the Opposition had raised matters of public importance in this place, I think on six separate occasions. I suggest to Senator Collins, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and to his colleagues on the Government side of the chamber, that he tell the tourism industry, all the other industries and the people dependent upon those industries in this country that it is getting a bit wearing for Government members to have to be told on no fewer than six occasions what a shambles this Government and this Prime Minister are reducing this country to through the Prime Minister's stubborn insistence upon the non-negotiability of his condition that on no account are the airlines to sit down and negotiate in any way with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. As I said, it may be getting a bit wearing for Government senators to have this matter debated but I can assure them that out there, where the pain is being felt, where the bankruptcies are occurring and the bank managers are making their telephone calls to the poor little motel owners, the taxicab drivers, the hire car owners and so on, it is certainly getting a bit wearing too. But the thing that is wearing is the financial pain involved. It is not wearing that at least somebody in this place is taking up their cause for them in the face of the total calculated callousness with which our Prime Minister, by contrast, is approaching the matter.

For the rest, what else did Senator Collins say, apart from a couple of lacings of personal abuse of the general kind which we are accustomed to from Government members when they are hard pressed? They always stop playing the ball and start playing the man and Senator Collins did that in the cases of both Senator Puplick and Senator Tambling. I do not propose to dignify those elements of his remarks by any response to them. I merely note the characteristic performance on the part of Government spokesmen in that regard. The one matter which I want to take up and deal with at some length is Senator Collins's atrocious suggestion that `day after day'-I think I am quoting him accurately-`we have the Opposition coming in here and offering aid and comfort to the Air Pilots Federation'. That McCarthyist smear, if I may use a bad pun, given the name of the chief executive of the Air Pilots Federation, from Senator Collins is totally unworthy of any senator in this place, not even an Australian Labor Party senator. The Opposition has never supported the Air Pilots Federation. The Opposition has always said, on the contrary, that we do not support the pilots' claim per se. (Quorum formed) I digress for one moment to comment on the total hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats who this morning wasted two hours of the Senate's time having a debate about the total inappropriateness of calling quorums, thereby incidentally wasting speakers' time, yet this afternoon they have done just that. But I will not spend any more time talking about this rabble on my left.

The Opposition has always said that we deplored the effect of the dispute on the travelling public, and we have always said that we deplored even more the effect on the Australian tourism industry and all those dependent upon it. It is an industry which appears to be the last of the Government's concerns. In addition we have always continued to express our total frustration at the fact that everything this Prime Minister has done from the outset of this dispute has had the effect of inflaming the dispute on the one hand and prolonging the dispute on the other. In the process, the Prime Minister has been totally ignoring the interests of the travelling public and totally ignoring, it would seem, the terrible effects of the dispute on the tourism industry.

Mr Hawke has again and again refused to permit the airlines to negotiate in any way with the Pilots Federation. The Opposition has said, and of course it is obvious, that there must be negotiations between the airlines and the pilots. On that we are at one with the Prime Minister and the airlines. But when did we arrive at a situation in this country whereby individual workers-in this case the pilots-were not allowed, by prime ministerial fiat, to be represented by a union of their choice? Whatever else might be said about the Pilots Federation-and many things could be said about it-there does not seem to be the slightest doubt that the Federation is strongly supported by its members. I must say that is unusual among trade unions in this country.

Because of the Prime Minister's absolutely manic determination-and I am unable for one moment to imagine what can be the basis for this, except for one suggestion which has been made, which I may return to-to exclude the Air Pilots Federation from any such negotiations, there are no negotiations. We cannot get any details, but there seem to have been no more than 10, and possibly fewer than half a dozen of the 1,647 pilots who resigned on 23 August-fewer than 10 and possibly fewer than half a dozen-who have gone back. There does not seem to be the slightest indication that the others are going to do so. So what are we going to do? What is the Government's response when we say, `What are you going to do about the present situation'?

Senator Collins, towards the end of his remarks, asked: Where does the Opposition go from here? I would ask: Where does the Government go from here? After all, as was revealed during the Senate Estimates Committee hearings last night, with the dispute now moving into its eighth week, we have no sign of any early end to it. Every few days we get fed a little more misleading pap. Three weeks ago the Prime Minister told us that by the end of September the airlines expected to be carrying 50 per cent of their normal passenger load. What do we find? We find, on the basis of information tabled during the Estimates Committee hearings last night, and referred to in Question Time today, that 34,800 passengers per day were carried during the June quarter by the commercial airlines; that is, by Ansett Airlines of Australia, Australian Airlines, East-West Airlines Ltd and Ansett regional airlines.

On 2 October, which is the best day for these figures from the Government's point of view, there were 18,545 seats available-not passengers carried, but seats available. I will come back to that point. Of those 18,545 seats, only 5,674 were being offered by the commercial airlines. There were 5,217 seats available on leased aircraft brought in from overseas. There were 2,154 being carried by the Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy, 1,300 by foreign carriers such as Thai Airways, British Airways, United Airlines and so on; 3,000 by Qantas; and 1,200 by various commuter airlines. So on 2 October, Monday of this week, we had the commercial airlines making available seats amounting to just over 16 per cent of the number of passengers carried during the June quarter on an average basis. I repeat that the airlines were making those seats available. It is a notorious fact that because of the shambles that the airlines booking system has been reduced to by the pressure of people upon them-I am not blaming the airlines for that; it is simply a fact of the situation-every plane leaving has vacant seats. In fact, the commercial airlines are carrying probably less than 15 per cent of what was previously their normal capacity.

We are now 7 1/2 weeks into the dispute. Fifteen per cent of the normal carrying capacity is being provided. Unless some magic wand is to be produced from some Prime Ministerial cupboard-and there is not the slightest sign of it-that seems to be about where we will be until Christmas. There might be a few more pilots starved into submission, but there does not seem to be the slightest sign of it. I believe from the general feeling that one gets from talking around the place that the pilots are absolutely fed up with the way this Government, and the Prime Minister in person, have treated them. I regret to say it, but I suspect that this country will finish up with airlines which are not being flown by these pilots at all. I suspect that they will never go back.

Is that what the Government wants? Is that statesmanship? Is that the action of a Prime Minister or is it the action of a vindictive little man? Do we have as the Prime Minister of this country a vindictive little man? That is the clear impression that any objective observer of the situation must get. At the beginning of this week, after seven weeks of the dispute, we had the commercial airlines, the four main carriers, carrying 15 per cent of their normal daily passenger load. The tourism industry meanwhile is going down in flames. We had a balance of payments deficit of $2.6 billion last month, and the Prime Minister has had nothing to say on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little hesitant to rise amongst these revolutionary voices. We have on the other side Senator Danton Stone and Senator Robespierre Puplick. Unfortunately, they want to tear up the rules by which the society runs. There is not any other way of looking at it. Democracy is a fragile fabric, but it is a serious situation when we have adopted a system such as the conciliation and arbitration system which operates under the Industrial Relations Act-one may or may not dislike it but that is what the community has opted for-and, when some strain occurs, the Opposition says, `Well, let's just ignore it'. Are we next going to ignore the rulings of the Federal Court and the High Court? Why obey anything? Why should we as members of this community obey the laws at all? That is what is being advocated here.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said, `Look, we understand that there is a process whereby people have their wages fixed, but because we have a bit of difficulty here let's ignore that'. The same sort of argument was used about the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal when that situation became a bit uncomfortable. What do we do in such situations? We just toss the umpire aside. We just throw out the system and, because there is a group of people who have a little industrial muscle, we say, `Let's give way; that's the answer. Let those people sit down and bludgeon whoever they will into submission and that will be that'.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am a great admirer and supporter of the union movement. I am a person who does not believe that sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act ought to operate and I am a believer that negotiations should take place, but they should take place within a system. And in taking that approach I am being a traditionalist. I make no apology for that. The powers of the Parliament, as the founding fathers set them out, read in section 51 in the following way:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to-
(xxxv.) Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State:
That is the way that this Australian community has opted to go since 1904 when the first Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was established.

Indeed, not only has the Commonwealth gone down that line; the States have as well. It is interesting to note that the Opposition says, `Let us forget about all this because the pilots do not want to use the system any more; we as an Opposition will support them in that. We say yes, they do not have to use the system any more. They can go and negotiate directly. They can tear up what has gone before; they can do what they want'. The interesting thing is this: the Pilots Federation did not have to register itself under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as it then was. The Australian Industrial Relations Act which operates now says:
Any of the following associations may apply-
they do not have to apply-
for registration as an organisation.

And then it goes through and defines them. The Pilots Federation applied for registration under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, now replaced by the Industrial Relations Act, and stayed within that system until it did not suit the pilots. Now the Opposition says, `Because you happen to be a union with considerable muscle you can go outside the system. You can go outside the guidelines and since you cause a lot of trouble we should give way to you'. That is really what is being said by the other side. Senator Stone says that he does not say that, and if that is what he--

TALK.START.PARA: —We have said nothing of the kind, Senator. What I have said is that the pilots are entitled to be represented by their Federation if that is their freely expressed wish.

—I have got no difficulty-in spite of what others might say-with the proposition that the Federation should represent the pilots, if that is what the pilots want, before the Commission-if it does in fact represent them. The difficulty is that the Opposition says, `Look, let the Federation represent the pilots'. But the difficulty is that it does not, and this is the point I am making, put itself within the framework whereby it can do that. Leave aside the Prime Minister; leave aside the politics; leave aside the politicians. Let us look at what was stated by the properly constituted body, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The Full Bench consisted of Mr Justice Maddern, President, Deputy President Hancock and Commissioner Paine. These are the umpires; these are the people that the community has appointed as the proper tribunal to decide these issues. This is what they said in Melbourne on 29 September 1989. The reference is 736/89, the print number is H9770, for whoever wants to read it. The Full Bench of the Industrial Relations Commission says this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federation has been given the opportunity to justify its claim before this Commission but has refused to do so. It is clear to us that the Federation has not changed its attitude-
this is last week-
which involves a refusal to proceed in accordance with the Act . . .

The Act of Parliament which this very Parliament has passed. It refuses. What are we to say? Are we to say, `Oh well, even though the Federal Parliament of Australia has decided something, because it involves the pilots, let's forget about the will of the people expressed through Parliament'. That is the argument on the other side. On the other hand, the Commission says:
It is clear to us that the Federation has not changed its attitude which involves a refusal to proceed in accordance with the Act, its own rules-
I will come back to that-
and the processes of this Commission; nor has it altered its attitude to the principles established in National Wage Case decisions.
I imagine Senator Stone is willing to accept what the umpire, this body that the Australian community has established as the proper body--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Commission? That bunch of clowns? You have to be joking!

—Now, Senator Stone, they are not a bunch of clowns. These are men with vast experience in law, economics and industrial relations. We are fully aware, says the Commission, of the damage which the dispute is causing to the economy and significant sections of the country. But, apparently, the pilots do not see that. The Opposition says, `Let us give way to this; let us concede this and go outside the system'. It is interesting to look at the pilots' own rules. I will explain what they are. These are the rules that the Federation itself established before it was registered. It is an agreement that was registered. It sets out the contract by which members of the Federation came together to form a union. These are the rules written by the Federation and which it put forward to have registered and which it had to justify to have registered. Rule 19 is headed `Industrial Agreements' and states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) An industrial agreement shall not be entered into unless its contents have been agreed to by a majority of the Executive Committee.
That is a standard rule and a good one. The second one reads:

(b) Industrial agreements or other instruments made on behalf of the Federation shall only be entered into in accordance with the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and copies of the same shall be furnished according to law to the Industrial Registrar.

These are the rules of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots-written not by compulsion but by agreement-which everybody who is a pilot is asked to accede to and which bind the pilots as in a contract. Yet the Federation, with, as I understand it, the support of the Opposition, simply says, `Look, let's ignore our own agreement. Let us ignore the very basis upon which we ought to proceed'. It is just a very revolutionary approach that the Opposition takes. What the Opposition says is that members of an organisation who ignore the Commission, who ignore their own rules, will somehow or other become people of sweetness and light as soon as they sit down to negotiate with their employers directly.

What does all the evidence indicate? What is the reality? The reality is that, unless this matter is processed through the Commission, we will get nowhere. It is just pointless to say that the thing can be solved without some compulsion being put on a group which says it wants 30 per cent and sticks by that. What is to be done? The simple answer the Opposition gives is, `All sorts of crises are being caused by this'. Of course crises are being caused by it. Of course people are suffering. The Commission understands that and, of course, the Government understands that. The pilots understand it, but what they are saying is, `Well, look, in pursuit of our industrial objective, a rise of 30 per cent in wages outside the guidelines-we will not comply with the sorts of guidelines with which everybody else complies-we will ignore the union movement, the Government, the Industrial Relations Commission and the pleas from the rest of the community and we will press on until our will is done'. That is the sort of opponent with which we are faced. Nevertheless it is suggested by the Opposition that if the pilots would sit down with the employers a settlement might be reached. Of course a settlement might be reached-but at what cost?

It is said that the breaking of the accord-an outcome that the Government has uppermost in its mind-would be no loss. The accord, since 1983, has delivered 1.5 million new jobs in Australia, over half of them for women. It has cut inflation significantly, it has produced Medicare, it has produced increases in pensions, it has made a fairer redistribution of income within the community, it has produced--

TALK.START.PARA: —The family allowance supplement.

—It has produced the family allowance supplement. I thank Senator Bolkus. It has expanded training opportunities, it has established Worksafe, it has produced redundancy payments, it has produced superannuation allowances. All those things have been a great achievement. They have helped the community and have helped the pilots themselves. All those things are to be jeopardised-with the consent of the Opposition, as I understand it; certainly without any criticism by the Opposition-for the sake of giving people a 30 per cent increase in wages of $70,000, $80,000 or $90,000 a year. What sort of system will we have? What sort of conciliation, what sort of arbitration, will we have if people can get what they want and ignore the structures that society sets up to govern us all by simply saying, `Because we want our will done, it will be done.'?

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make clear, by the way, the context in which the Full Bench was speaking on 29 September. Mr Justice Maddern, the President, on 25 September said:
In relation to these matters-
he was talking about the dispute between the pilots and the employers-

. . . have revealed a clear division between the employers and the government on the one hand and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) on the other. The former have insisted that the dispute be settled within the guidelines laid down by the Commission . . . the AFAP has refused to accept this position.

That makes it quite clear that one side is willing to go by the rules and the other is not. The Commission itself tried to do something. It was ignored. It is very hollow for the Opposition and for the pilots to say that they are on the side of righteousness when they have ignored every institution, every principle, by which we all otherwise live.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance raised by Senator Puplick today, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to recognise that the failure to resolve the pilots' dispute arises fundamentally from the unwillingness of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, to govern on behalf of all Australians.

I have listened to the contributions made in this debate today and I have heard a significant amount of rubbish. I will deal with the rubbishy comments that I have heard seriatim in a minute. But let me commence by saying that Australians, and especially Labor voters, are very forgiving people. They have hearts of gold. They can forgive the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a lot. Those who have read Blanche d'Alpuget's biography of the Prime Minister obviously have very forgiving hearts. They can forgive a Prime Minister for discarding Labor policies. One only has to read what Clyde Cameron, the former South Australian member, said in a speech entitled `Policy is the problem Bob' to see what true blue Labor voters-or are they true pink Labor voters, I am not sure-think of a Prime Minister who has come from one position in 1974 to a completely different one in 1989 with respect to a very large number of his policies. He is a chameleon-that is his problem. He looks around for what is popular and changes to fit the tune. Labor members, Labor voters, possibly, can forgive him that.

Australians can forgive a Prime Minister who has a few tears, a few boohoos on the television. The British would not put up with it from Thatcher and the Americans would not put up with it from Bush. But we will put up with it from our Prime Minister. He has a few oddities and we can wear that. We will put up with public declarations of cheating on his wife-we can forgive that. We will even put up with his calling a senior citizen who wants to have a go at him in a shopping centre a `silly old bugger'. He seems to get away with that and other expletives which I will not bother the time of the Senate with. But what we cannot forgive is someone, a Prime Minister, who, when faced with such a serious dispute, lets his unbalanced and emotional state get the better of him and declares `It's war' in Rambo style. He inflamed the dispute from the very beginning. He made it clear that the purpose of his involvement in the dispute was to crush the airline pilots union.

There is a huge personal and social cost to the nation of all this. Incidentally, it is a lesser cost to some of the Government's rich mates. Some compensation is being paid to them, such as through waiving landing fees, but nothing is being done for people who have bought a newsagency or gift shop at an airport or who happen to have a tourist facility. Nothing is being done for those people despite the fact that they might be going broke. Australians will not forgive the Prime Minister's bungling in handling this dispute.

Senator Collins's contribution was not very outstanding other than for its nonsensical quality. Senator Collins comes from the Northern Territory. I am surprised that he did not remind us what the Tourist Commission Chairman, Robert Doyle, had to say. With respect to the Territory, Senator Collins's area, he said `Nothing is coming here. It is absolutely infuriating. Nothing is happening and there is loss of jobs'. Senator Collins might have talked about the Northern Territory Minister for Tourism, Roger Vale, who said that hundreds of young men and women have lost or are about to lose their jobs. That is where we are at.

This is not just some ideological argument over whether the pilots union should be able to represent the pilots. This debate is about whether the Prime Minister has in his heart the interests of all Australians, not just those of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), which wants to see recalcitrant unions quashed, and his own interests, because he wants to see those who are bound by the award now sticking to it. The debate is about ordinary Australians who are hurting badly. I come back to the point I made about Australians being forgiving. They are prepared to put up with the problems of an industrial dispute for a period, but this has gone on for too long.

Senator Collins said that this dispute was not caused by the Government and the centralised wage fixing system. He said that it began because the pilots tried to go outside that system and into collective bargaining and because they put demands straight to the airlines. He said that the Rafferty's rules system is what the Opposition wants. Let me take the opportunity to paint that as being the lie that it is. What his dispute shows is the lack of flexibility and lack of discipline in the current system. Not every Australian is covered by the accord and paid wage increases in accordance with the wage guidelines. Let us not kid ourselves about that for starters. Surgeons, doctors, lawyers and sales people who are on commissions are not paid in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President of the ACTU is not either.

—I am reminded by Senator Puplick that the President of the ACTU is not paid in that way. Hundreds of thousands of Australians are not bound by the accord. So what happens when a group of Australians decide that they want out of the centralised wage fixing system? At the moment Rafferty's rules apply. They apply because the Government, recognising that the Industrial Relations Commission needed enforcement powers, intended to give the Commission those enforcement powers but after a little tap on the shoulder from the union movement saying, `No you don't, Bob, not with our agreement', what do we know? The enforcement clauses were withdrawn from the Government's Industrial Relations Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognised the problem with the centralised wage fixing system and that the Commission does not have the capacity to enforce what it wants. It recognised that weakness and was going to do something about it, but the unions said, `Oh no, you don't, that doesn't suit. Leave a system where, if people want to create trouble, they can'. That is effectively what happened. The Government bowed to the unions. That is why we have a problem now. The Commission cannot enforce its decisions. That is why there is not sufficient discipline and flexibility in the system at the moment.

Let me outline the coalition's industrial relations policy. It is not one of Rafferty's rules, as Senator Collins and other Labor senators have presented. It is not one under which if people want out they can just opt out and that is it: they can demand whatever they like and they will get it. Ours is a system under which the centralised wage fixing system would be retained. Some people-both employees and employers-would prefer to stay in that system. They find that a better system-one that protects their interests better.

But that is not true of everyone. Some firms, because they have perhaps achieved an advantage in the market due to their own capacity and hard work, will be willing, prepared and want to pay their workers more. Some firms would be happy to negotiate directly with their workers-not with some union that deals with workers in that area or that particular craft all around the nation but directly with the people who work for that firm, who can take some pride in the achievement of that firm. We say that where a firm wants to do that, where an enterprise wants to make an agreement with its workers and its workers want to do the same back, we will let them do that and that agreement will be specific to that particular enterprise.

There is no question of some mad flow-on of wage increases. Those agreements will be for that enterprise. But, of course, the union movement does not want that. The union movement does not want to be muscled out by the workers, the very workers it is purporting to represent. We say that will be a better thing. We will have a centralised wage fixing system which those who want to can remain in and we will have the opportunity for people together, worker and employer, to decide whether they want to opt out and to negotiate agreements that suit themselves. We say that is a very sensible thing. So, in that sense, our system will be more flexible but we will also have the capacity to enforce those decisions. Once you make your choice, you will stick by it. There will be no Rafferty's rules as you can have under this system. Enforceability provisions will be installed into the Act so that there will not be the system that we have at the moment where people can just opt out and say, `See you later, Jack'. There will be a much better system.

Incidentally, the Minister at the table, Senator Reynolds, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of women, may care to realise, may even one day acknowledge, how much better this will be for women, because we have even seen the union movement acknowledging that it is not adequately representing women. Women are not flocking to join unions, and they are certainly not being given the opportunity to be represented at the higher echelons of unions as we have seen in the last couple of weeks: a couple of women have lost their jobs, lost the opportunity to represent women at the higher levels in the union movement. It is a boys own movement.

Under our system women in a particular enterprise would be able to have their voice properly heard because they would be negotiating directly with the employer. Under our system we say that, if the employees want to nominate a union to act on their behalf, they can. That is fair enough. People should be able to nominate who can represent them. So I fail to see how that can be presented as an anti-union policy. What the Prime Minister wants to do is defend the accord at all costs. My leader in the Senate, Senator Chaney, had this to say with respect to the accord and, in addition, with respect to the allegation constantly being made by the Labor Party that we support the pilots:

The pilots' action is inexcusable but the irony is that the Prime Minister is using the dispute to defend an accord which has cost Australia a fortune in terms of inflation, productivity forgone and massive increases in interest rates and foreign debt and, of most importance to workers, falling real wages. There is widespread disenchantment with the so-called accord. The reality is that it is making Australian workers worse off and they know it. It is a third world approach which offers only the prospect of ever decreasing real wages.

Senator Collins was quick to list, as Senator Cooney did, what he thought the achievements of the accord were. Let us look at the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly released a couple of days ago, quoted ad infinitum in Question Time today by Senator Cook in one of his set up dorothy dix questions. We see that in Australia economic growth is expected to be, for 1989-90, about 3 per cent, conferred with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average of 2.6 per cent, 2 per cent in the United States and 4 per cent in Japan. So in that sense you could say, in terms of economic growth, we are not too far off the mark. So where are we going wrong because, when you look at the average for inflation for OECD countries, you see that that is 4 per cent? We are still struggling along on 7 per cent, which is nearly double. Japan, which was expected to have a growth of 4 per cent, can manage with an inflation rate of 2 per cent.

The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women might like to turn her mind to what the accord has done in terms of inflation to the weekly shopping bill of every woman who buys groceries and food for her family. We should not forget that the Prime Minister has handled this dispute in such a way that he is not trying to salvage what he can out of it for all Australians; he is salvaging what he can out of it for himself, his mates and the union movement. He is doing this for himself, because he wants to get on with his mates and the union movement; he is doing it for the union movement because it wants to get rid of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots; and he is doing it for his mates because Peter Abeles is acknowledged to be a very good friend of his. It is extraordinary that the Government is paying compensation to the airlines-admittedly a good friend of the Prime Minister-and nothing is being done for the other people who have been so devastatingly affected by this dispute. So the Government wants to abuse the Opposition. It says that we have nothing to offer, obviously ignoring our nine-point plan. It is clear that that plan is not in support of the pilots. It is an absolute lie that we have supported the pilots.

We have written to the Prime Minister and encouraged him to use his capacity to solve this dispute, to exercise some influence on Australian Airlines, but still mistruths are being quoted by the Government. The Government is determined to look after its mates. This is not only the case in terms of the airline dispute. As Senator Puplick pointed out, this can be seen in changes in the media laws in this country, in the funding we put into the defence of the America's Cup, in the inexplicable decision to pour millions of dollars into Kodak, which just happens to be in the Prime Minister's electorate, and in another attempt to buy off the banks to try to keep interest rates down. It is bad luck if a person is not in that category. If one happens to have one's mortgage with a building society, it is just bad luck. Senator Puplick pointed out examples of jobs for the boys. The notion that this Prime Minister has got rid of child poverty is an absolute embarrassment.

So what it amounts to is that the Government has not handled this dispute on behalf of all Australians. The dispute has been used to achieve the ideological aims of the Prime Minister and the union movement and the cost of that to all Australians has simply been ignored. As I said at the outset, Australians can be very forgiving of a Prime Minister. They will forgive him the tears, they will forgive him cheating on his wife, they will forgive him calling an old pensioner a `silly old bugger'. But the Prime Minister's hopeless handling of this dispute will not be forgiven by the normal voters, and that is the reason this Government will be disposed of at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before us today is that the airline pilots strike is the fault of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and, further, that the Prime Minister does not govern on behalf of all Australians. This nonsense would be laughable if it were not taken so seriously by the Opposition. The joke is that the Opposition fundamentally believes that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) can hold a gun at the head of the Australian people but that this is the Prime Minister's fault. The airline pilots can wreck the tourist industry, damage the economy, create havoc in the hospitality industry but, as we find out today, this is the Prime Minister's fault. We are constantly told in this place by the Opposition that this strike is currently costing billions of dollars. I have listened to some of Senator Chaney's estimates of what this dispute has cost to date and, moreover, what it is likely to cost in a full year. We have even had breakdowns of figures for the tourist industry. Never once, though, have the pilots been condemned for the ruthless and reckless way in which they are seeking to achieve their ends.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition says that the Prime Minister does not govern on behalf of all Australians. If he gave in to the outrageous industrial blackmail of the pilots, does that mean that he would be governing for all Australians? If the airline pilots can opt out of the wages guidelines and negotiate using the tactics they are currently employing, that seems okay to the Opposition. The pilots enjoy the support of the Opposition. Like the Canberra and Sydney visiting medical specialists, the Opposition makes out a special case. Again, if people hold the community to ransom by whatever means, the Opposition will defend them. The pilots seem to have the support of no-one in Australia except some honourable senators opposite.

Yesterday, Mr Howard, the previous Leader of the Liberal Party, asked a question of the Prime Minister in the other place. His question in part was: would not this dispute be ended by individual pilots being signed up as quickly as possible on new contracts? Certainly, if Opposition senators did not support the Pilots Federation in the way that they have, we may well have made more progress to date.

Last week the Opposition said that this dispute had been mishandled. It seems to believe that to stand back and let anarchy prevail as industrial relations is the only sensible course of action. The Opposition argues that anything else is a mishandling. When the Opposition says that this dispute is mishandled, it is guilty of some of the worst humbug and hypocrisy. The Government must stand firm behind a wages policy that has established guidelines and has seen a reversal of the disastrous Fraser-Howard years, such as when inflation and unemployment went out of control in 1981 and 1982. In those years Australia experienced a wages explosion and a recession followed that saw unemployment rise to around 11 per cent.

The policy of the coalition Government of that time allowed collective bargaining and ended centralised wage fixing, which gave wage outcomes that threatened to wreck the whole country. Indeed, the industrially strong did very well out of those years whilst other groups of wage and salary earners copped the inflation and the broken promises. They remembered those failed policies in March 1983. Coalition policy now seems to be the same. It does not feel the need to rethink and reassess its position since 1981-1982, even though the price of its policies has been the political wilderness ever since.

This is an important matter today because the central issue in the pilots dispute is whether a centralised system of wage fixation, with balances, checks and benefits for all wage and salary earners, can survive. The alternative which the pilots want is a wage fixing system which allows them, with the ability they have to wreck the tourist industry, dislocate business, and cost Australia valuable overseas exchange, wage rises whenever they wish. The pilots can hold a gun at the Government's head or the airlines' head and say, `Pay up now or we will cause all of the dislocation and disruption that we can'. The pilots know that they can rely on the support of the Opposition. When the Government and the airlines refuse to pay up they are accused by the Opposition of mishandling the dispute.

Of course, if things were different and the Government did not stand firm, the wage fixing principles would be thrown out the window. The industrially strong would immediately use the muscle that they have and completely break the wages system that has seen an unparallelled growth in employment in Australia. No doubt if that were to happen the Opposition would be arguing here for quids for their mates and nothing for the rest. In fact, it is interesting to see the Opposition's real industrial relations policy at work. When Canberra doctors are after every dollar they can get, the whole world must come to a stop. The Opposition screams `foul' and says that the doctors must get exorbitant rises immediately. I seem to remember listening to how terrible it was that visiting specialists could get only $67 an hour in Canberra but could get $97 in Sydney and how the world would come to an end because of this.

The Opposition also seems to be concerned that the pharmacists are not getting enough money. It has argued repeatedly here for more money for the pharmacists. The fact that an independent tribunal has come down with some findings does not seem to worry them. No, those in the Opposition will not let anything like that get in the way of pay rises for their mates. It was a different story when it came to the Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets workers. Then every sanction possible was advocated. The policy was different but quite clear-cut: wipe out the meat workers and the confectioners, and the Government would no doubt have mishandled that dispute as well. In that case the Opposition wanted every possible weapon used to break the strike. This time it is the Opposition's mates who are involved; so it wants negotiations, pay deals and the whole bit.

The hypocrisy of the whole industrial relations policy of the Opposition stands out starkly: `When it is ordinary workers, use every weapon to break them; when it is our mates let us all get together and work out a deal'. The Norm Gallaghers of the airline industry can feel safe with coalition industrial relations policy. From the very outset the Pilots Federation has aimed to destroy the orderly, centralised wage fixing system that has served Australia well. From the beginning it was clear that nothing was going to get in its way. It planned for months before the dispute, started the whole campaign and advised its members on how to survive a long period without pay. Of course, the Pilots Federation represents other workers outside of the commercial airline industry. It also represents pilots in other areas of employment, and for these workers the Federation is seeking rises inside the system: `When and where the bargaining power is greatest, use muscle'. All other areas use the system that so far has seen an orderly movement of wages.

On 11 August the Pilots Federation did not attend the Industrial Relations Commission but instead organised a 12-hour stoppage in Melbourne. From 12 August to 14 August it was the turn of Brisbane, Perth and Sydney. On 11 August, the AFAP stated quite clearly that the pilots saw no point in pursuing wage increases within the wage fixing guidelines. Since that time the Pilots Federation has stated that if the pilots get the rise and somebody says it is consistent with the guidelines, it will not worry the pilots.

Now, after many more weeks have gone by, the Pilots Federation has again refused arbitration. It walked out of the hearings last week having restated its claim that it does not care about the wages system and wishes to negotiate directly with the airlines to obtain its claim of 29.47 per cent. At no stage have its demands or its tactics changed. The pilots will claim the 29.47 per cent outside of the wages guidelines, and they will disturb, disrupt or ruthlessly do as much damage as they can until they get their own way. And what do we get from the Opposition? We are told that the Government is mishandling the dispute, we are told that it is the Prime Minister's fault, and we are told that the Government is not governing on behalf of the whole country because it will not give in to the demands of the Opposition's mates-the Pilots Federation.

We have had some other lovely little chestnuts from the Opposition on this matter. Senator Stone has revealed to the world during this dispute that he has always been a supporter of trade unionism. He even revealed that the trade unions have been secretly admired for years by all members of the Opposition. The key words are `secretly admiring the unions'. Those opposite have certainly never done anything to suggest that they have anything but contempt for trade unions. When their mates are in a sticky situation and they are called out to defend them, all of a sudden we find out that they are all born again trade unionists. So what does the Opposition advocate? Nothing. Mr Peacock, as the current Leader of the Opposition, stated on 31 August:
We are not in Government today, and the duty is on this Government to fix the dispute.

The only thing the Opposition can suggest is that it is not the fault of the Pilots Federation; that the whole world should condemn the Government and the Prime Minister. We never hear anything from the Opposition about the tactics of the Pilots Federation and I doubt whether we ever will. It is just like the doctors dispute: we are told that they are all reasonable people pursuing reasonable goals. As to the Dollar Sweets workers, the Mudginberri workers and others, the Opposition has a more hysterical view about them. The Opposition does not know where to go on this dispute. The topic it has put up for debate here today shows how bankrupt it is.
