SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to major reforms to government purchasing and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Government is about to take significant steps forward in improving both the cost-effectiveness of government purchasing and the ways in which it can enhance opportunities for local suppliers to get Commonwealth business.
This is a major element of micro-economic reform.

From 1 November there will be major changes to improve the efficiency of government purchasing. At the same time we will introduce new measures to give greater effect to our strong and continuing commitment to encouraging the development of local industry.

Federal public sector purchasing is very big business. An estimated 7 to 8 billion dollars, or 4 per cent of gross domestic product, is spent each year by Budget sector agencies alone. This estimate excludes very substantial expenditure by government business enterprises. Purchasing is also very important to the efficient administration of government. Government programs would founder if their supplies of goods and services were to fail through breakdowns in their purchasing systems or if capital acquisition projects were unable to deliver on time and within budget.

But in the past purchasing has been a backwater. In government, as in the private sector, it has not received the attention that it merits from management and its potential to contribute to better management has not been exploited. This was borne out by the service-wide review which was conducted last year under the financial management improvement program.

The review involved extensive consultation within government and with industry. It took account of the views of the people who work in purchasing and managers who are served by purchasing. It took account of developments in other governments. It also took account of the views of those who do business with government.
It found:
A restrictive regulatory environment;
An emphasis on process rather than outcomes;
A culture of caution and risk avoidance;
Slow and laborious processes;
A failure to provide staff with the training and career development opportunities they needed;
A preoccupation with technical rather than functional specifications;
A commitment to single stage tendering processes whether or not they were effective in the market.
The system was costing us money through excessive processing costs, time delays and failure to obtain the best price or the most appropriate goods and services from suppliers.

It was against this background that the Government decided to embark on the current program of reforms. The aim, as with other reforms to public administration, was not only to give managers greater freedom and authority to manage but also to require them to manage and to be accountable.

These reforms are part of a general program to improve efficiency in government administration. In the Administrative Services portfolio this has also been reflected in major reforms to the provision of common services which have already produced better performance and very large savings to government.
Following months of planning and preparation, the progressive implementation of the changes will begin with effect from 1 November. The following requirements have been undertaken:
The Audit Act 1901 has been amended to enable the issue of ministerial guidelines;
The finance regulations dealing with purchasing have been substantially amended to eliminate prescription of detailed processes and tabled in Parliament;
The Minister for Administrative Services has tabled and issued several guidelines on principles and practices for purchasing under the new regime; and
Departments are preparing purchasing reform plans for endorsement by their Ministers before they begin to operate under the new regime.
Departments are required to advise on progress in their annual reports from 1988-89 to 1990-91.

To complete the system, the Minister for Administrative Services will shortly issue a policy framework which sets out in summary form the major policies applying to Commonwealth purchasing and their integration with industry policy.
The main elements of the new approach will be:

A new emphasis on value for money in government purchasing, rather than price or acquisition costs. Departments' officers will need to look broadly at the performance of the goods and services they buy and their suppliers and take all relevant costs into account in assessment of offers;

Greater scope for departments to settle purchasing methods within a general principle of open and effective competition. Departments will have to gazette public invitations of offers and contracts arranged. But methods of approach to the market will not be rigidly prescribed. Use of conventional public tendering will continue, but other approaches, such as staged purchasing and prequalification of suppliers, will be encouraged, together with early notification of purchasing plans.
Under this new approach there will be greater opportunity for departments to tailor their methods to the markets in which they are buying. Generally, we expect to see:
Reduced costs in bidding and administration for both suppliers and government;
A more competitive approach from suppliers;

A continuing emphasis on ethics and fair dealing, supplemented by a formal code of ethics which the Minister for Administrative Services has already issued with one of the Commonwealth procurement guidelines;
Training and development to raise professionalism in Commonwealth purchasing and supply; and
Use of practices and procedures that will make it easier for industry to provide commercial solutions to government, and for government to get value for money, for example:
Functional specifications rather than detailed technical specifications;
Purchasing planning including forward purchasing planning;
Negotiation, including post offer negotiation in appropriate circumstances; and
Standardised and simple documentation.
I want to turn now to the Government's preference policy.

For a long time the Commonwealth Government has given some form of preference in its purchasing with the object of assisting Australian firms to obtain government business and thereby encourage the development of Australian industry. Since 1983 New Zealand industry has been treated in the same way as Australian industry for the purposes of the policy, consistent with the closer economic relations trade agreement between the two countries.
The preference policy has been in operation in some form for many years and has four main elements:
A monetary margin of preference;
Avoidance of biased or discriminatory practice in purchasing;
Debriefing of unsuccessful local tenderers; and
Mandatory use of the local products in some construction works purchases.

The preference margin is generally equivalent to a notional discount of 20 per cent on the Australian and New Zealand content of tendered goods and related services. There is discretion to give a higher margin in defined circumstances and for high value contracts.

A review of the effectiveness of the preference policy was initiated in 1988. The review was part of our response to the 1987 report of the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements.

There has been extensive consultation with industry, the unions and the States about the preference policy. As part of the review, the Bureau of Industry Economics evaluated the effectiveness of the margin as an industry development mechanism. What has emerged is that:
The margin is cumbersome and costly to administer;
It has very little effect, for example it has influenced the outcome of only 107 contracts out of tens of thousands;

It is inconsistent with the thrust of our industry policy which is directed to making local industry more competitive. This is because it is like another protective tariff overlaid on the existing customs duty. It does not serve our concern to make industry more competitive;

The margin is inconsistent with the new purchasing policy with its emphasis on value for money. In this regime it does not make sense to use a mechanism which is narrowly focused on price. Remember that the new purchasing policy does not rely solely on final price.

For us the outcome of the review of preference was disappointing. We find ourselves responsible for a scheme which is not cost effective, not contributing to industry development and which is contrary to the thrust of purchasing reforms. But we believe very strongly that we must do something to demonstrate and make effective our commitment to Australian industry.

We considered various alternatives to the margin, including a second offer scheme to give suppliers with high local content a chance to make a second bid in some circumstances. However, the scheme did not generate wide acceptance. So we did not proceed with it.

What we have decided to do is to abolish, from 1 November, the notional 20 per cent discount component of the National Preference Agreement as applied by the Commonwealth. But we will retain and strengthen the anti-discriminatory elements of the current policy. For example, we are looking at making purchasing managers ensure that the specifications they issue are not biased.
The elimination of discrimination against local industry is fundamental Government policy and the basis of the National Preference Agreement to which the Commonwealth is strongly committed.

The Commonwealth's decision was agreed to in principle by the signatories to the National Preference Agreement at a meeting of the Australian Industry and Technology Council on 22 September. Some of them wanted to delay removal of the margin for twelve months, but this was not a practical alternative if we were to press on with our general purchasing reforms. So the changes will go ahead and we have been asked to report back to the Australian Industry and Technology Council next year on their effectiveness.
In any case, not all signatories to the Agreement apply the 20 per cent margin. Some apply 10 per cent and New Zealand does not apply a margin at all.
The specifics of the new arrangements are as follows:

the 20 per cent preference margin and discretionary preference elements of the Commonwealth's policy will be abolished from 1 November 1989-the same date as for the commencement of the purchasing reforms. Requests for tender for goods over $20,000 issued before that date will be assessed under the old system;
the important elements of the policy dealing with non-discrimination and debriefing of unsuccessful local tenderers will be retained and strengthened;

emphasis will be placed on the use of functional specifications rather than detailed technical specifications. This will give local suppliers the opportunity to offer cost-effective and innovative solutions to user requirements;
a purchase Australian office will be established;
there will be a public sector education campaign about buying local products;
we will fund the establishment of a full time National Industrial Supplies Office Co-ordinator;
a working party of officials investigating whether departments should pay Customs duty will report by 1 November;
priority will be given to dealing with the remaining recommendations of the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements;
consideration will be given to measures to co-ordinate the use of Commonwealth and State Government purchasing to assist industry; and

there will be additional Commonwealth funding for the very successful national procurement development program. State Ministers at the recent Australian Industry and Technology Council meeting agreed in principle to additional joint funding for the program after June 1990.
I turn now to some details of these measures.
Existing Measures

The measures which will be retained and strengthened were last endorsed in 1984 and are designed to give Australia and New Zealand suppliers every opportunity to win orders from the Commonwealth. They require that:
Government specifications not exclude suitable, or reasonably adaptable, Australian and New Zealand products;
alternative Australian and New Zealand solutions be considered;
department's ordering patterns where possible be scaled to the minimum economic order requirements of Australian and New Zealand industry; and
unsuccessful suppliers be debriefed on request about the reasons why they failed to win orders.
A Purchase Australian Office

This new and entrepreneurial organisation will be established in the Department of Administrative Services to develop a role in promoting Australian and New Zealand industry in government and government businesses to industry. It will help to educate business about government buying, without cutting across what is already being done in government departments and agencies. A 008 number has been installed in the new office to handle queries from local suppliers.
The office will take on the role of designated body under the national preference agreement to investigate any complaints of discrimination.
It will manage a public sector education program.

It will work closely with those agencies in government with specific industry development functions, such as the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and Austrade, and with the purchasing community generally.

It will also join in investigating other suggested initiatives, such as strategic purchasing by Commonwealth and State governments to develop local industries. And it will develop links with the industrial supplies offices.
National Industrial Supplies Office Co-ordinator

The Government has also committed funds for the establishment of a full time national industrial supplies office co-ordinator in Canberra. The industrial supplies offices assist suppliers to be fully aware of the commercial and technical requirements of major purchasers and ensure that these purchasers are equally aware of the supply capabilities of local producers. The national office will coordinate the efforts of the various State offices to stimulate Australian industry.
The office is presently staffed on a part-time basis with funds from the States. The co-ordinator will work closely with the purchase Australian office.
A Public Sector Education Campaign

The aim of this campaign will be to promote in government the real advantages of dealing with Australian and New Zealand industry and the opportunities to get better value for money through doing so. These can include:
whole-of-life support;
shorter supply lines; and
avoiding the vagaries of currency fluctuations.
Payment of Customs Duty by Departments

One step we are disposed to take is to make departments, not just statutory authorities, pay customs duty. Under present arrangements, departments are required to include the duty notionally for tender evaluation purposes. However, actual payment of the duty would remove a possible financial incentive which departments might have to buy cheaper imports. It may also simplify the government purchasing proceeds for both suppliers and buyers. We have directed a group of officials considering the issue to report by 1 November.
General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-Government Procurement Code

Removal of the preference margin would allow fresh consideration of Australia's accession to the code should the Government decide that this will offer advantages to Australian industry. At present we are unable to sign as a result of the protective nature of the preference margin.

To reiterate, purchasing reform is an important part of the Government's programs for economic improvements. Greater public sector efficiency and improved access for local suppliers has a beneficial effect right down the line. And it is consistent with and complementary to the Government's programs for the development and restructuring of Australian industry.

The issues have been thoroughly canvassed by all the interested parties. We all want better government purchasing systems that save time and money, improve service and performance and encourage local suppliers. We don't want symbolic reforms or to continue with processes that are outmoded or unworkable.
We aim to make purchasing by government conform to the best practices of the private sector.

Certainly, we will demonstrate for all to see our clear commitment to the development and strengthening of Australian industry and we will show our equally strong commitment to the anti-discriminatory principles underlying the national preference agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The Liberal and National parties welcome the thrust of the statement and the stated intention of placing a new emphasis on value for money in government purchasing. We also welcome the proposed reduction in regulation and the simplification of contracts which are detailed in this joint statement. Indeed, the statement picks up a number of Liberal and National parties policies, and I welcome that.

The problems for Australian manufacturers is that this Government is still not addressing the basic problems of macro-economic and micro-economic reform and until it does so Australian manufacturers will face great difficulties in competing with their international counterparts. Further, the statement is short on detail, especially costing, and proposes the establishment of yet another bureaucratic office which does not augur well for reforms aimed at addressing excessive regulation which has for so long been a feature of the purchasing environment of this Government. The absence of detail and costing and the failure to include these proposals in the 1989-90 Budget is indicative of the haste with which these proposals have been brought forward and I believe that they have been brought forward for a political purpose. They have been brought forward at this late hour in this Government's life so that the Government will be able to say at the election, `Oh yes, we were addressing these matters when we went to the people; have a look at the statement'.

Of course, this Government is long on statements and short on action. I doubt whether it will have much time to implement these proposals, although I welcome them, and I hope that it arranges to implement them. It would indeed be most welcome if the key objectives as outlined in the statement were achieved and if they ultimately led to more purchases from Australian manufacturers. But I have to say that the Hawke Government's record on regulation review does not inspire confidence in its ability to simplify purchasing procedures. The Government's failure to deliver on its rhetoric does not inspire confidence in its ability to deliver this package. As I said, this Government is long on talk and short on action. I hope that this will not be so with this statement of intention in relation to government purchasing. Australian industry would welcome relief from the heavy burden of on-costs. Australian industry would welcome a reduction in the heavy burden of regulations and welcome micro-economic and macro-economic reforms that would enable it to compete domestically and internationally with overseas industry.

The most important point about this proposal is the removal of the 20 per cent preference margin for Australian tenders on Commonwealth Government purchases. The Hawke-Keating Government now expects, or will from November of this year, Australian manufacturers to compete with overseas manufacturers, without preference, while continuing to allow them to be subject to crippling burdens such as interest rates currently running at up to 25 per cent on their overdrafts; a rigid industrial relations system which grants across the board wage rises regardless of productivity increases; as I mentioned before, ruinous on-costs and penalties; and the Hawke-Keating Government's failure to address properly the need to reform coastal shipping, the need to reform the waterfront, the need to address itself to the problems of the transport industry and the need to free up the communications industry. I also refer to this Government's failure to take any steps which would enable employers to attack current restrictive work practices.

The Hawke Government is also imposing on Australian manufacturers the burden of refusing to reduce the enormous volume of paperwork and overregulation which is imposed upon them. Indeed, while the Hawke Government refuses to address these fundamental issues Senator Button wonders why his policies are not working. Indeed, he has publicly acknowledged that his policies for industry are wrong. I say to Senator Button that they continue to be wrong and not to work because the Australian Labor Party refuses to address the fundamental defects of our economy.

The statement glosses over the real problems of the economy of this nation and attempts to con the people of Australia into believing that delivery of a statement of intention is the same as delivery of the goods. We wait to see, because that is not so, as has been amply demonstrated by this Government's repeated statements about micro-economic reform and its repeated failure to address micro-economic reform. I do hope that this statement will be not just another statement that goes into the drawer of things this Government has talked about but not acted upon. I hope we do see some action in the delivery of this package to the benefit of Australian manufacturers.

There is one particular matter on which I have made many speeches publicly outside the Senate and within the Senate. I am delighted to see that Senator Button has picked up my point and that in future contracts emphasis will be placed on the use of functional specifications rather than detailed technical specifications. This will give local suppliers the opportunity to offer cost-effective and innovative solutions to user requirements. What does all that technical language mean? In simple language, it means that, instead of government officers being technical experts and saying, for example, in relation to computers, `What we want is an IBM XYZ computer operating in this area doing this job, a Wang computer in this area doing this job and a Digital computer in this area doing this job' with detailed software all worked out by government employees, many of whom will have been duchessed by the international companies whose programs and equipment they have specified, the Government will simply say, `We want a computer to provide this result'-in other words, a functional specification rather than a detailed technical specification.

Then Australian manufacturers will be able to put forward propositions which incorporate their equipment, maybe in conjunction with imported equipment, which will result in Australian manufacturers being given the opportunity to tender successfully whereas at present, because of the way in which the tender documents are written, frequently Australian manufacturers are excluded by the tender document from being able to enter into the field. It is a matter upon which, as I have said, I have spoken frequently. I am delighted to see that Senator Button and his colleague have picked up my recommendations in this regard and implemented them in this document. I do hope that it is not just a statement of intention but becomes a fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly on this ministerial statement and to make several points. Firstly, it is extremely poorly written. I find it rather offensive to have to read gobbledegook, to have difficulty in working out exactly what is meant and also to have to wade through an enormous number of completely unnecessary words. The document could have been shortened enormously and said exactly the same thing. I want to give a few examples of poor English. It states, `The following requirements have been undertaken'. One does not undertake requirements. On page 7 one finds the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to develop a role in promoting Australian and New Zealand industry . . .

What is wrong with `promoting Australian and New Zealand industry'? There is no point in the extra words. It states that it will `manage a public sector education program'. How about using the words `educating the public'? On page 8 of the typescript of the statement there is a double tautology when the argument twists back on itself. It reads:
Removal of the preference margin would allow fresh consideration of Australia's accession to the code-
referring to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade code-
should the Government decide that this will offer advantages to Australian industry. At present we are unable to sign as a result of the protective nature of the preference margin.

One does not know what the advantages are or to whom it is referring. One could refer to inefficiency in regard to some government purchasing by mentioning the recent purchase of photocopiers for senatorial offices. I was sent specifications for two photocopiers and asked to decide between the two photocopiers in order to replace the one that was in my office. Having an interest in using the least possible amount of paper, I selected a photocopier which, according to the specifications, would double side and collate. The photocopier was duly delivered to my office. I understand that this experience has been shared by other senators. When I proceeded to try to make it double side and collate, I found that I could not work the knobs on it to get it to do that.

The service lady came out and looked at the machine. She said, `Yes, you press this button to do that and this button to do something else'. When she had finished I said, `Yes, but I want to be able to double side and collate'. She stooped down and opened a drawer in the base of the photocopier and said, `To get it to do that you have to have this extra little piece which goes in down here'. I said, `I bought this machine believing that it had that little piece so that it would double side and collate'. She said, `That wasn't in the contract'. Clearly, there had been a slip-up between the information which was provided to my office and on which I had made a choice, and the contract which had gone to the supplier. To compound matters, I then said, `Well what happens if I buy the piece out of my electorate allowance and put it in because I am keen not to use so much paper?'. I was then told that if I bought anything and attached it to the photocopier it would abrogate the service contract for the photocopier and that furthermore the Department would not buy the extra piece of equipment to attach to the photocopier.

Another point to be made about this example is that in many instances when staff are very heavily loaded with photocopying duties, the photocopying is done only on one side of the paper when in many instances it would be quite appropriate to use both sides of the paper. So more paper is being used unnecessarily. I pose the question: Did anybody do the sums, not just on purchasing the photocopier, but on the actual lifetime cost of the photocopier plus the paper that goes through it? I suggest that nobody bothered to do the sums because if he had done so, he may well have found that the purchase of that extra bit of capital equipment would have not only saved money in terms of purchasing of paper but also conserved paper, and that is an important point.

One could also look at the purchasing of computing equipment for Parliament House and the way in which we have been provided with software which does not easily interface with software outside Parliament House. The software requires special instruction and quite a considerable number of staff to be available to provide assistance. A so-called `help desk' had to be created. The purchase of more usual software may well have avoided a great deal of that cost. It may be that the initial capital cost of the software was low, but what is the lifetime cost of running that software if we have to maintain a large staff of people to help us when we have problems? The software is not a particularly well designed piece of software, in particular with respect to word processing, but it is even less user friendly with respect to a number of other features.

The document before us, as I have indicated, is long on rhetoric and is not particularly specific with the exception that it seeks to remove the 20 per cent margin which has been a nominal margin provided to the purchase of Australian equipment up to the time, I think it is 1 November, when it will be removed. I stress to the Government that in making this sort of decision it is important that the total overall costs are considered. If, for argument's sake, one has a choice between buying an Australian piece of equipment and buying an overseas piece of equipment and the purchase of the overseas piece of equipment necessarily involves a downturn in Australian industry, a change in our foreign exchange and, perhaps, the unemployment of Australians-Australians going on to the dole-what is the total cost of making that sort of decision? We should be looking not just at the cost of the equipment in isolation but at the total effect of the purchase of that equipment, either within Australia or outside Australia, on the total Australian economy. It may well be that a substantial margin in favour of Australian purchases is, overall, beneficial.

The only other point I wish to comment on is the desirability that Australian Government purchases also be associated with any import duties that are payable on those purchases. This would seem to me to be a reasonable way of making those comparative assessments provided, and I stress again, that the associated costs such as the lifetime costs of the use of the equipment, that may well be borne if purchases outside Australia are made, are taken into account. A fairer way of considering those costs would be if the import costs included the import duty, if any is payable.

The area is clearly an important one. The Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) draws our attention to the fact that public sector purchasing runs to the extent of $7 billion to $8 billion per year or 4 per cent of gross domestic product. It is important that we do better in this area, that we make better choices. I suspect that many of those choices will be better only if we get more competent people doing the assessments and those more directly involved in the use of the equipment having some say in how those choices are determined. Certainly, the point that has already been stressed in relation to emphasis on performance rather than narrow technical descriptions is a valid one. I am aware from the past, working in a former government department, of the way in which the call for tenders was often written with a particular piece of equipment in mind. In fact, the specifications for that equipment were virtually copied into the tender documents and made it extremely difficult for other tenderers to meet those precise specifications. A more generous and function-oriented description of the equipment would help in that area.

In conclusion, I do not find this document all that satisfactory. It does not really give us a great deal of indication as to where the Government is going with the exception of the tariff and the removal of the 20 per cent safety margin. It remains to be seen in practice whether this package results in more efficient ways and a more effective government purchasing regimen.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The annual report of the Commonwealth Bank Group was tabled by the President in the Senate yesterday. I congratulate the Commonwealth Bank Group on the quite clear improvement in its finances and, more importantly, on what those financial results reveal about its improved efficiency of performance in 1988-89. But in doing so-and I will come back to that point-I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the report from the Board of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation contains one or two comments which I think are of more general interest in so far as they touch upon the state of the banking industry and, more particularly, the state of financial markets under the great pressure which the Government, through its tight monetary policy-high interest rates-is placing upon those financial markets. I quote from page 2 of the report where the Chairman of the Board, Mr Besley, who signed this report on behalf of the Board, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Towards the end of the year, the operating environment was marked by sharp increases in interest rates associated with a progressive tightening of monetary policy aimed at excessively strong demand, inflationary pressures and Australia's external imbalance. While the monetary stance adopted by the authorities has contributed to some moderation in the pace of economic activity-
I interpolate to say that the degree of moderation is not overly apparent-
its effort on credit markets has been particularly significant, resulting in a weakening of the underlying position of many companies.

Given the kind of language which the Commonwealth Bank Board uses in reports of this kind, I regard that as rather sombre stuff. It is reminiscent in that respect of the Reserve Bank's annual report for 1989, which was presented and debated in this chamber about six weeks ago, just after the Budget. A little more on the same aspect appears on page 10 of the report, where, in discussing the question of its provision for bad and doubtful debts-a vastly increased provision, I might note in passing-the bank says:

Earnings had to bear a considerably increased charge for bad and doubtful debts, as higher interest costs on financing found out weaknesses in business cash flows . . . Careful analysis of accounts resulted in a charge against profit of $200.4 million to write off bad debts and provide for specific doubtful debts. This was about double the comparable charge of $104.5 million in 1987-88.
I will skip a couple of sentences in order not to make the quotes too long. The bank goes on to say:
In striking this provision, the Bank took a more than usually conservative approach, to allow for the likelihood of testing times ahead for the economy.

In discussing the Reserve Bank annual report I pointed out that Reserve Bank boards, and in this case boards of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, are not given to flamboyant or overly alarmist language. Language of the kind I have just been quoting is, I think, rather strong by the standards of these reports. This commercial bank-a government-owned bank, of course, but a bank operating within the commercial banking sector-is saying to the public and, indeed, to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and to this Parliament, to which this report has been presented, `Notwithstanding that the economy at present appears to be bobbing along rather buoyantly, don't make any mistake about it; the very high interest rates that have been imposed upon us by the Reserve Bank at the Treasurer's behest are slowly but surely weakening the underlying financial standing of many of our customers. Therefore, we as a prudent commercial bank have felt it wise and appropriate to virtually double our provision for bad and doubtful debts in our accounts for the year just ended'.

I note in passing that those remarks by the Commonwealth Bank Board are fully in line with the views stated-again, in rather unusually blunt terms-in the latest Commonwealth Bank Economic Newsletter, which was released last weekend, and in an accompanying press release in which Mr Paul McCarthy, the Chief Economist of the Commonwealth Bank, who would of course have had a hand in writing the very passages I have just been quoting from this annual report, has said:
With no signs yet of an across-the-board moderation in domestic demand, and imports continuing to trend higher, there are no prospects of any decline in interest rates until some way into 1990.

At a later point of his remarks-again, I will be sparing in my quotation of this very interesting Economic Newsletter because I am using it only to back up the point that was made in the Commonwealth Bank report-Mr McCarthy said:
Even when an economic downturn is clearly underway-
which he foresees presumably early next year-
the vulnerability of the exchange rate to a rapid decline in interest rates is likely to see monetary policy eased cautiously rather than aggressively.

So much for those aspects of the Commonwealth Bank's annual report which deal with what I might call the macro-economic or, if you like, the monetary environment within which the bank is operating or seeking to operate.

Another aspect of the report on which I want to touch very briefly is the quite clear, I would say, quantum leap, almost, in efficiency of operation of the bank during the past 12 months. There are at least three indicators of that given in the report. There is first of all the reference on page 10 of the report to the return on average equity which in 1988-89 rose sharply to 14.63 per cent from a figure of just over 10 per cent-10.01 per cent-in the previous year. I think one only has to look at those two figures to see that something very significant happened to the bank's performance in 1988-89. Interestingly enough, the bank makes the point that this has nothing to do with a greater return from the pure interest rate effects. It is not due to higher interest rates. In fact, the bank actually says that the margin of the average interest earned over the average interest paid to its depositors fell slightly during the year from 3.97 per cent in 1987-88 to 3.84 per cent in 1988-89. So what we are really looking at is simply a more efficient operation and not an operation which is simply having its profits increased because interest rates have risen. On the contrary.
One obvious area where that increased efficiency is being found is indicated by the comment on page 11 of the report relating to staff costs where the report notes:
Staff costs as a percentage of total net income were reduced to 37.9% . . .
And it goes on to describe this as:
a dramatic improvement on the ratios of 40.3% in 1987/88 and 52.7% five years ago.

I think one would have to say that those figures speak for themselves. Finally, the report notes on page 5 a significant improvement in the bank's risk-weighted capital ratio. I apologise for that piece of jargon, Mr Acting Deputy President, but the Reserve Bank of Australia has made that kind of jargon necessary nowadays because of its new capital ratio requirements. The report simply says on that:
As at 30 June 1989, the Group's risk-weighted capital ratio was 9.56% compared with 7.33% a year earlier. This is comfortably above the 8% ratio required by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

So I think one must say that all of that is very encouraging in terms of the present management and direction of the bank. But, in conclusion, just let me say that I am sure I do not utter any blinding flash of revelation for the bank's management in pointing out that all banks these days are more and more dependent on the growth of their capital base and the Commonwealth Bank, most of all of our four major banks in this country, is most handicapped in that regard. And while it is encouraging to see that the Commonwealth Bank Group's risk-weighted capital ratio at the end of June this year was comfortably above the requirement laid down by the Reserve Bank, nevertheless the bank would itself, I am sure, be the first to agree that that situation will not necessarily remain if the bank is to grow without at the same time being able to raise new capital in one way or another. Of course, the Opposition's policy in that regard for the privatisation of the bank provides the clear avenue for it to move out into the capital markets in its own right, in a way which it presently finds great difficulty in doing, and thereby to maintain its position-its proud position-within the Australian banking scene and to provide a future for all its many and highly professional employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise ever so briefly to record some comments in respect of this inquiry, and I do so as a not detached senator, but rather one who have the dubious distinction of being on the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which was inquiring into drugs in sport. It was as a result of evidence provided to the Committee that this reference was made to the Committee of Privileges. Mr Acting Deputy President, it relates essentially to evidence given to the Committee by one Miss Sue Howland, and action purported subsequently taken by Mr Greg Blood, following Miss Howland's evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to put two matters on the record. The first is that Miss Sue Howland-Suzanne Howland-appeared before the Committee on subpoena and not on a voluntary basis, and secondly, the evidence she gave to the Committee was on the basis of that subpoena and as a result of questions asked of her due to her attendance. Miss Howland produced at that hearing a laboratory result and the request for the test, and the findings of the laboratory result. The test was to find the testosterone/epitestosterone ratio of Miss Howland. It is a standard test that athletes take when they want to find whether they can cheat the system. It is a test they take to determine whether the ratio is within the acceptable limit so as not to have them test positive following a meet, and therefore to be disqualified.

Miss Howland had that done by a doctor at the Australian Institute of Sport, and paid for by taxpayers. Miss Howland provided evidence in respect of that document during the hearing of 1 December. Miss Howland was living at a home owned by Mr Greg Blood, an employee-in fact a librarian-of the Australian Institute of Sport. Following Miss Howland's evidence to the Committee and upon her returning home, she found herself with a note which read:

I'm afraid you will have to look for alternative accommodation as soon as possible. I'm sick and tired of the drugs in sport. You can say what you like, I can choose who lives in my house. It was a very hard decision to make.
It was on that basis that Miss Howland first contacted the Committee. One of the terms of the Privileges Committee was to inquire into interference with witnesses and it reads:

A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force or threat of any kind, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit of any kind, or by other improper means, influence another person in respect of any evidence given or to be given before the Senate or a committee, or induce another person to refrain from giving such evidence.

Mr Blood had made it clear to Miss Howland previously that if she gave evidence she would be required to leave his home. That reference was handed to the Committee. I do not propose, nor would it in my mind be proper, to reflect upon the findings of the Committee, but it did find that Mr Blood had not committed a contempt of the Committee. Notwithstanding that, Mr Blood's actions were ones which I would have thought were likely, by any measure, to influence the evidence of Miss Howland and weigh, to some extent, upon her mind in the level of evidence that she gave, particularly given that the evidence was by and large within her knowledge and nobody else's.

It is not unreasonable to say that Miss Sue Howland is not one easily intimidated. She is robust both in physique and character and unlikely, I would have thought, to be subject to any emotional duress from Mr Blood who, on the other hand, was found by the Committee to be a person timid in nature. He found himself under considerable stress. The Committee notes that he perceived a number of conflicts between loyalty to his friend and to his employer; his desire that there should be a free flow of information and that issues relating to drugs in sport should be resolved, on the one hand, and his fear that he might be implicated in the dissemination of the information in an atmosphere of tension; and his somewhat sensitive personality and a battle, not of his making, between a forceful personality and the organisation where he worked. It appears to the Committee that Mr Blood took the action he did in a state of stress and was motivated by a desire to obtain relief from the stressful situation in which he found himself. I think that that is absolutely right. But what was not examined, and the Committee would not have had the capacity to examine it, was what duress or influence was cast upon Mr Blood by the Australian Institute of Sport.

One of the difficulties I have in reading this report is when the Committee perceives the conflicts between loyalty to his friend and to his employer. Quite frankly, that should not have been a conflict to Mr Blood. The acceptance of one is not the rejection of the other. I would have thought that the Australian Institute of Sport-his employer-would have been, and to my knowledge it was, a willing participant in the inquiry. It ought not to have caused any stress or affliction upon Mr Blood to have somebody living in his home give evidence that did not necessarily reflect generously upon employees at the Institute. My understanding from evidence given by the Institute was that it was fastidious and diligent in its endeavours to ensure that if there were any wrongs at the Institute they would be put right, if there were any improprieties they would be rectified and if there were any faults they would be corrected. I raise this because there was a great deal of difficulty for the Committee in finding witnesses who felt unencumbered, uninhibited and free to give unqualified evidence before the Committee. So very often it was brought to our attention that athletes were subject to communication from their peers, from coaches and, on more than one occasion, from employees at the Institute of Sport when it became public knowledge that they were giving evidence to the Committee. Once it became public knowledge, those people, by way of those communications, invariably found themselves subject to one form of duress or another. Miss Howland found herself in that category.

While the Committee has completed much of its collection of evidence, there is some way yet to go. I hope the fact that this matter was taken with the seriousness with which it has been by the Committee will mean that future witnesses will feel free and discharged from duress in giving their evidence before the Committee, particularly that which is given by way of subpoena.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
