SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare entitled Sheep Husbandry, together with a transcript of evidence from this and earlier reports of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
The statement read as follows-

`Sheep Husbandry' is the fifth report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. It follows reports on live sheep exports, dolphins and whales in captivity, kangaroos, and animal experimentation. The Committee is currently inquiring into intensive livestock production and the animal welfare aspects of the racing industry.

In the initial spate of general submissions received by the Committee in 1984, a number of groups and individuals expressed their concern about certain practices associated with sheep production in Australia. In particular, the surgical procedures of castration and mulesing were highlighted as being inimical to sheep welfare. The adequacy of shelter for newly-shorn sheep and new-born lambs was questioned, as was the general level of supervision of sheep in the extensive environment. Other concerns were for the welfare of sheep following natural disasters. The desirability of raising sheep at all in the semi-arid zones was questioned on both welfare and ecological grounds.

From the many competing animal welfare issues brought to the attention of the Committee, the welfare of sheep was selected for investigation not only because of the concerns expressed above but also because of the fear that, in an industry as economically significant as that of sheep and wool, the best interests of the sheep might always come a poor second to economic considerations.

By inquiring into sheep husbandry issues, the Committee provided a forum for sheep producers and others involved in `using' sheep to meet and exchange views with animal welfare groups. As the Committee's inquiry progressed, each group came to accept that the other had some legitimate concerns. Producers acknowledged that some of their practices could be improved, while welfare groups acknowledged that some of their proposals were unreasonable. The Committee is heartened, however, to see that both sides are now prepared to engage in more constructive debate on the issues which still separate them.

In considering the basic needs of the sheep, particularly access to adequate nutrition, the Committee concludes that at least some of the sheep welfare problems in this regard stem from a lack of knowledge on the part of some producers of the nutritive value of their pastures. The Committee encourages State departments of agriculture to the more forthright in publicising their guidelines concerning the amount, quality and continuity of feed necessary to maintain sheep health and to meet the specific physiological requirements for growth, pregnancy, lacta- tion, cold stress and survival following natural disasters.

Protection from climatic extremes is another basic sheep welfare need, but one which is clearly not being satisfactorily met by at least some sheep producers. The Committee believes that all sheep producers must provide whatever form of shelter is suitable for their location-stands of trees, sheds, windbreaks, grass shelter belts or sheep coats. If sheep continue to suffer and die from the lack of adequate shelter, the producers who permit this to occur ought to be prosecuted under the relevant State prevention of cruelty to animals legislation.

The Committee is particularly concerned at the level of lamb losses in Australia. It recommends that the industry, together with the State departments of agriculture, develop lamb loss parameters for the common breeds of sheep in each district, as a minimum target at which producers should aim. It further recommends that research be continued into the most effective forms of shelter, on a regional basis, and that the results of that research be widely and promptly disseminated. Other research recommended by the Committee to enhance the survival chances of new-borne lambs includes work into the cost-benefits of using ultrasound imaging on ewes in early pregnancy, and into improving the mothering ability of Merino Ewes. Research into vaccines to promote fecundity should, the Committee believes, be linked to work on improving lamb survival rates.

After considering the practice of tail-docking lambs, the Committee concludes that it is probably a helpful management procedure, though one which should take place at an early age. The Committee, however, believes that no tails should be docked completely for aesthetic reasons.

Other surgical interventions appear to cause lambs a great deal of temporary distress. The Committee questions the need for the castration of ram lambs destined for early slaughter. It recommends continued research into alternatives, such as immunocastration.

The distress caused to sheep by flystrike is of major concern to the Committee, as are many of the prevention and control measures. The Committee particularly finds the practice of mulesing abhorrent, but accepts that it is, for the present, necessary. Clearly mulesing cannot be eliminated overnight without causing further suffering to sheep from flystrike. However, the Committee recommends continued research into all means of preventing blowfly strike, so that the need for mulesing is ultimately removed.

Faulty dentition usually results in the culling of the sheep concerned. The Committee was therefore interested to receive evidence on the practice of teeth grinding to rectify that fault. Research into the practice to date, however, has not produced demonstrable benefits for the treated sheep. The Committee considers that until such benefits are demonstrated, teeth grinding as a preventative measure for whole flocks should be discouraged.

Electro-immobilisation as a means of sheep restraint is viewed by the Committee with some disquiet. The Committee would prefer to see the development of innovative, less stressful restraint alternatives. In the meantime, the Committee urges that the technique be applied with caution until further research clarifies the stress parameters associated with its use, and whether or not it has an analgesic effect.

The Committee is supportive of recent innovations in sheep handling and marketing, which lessen the stresses associated with these practices. It particularly welcomes the advent of computer-aided livestock marketing which lessens the amount of movement sheep have to undergo, and eliminates the discomfort of saleyards and the additional travelling time.

The degree of supervision of Australian sheep raised extensively was the subject of considerable criticism before the Committee. The Committee is perhaps more concerned at the husbandry skills of the persons working in the sheep and wool industry, rather than their number, and supports calls for more training in behaviour-based skills in animal handling.

Changes to the traditional method of removing wool from sheep were viewed and considered by the Committee, given the costs and stresses of manual shearing. The Committee recommends that research be continued into both biological wool harvesting and robotic shearing, and in the short term, it recommends continued research into improving manual shearing practices.

The Committee considered the objectives of sheep breeders striving for improved performance from their flocks. Substantial progress can be made by rigorous conventional selection for desired characteristics, including welfare objectives such as resistance to fleece rot. The increasing tendency particularly of studs to favour artificial reproductive techniques, either artificial insemination or embryo transfer, leads the Committee to urge that the techniques are only performed by persons with appropriate qualifications.

Genetic engineering of sheep is still in the experimental phase. The Committee considers that genetic manipulation may hold great promise for sheep welfare, and as such, continued research into its applications should be supported. An imported proviso, however, is that the relevant ethics committees are satisfied with the research protocols.

The welfare of sheep during and after natural disasters is of considerable concern to the Committee. The 1982-83 drought brought about high levels of sheep losses, not all of which could have been avoided. The Committee is not of the opinion that drought relief subsidies are the answer to the problem. Such subsidies appear to have been operating inequitably and are potentially open to abuse. The Committee is particularly concerned at the ecological and welfare problems presented by overstocking, and recommends that guidelines be devised on conservation farming techniques.

In addition to considering the specific welfare issues raised, the Committee also addressed the question of what to do when breaches of acceptable welfare standards occur. Cases of gross cruelty or neglect are covered by State legislation dealing with prevention of cruelty to animals, but few prosecutions involving sheep ever reach the courts, partly because of the difficulty in defining what constitutes acceptable sheep husbandry.

The Committee remains unconvinced that industry self-regulation is working effectively. The few bad sheep producers are not being removed quickly enough for the good of the sheep. Appending codes of accepted sheep husbandry practice to legislation, as has been done in Victoria, results in more successful prosecutions. The Committee recommends that State governments increase the number of RSPCA inspectors authorised under the relevant State prevention of cruelty to animals legislation, to ensure that all complaints can be acted upon promptly.

In the view of the Committee, the only viable approach to achieve the well-being of sheep in the longer term is producer education. The sheep and wool industry must be more active in ensuring that its members act responsibly at all times. The Committee supports the continued development and regular review of codes of sheep husbandry practice at State and federal level, both as a means of bringing together all groups concerned with sheep welfare and as statements of considerable moral weight, whether or not they are appended to legislation.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay tribute to those who contributed to this inquiry and report. I particularly thank those who made submissions and gave evidence to the Committee. I thank my colleagues on the Committee, John Morris, the past Chairman, David Brownhill, Paul Calvert, Barney Cooney and Norm Sanders. Finally, the Committee expresses its appreciation to the secretariat staff involved in this inquiry-Paul Barsdell, Barbara Allan, Doug Hynd and Doris Pratezina.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second report in a very short time from the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I am very pleased to see that we are at last starting to get some reports tabled in the House. As with the previous report on animal experimentation, there is no dissenting report. The report has been agreed to by all members of the Committee. That in itself reflects the attitude not only of the Committee members but also of those people that gave evidence. Most of us know that Australians benefit very much from sheep raising in Australia, whether it be from the $6 billion per annum export earnings that we receive, from the wool, from the woollen suits and dresses that we wear or from the meat we eat. A well-known and well-worn saying for many years has been, `Australia rides on the sheep's back'.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years there have been, no doubt, many reports, papers and books written about sheep, but there are very few, if any, reports written about the actual welfare of the animal, questioning the husbandry practices that have evolved over the years in the industry. In chapter 1 there is a very concise history and outline of the industry which began, as far as Australia is concerned, in 1807 when Captain John Macarthur introduced 26 merino sheep from the Cape of Good Hope and thereby started the Australian wool industry. From that day on sheep and wool have become very big export earners for Australia, culminating in 1987-88 when the sheep and wool industry was Australia's largest single export earner.

When talking about the sheep and meat industry, though, we must remember that it survives in a very highly competitive market, with wool always under threat from synthetics and sheep meat always in very strong competition with beef, poultry and pork. Any changes in viability, therefore, could have a very profound effect on the sheep. With competition and rising costs always a threat to the industry, coupled with the vagaries of our climate, it is sometimes easy to forget the welfare of the animal itself.

The Committee pointed out in its previous report on the live sheep export trade that society has a duty to see that undue suffering is not caused to animals and that we cannot accept that the duty should be set aside in order that food may be produced more cheaply. Where unacceptable suffering can be eliminated only at extra cost, that cost should be borne or the product forgone. On the other hand, all methods of domestic livestock rearing entail some loss of freedom and where an imperfect, but not unacceptable, system can be improved only at a disproportionate cost, it may be unreasonable to insist that this be done.

Today, with more people living in suburbia questioning the practices that have never been questioned in the past, it was pleasing to see during the course of our inquiry that there was an airing of many different views. It was certainly pleasing to see the positive attitude that was adopted by all those who gave evidence. The bringing together of the views of the producers, the researchers, and those who have become violently opposed to some aspects of sheep husbandry was one of the major achievements of our Committee. Just as in the animal experimentation inquiry, the benefit of all sides putting their arguments publicly will be of immense benefit to the community as a whole. Producers were keen to hear the concerns from responsible animal welfare groups. Conversely, the same groups concerned with welfare issues acknowledged that some of their proposals were unreasonable and they were prepared to modify some of their approaches.

Without going into too much detail, I would like to comment on some of the major areas of concern. As a lot of sheep are bred to die at a young age, the main issue as far as the Committee was concerned was the quality of life and the care during the life span. The main requirements for sheep, as we all know, are good food, ample water and good husbandry techniques. Some of the main issues raised about husbandry were with regard to sheep losses, mulesing, transport and neglect of sheep. Whilst not denying that there are significant losses of newly shorn sheep and newborn lambs, during the evidence that was given to the Committee I must say that I was concerned at some of the quite obvious extravagant claims of losses that were made. I believe that some of them were based on quite false figures. But regardless of some of these doubtful claims, the evidence given certainly raised a great deal of concern about stock losses. Many of these losses are due to unpredictable weather. Nevertheless, there is no doubt in my mind that an adequate supply of shelter was a No. 1 priority. I certainly agree with our recommendation regarding an increased provision of shelter, combined with more investigation into breeding and lambing techniques, particularly with merino sheep.

A great deal of the report deals with lamb losses and lamb practices. The most vigorous debate occurred when we entered the areas of lamb marking and mulesing. A great deal of evidence was given on these matters. The Committee took the time to make on-farm inspections and investigate some of these practices. It is interesting to note the recommendations that were brought forward as a result. I quote from recommendation 10.11:
No sheep have its tail completely removed.

There was a reason for that. Some operators had been taking the tail completely off the animal, thus depriving it of something with which to keep the flies away, and also allowing that particular area to become sunburnt and therefore in some cases develop skin cancer. As far as the castrating of lambs was concerned, we recommended that there be continued research into immunocastration whereby the animals are actually castrated by the use of an injection.

When we looked at the area of mulesing, feelings started to run high. As a sheep producer, I find mulesing cruel and visually offensive, but when I compare it to the alternative of flystrike, reluctantly, I must say that mulesing, in the short term anyway, has to be accepted. I was pleased that one of our biggest critics of mulesing, Christine Townend, also reluctantly accepted that, in the short term anyway, mulesing was a practice that should be accepted. I think the Committee was heartened by the vast amount of research that seems to be going into the control of flystrike in particular, because flystrike is one of the biggest curses of the sheep industry. It costs the industry something like $1m a year. A great deal of time and effort is being put into trying to find alternative methods to mulesing. I am quite convinced, having spoken to the researchers, that in the next three or four years there will be a chemical means of mulesing sheep. Hopefully, practices such as mulesing will fade into the past.

We were also very impressed with the research into shearing. Of course, shearing is one of the major tasks of the sheep industry. Evidence was given on robotic shearing. We were also given quite a deal of evidence on the use of epidermal growth factor, a natural chemical produced by sheep that is used for defleecing the sheep. I believe that that particular method has a great future. However, like everything else, it still has a long way to go. In the meantime, we recommended that research be continued into alternatives to conventional shearing. We also recommended that research be continued into improvements to manual shearing.

Two other concerns were raised about sheep farming. One was the practice of raising sheep on marginal country. This is opening up another debate; it is not one that I will dwell on today because I believe it will be discussed in the soil degradation and environment debate. Certainly, evidence was given that sheep raised in some marginal country was likely to make such country more drought stricken than normal. There was also the effect of overgrazing of the land, which was a matter of personal concern to all of us.

Finally, I would like to touch on a matter which was not dealt with in the report, although it may have been touched on briefly, but which is of concern to me. I am concerned about the increasing number of hobby farmers in and around metropolitan areas. I believe that, in looking at the question of sheep husbandry and cruelty to sheep, that is one area in which the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) and other like organisations should be taking much more notice because there is a lot of evidence to show that many sheep are attacked and wounded or killed by dogs in these areas. There is a lot of evidence to suggest poor husbandry, because of little knowledge by the owners of flystrike, pizzle rot, lice and all those sorts of things that sheep become infested with; that the suburban sheep owners do not really know enough about the breeding or husbandry of sheep, nor do they have the facilities to look after them correctly. We end up with interbreeding of sheep and the straying of sheep and lambs all over the place. Quite honestly, I believe that this is an area that the RSPCA in particular should be looking at. I think our final recommendation was that State and Territory governments increase the number of RSPCA inspectors authorised under the relevant State prevention of cruelty to animals legislation and provide additional funding to support them.

I believe that this document, like the animal experimentation document, is a very professional report. It is put together very well, in a manner that is easy to understand. I believe that this report will become a very important reference document for those people interested in the welfare of sheep. I commend the attitude of all those concerned, including those who gave evidence, and particularly our staff for the amount of work put in by them, especially Paul Barsdell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. It is a good report. As Senator Calvert has said, it is a mine of information. The people who have put it together have done it in a very professional and competent manner.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to talk about mulesing, which caused me a lot of concern. I think we have to talk about what mulesing is. `Mulesing' is a nice word for a very brutal practice, which involves the taking of a flap of skin some five inches long and two or three inches wide from under the tail of a sheep with shears. The sheep is grabbed with the hand, a kind of a fold is created and the skin and attendant hair are cut away from the area. It is a brutal and bloody operation. We observed it in the field. Many of the animal welfare people have reacted violently against the technique because, as Senator Calvert has said, it is brutal. It should be replaced.

The unfortunate fact is, however, that the consequences of not mulesing-in other words, leaving the sheep with a matt of hair underneath the tail-is fly strike. The area is wet from urine and faeces, the flies lay their eggs in the area and then the eggs hatch. That causes far more distress to the sheep than mulesing. Can one imagine how it must feel to a sheep to have fly larvae actually growing within its flesh? That is what happens. The recommendation was -I believe this to be a very strong recommendation-that mulesing cease as soon as research has developed a way of stopping flystrike.

I think we all agree-Senator Calvert nods in agreement-that mulesing should cease. It was a very difficult decision for me because mulesing is a brutal operation, but flystrike is even harder on the animal in terms of animal welfare and animal suffering; therefore I did support the continued use of mulesing. But I urge everyone in the industry to heed our recommendations 10.13, 10.14 and 10.15. I am not going to bother to read them out here, but basically they concern the reduction of flystrike by breeding more resistant sheep, by research into biological control methods over flies and by chemical control methods. Mulesing should be eliminated forthwith and--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to replace it with?
—Senator Panizza has just come into the chamber.
—Yes, but I know a bit about the subject, which I don't think you do. They have been trying for the last 100 years to eliminate it.

—I wish the honourable senator had been here because if he had he would know that for once I really agree with him. I do agree that flystrike is a very important thing and I say that mulesing should continue until flystrike is eliminated. But once flystrike is eliminated, mulesing should then cease. I am going to conclude at this point because I know that the time of the Senate is valuable. But I really do not understand why Senator Panizza is carrying on in the way he is. I hope that he will in fact contribute to this debate because I would like to hear his expert views on mulesing and flystrike.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSIONER BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, we have had some difficulty getting a prolonged debate on this legislation because of other business before the Senate. But I remind the Committee and Senator Bolkus, who is sitting in for Senator Tate, that when this Bill was last brought on I was explaining the three legs to our concern over clause 226, which is the subject of our amendment No. 59. The first leg of our concern is the general question of the proper relationship between a Minister and his department and the officers of a statutory authority. I have explained that and will not repeat it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second and third legs of our concern relate to the particularities of the amendment proposed to clause 226 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. Very briefly, before lunch I set out some concerns we had about the first part of the amendment in the Bill-that is, the part that relates to the secrecy provision in which the Government seeks to amend section 23e of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act by providing that certain officers of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) be among those who are listed as having exemptions from certain secrecy provisions. I draw to the attention of the Minister and the Committee the curious anomaly which this seems to present which seems to highlight once again the very unusual relationship which will exist-I know that Senator Tate is coming back, so I may not have to repeat the whole argument-between the commissioners, who will not have the exemption and who will not be able to receive certain information, and some of their officers, who will have the exemption and will be able to receive the information. A very strange situation may arise where we may end up with officers of ATSIC having certain information which they can pass on to the Minister, if they are advising the Minister, but which they are not able to pass on to the commissioners who are in charge of the Commission because if they do they may render themselves liable to a fine or a term of imprisonment.

If I understood Senator Tate correctly in the 30 seconds he had before lunch, he indicated that there was another mechanism by which the commissioners could be so authorised. I put it to him that that mechanism would allow anyone to be authorised-it could allow the officers of ATSIC-but the Government has seen fit in this Bill actually to nominate certain officers of ATSIC. It has actually nominated the chief executive officer or a member of the staff of the Commission approved by the chief executive officer which we all understand is the standard way of delegating that authority to the officers of the Commission. I suggested that the Government might wish to include the commissioners themselves in those who are included here in order to avoid the anomaly which I have drawn to the attention of the Committee.

The rest of the Government's amendment contained in clause 226, however, seeks to put in a new section 64b relating to land council's trust funds. This is contained in subclause 226 (3) of the Bill before the Committee. There are two issues here. The proposal refers to a Minister administering the section. The question is: who is the Minister administering the section? The question then is, also, what law or arrangement is the new section 64b, which is sought to be added by the Government, to replace?

I will turn initially to the first question. Who is the Minister about whom we are talking? It seems that two Ministers are being talked about under this new section. One of them is apparently the Minister for Finance because the Minister for Finance must approve the form of the accounts; and the other is the Minister administering this section. I am aware that my colleague, Senator Tambling, who is in the chamber, was intrigued by this very distinction and he asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a question on notice. It is Question on Notice No. 1112. It has been placed on the Notice Paper and a response has been received. In order to expedite the work of the Committee I seek leave to have the question and the Prime Minister's reply incorporated in the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—I would like to have a look at it.
—It is just a question and answer. It is--
—I don't mean for the purpose of giving leave to incorporate it. I just mean I would like to see it.
—Of course. In fact, the attendants may wish to take a copy of it to make sure that the Minister gets a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT
IN THE SENATE
AND
MINISTER REPRESENTING THE PRIME
MINISTER
SENATE QUESTION
(Question No. 1112)
Senator Tambling asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 August 1989:

In the event of passage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989, and specifically, in the event of passage of clause 226 in the form now before the Senate, can the Prime Minister say:
(a) which Minister does he intend should be the `Minister administering this section'-that is, proposed section 64b of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976; and
(b) which Minister does he intend should be `the Minister' for purposes of sections of the Act, other than proposed section 64b.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) and (b) The expression `Minister administering this section' has been used in subsections 64b (2), (3) and (4) to distinguish that Minister from the Minister for Finance who is mentioned in subsection 64b (1). The intention is that `the Minister administering this section' will be `the Minister' referred to throughout the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The current Administrative Arrangements Order identifies that Minister as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears from the answer that the Minister administering this section and `the Minister', as we have used that phrase throughout the Bill, are to be one and the same person. The question is: why is it written in different language and why is there a difference in terminology? I turn to a more substantial matter about the proposed new section 64b. What is this section proposed to replace? It would require ATSIC to keep accounts and to prepare financial statements and annual reports in respect of the trust fund set up by section 62 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. As we all know, that is the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account (ABTA). Why is this section necessary at all?

SPEECH.PARA: I interpolate here that the Opposition amendment is simply to leave out the proposed amendments and the question we are asking is: why are they there? The secrecy provisions seem to us either to be unnecessary or to be clumsy, and we are now asking in relation to the trust fund amendments why the section is necessary. Presumably the trust fund accounts, in all the ways set out in this section, are handled by someone at the present time. Are they handled satisfactorily? If they are not handled satisfactorily, would you please tell us? Is there something wrong with the present arrangements? I feel obliged to remind the Committee that some recent newspaper articles have suggested that something might be wrong with the way in which the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account is being administered.

I remind honourable senators that the fund is used in three ways. It is used to fund the administrative costs of the land councils, to make grants to Aboriginals in the region, and the remainder is used for the benefit of Aboriginals generally and proportions of the royalties are supposed to be used for each of them. I also remind honourable senators that there is one exception: the Minister may use some of the money that would otherwise go to Aboriginals generally, through the ABTA, and if necessary provide that to the land councils if they have extra administrative costs. I seem to recall that when I was Minister I had to activate that process. I think that I put a very substantial amount of money from the ABTA into supporting land councils. I believe that the amount was $1.3m that year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a lot different now.

—That is the very point, Senator. It is a lot different now. I understand that in the last two years amounts of $4m and $5m have been transferred from the royalties, which might have been expected to benefit Aboriginals generally, and have been given via this mechanism to the land councils for their administrative costs. Further, I understand a report has been prepared by a Mr Greg Crough suggesting that something will have to be done if the land councils and the trust fund are to avoid bankruptcy. This is a very serious matter because the amounts of mining royalties have been quite substantial. Senator Tambling sought from the Minister some information about this report and asked whether, because of the interest we have in it, it could be made public. The Minister declined to make it public. What possible secrecy can there be about the fact that the trust fund is in trouble, is almost bereft of funds and, as we know from other sources, that is because large amounts of money have been channelled through this mechanism to the land councils?

SPEECH.PARA: We are aware that the Prime Minister has already conceded that a small departmental unit dealing with Aboriginal affairs will need to be retained. If that is the case, proposed section 226 is simply not necessary. The small administrative unit can continue to do the jobs for which this section provides. I do not understand the essentiality of anything contained in it and it is for that reason that the Opposition has proposed that we leave out the clause; in other words, vote against what is proposed by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might suit the convenience of the Committee if I responded at this stage. Other senators can supplement the points made by Senator Baume as they wish. In relation to the first matter-that is, whether there is some anomaly, as Senator Baume suggested, in the omission of the members of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission from the proposed paragraph (ba), obviously it was the desire of those drafting this legislation that those persons who might have permission, if you like, to receive this sort of information should be confined as stringently as possible. But I am quite happy to accept an amendment. In fact, I will circulate one to allow for paragraph (ba) to be rewritten to allow a member of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to be named in that list in paragraph (ba). Madam Chair, with your permission and the permission of the Committee, in relation to clause 226, lines 7 to 10, I would like to leave out proposed paragraph (ba) and insert the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: `` `(ba) to:
(i) a member of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission;
(ii) the Chief Executive Officer of that Commission; or
(iii) a member of the staff of that Commission approved by the Chief Executive Officer; or' ''.
I seek leave of the Committee to move that substituted paragraph.

TALK.START.PARA: —That should be foreshadowed; it should be moved in a few moments at an appropriate time.

—I will be guided by the Chair as to when to move it; I am just indicating the position to save unnecessary debate. I turn to the question of the way in which the Minister administering this section, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs under present administrative arrangements, shall be in a position to lay before the Houses of Parliament the report and financial statements required in relation to the trust account. The proposal that the Commission undertake the role of preparing the accounts and financial statements in the form that the Minister for Finance determines in relation to the ABTA is part of the general process which we have noted in section after section and which, indeed, lies at the base of the whole proposal encompassed in this legislation that responsibility for many matters in relation to Aboriginal affairs is to be taken over by the Commission from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: At present the Department, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901-I think it is section 41d, according to the note given to me-accounts for the payments made into and out of this trust account. It is intended that ATSIC will be required to prepare these accounts and financial statements and submit a report to the Minister relating to the trust account-and, of course, they have to be audited by the Auditor-General-before the Minister then lays a copy before the Houses of this Parliament. So it is simply part of the pro- cess which has been well rehearsed during the committee stage of this debate whereby the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will take on the roles and functions in many instances at present undertaken by the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume. As he alluded to in his comments with regard to this point, the issues and concerns that have been raised have come about largely because of the questions on notice that I have submitted to both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). There has been considerable media concentration in the past several weeks on the administration of the land councils in the Northern Territory and the operation of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. I do not want to take up much of the time of the Committee to canvass those issues in detail because I will have the opportunity in the Senate Estimates committee hearings in the next week or so to pursue and explore the past sins and the history of those particular areas in much more detail. In fact, that would be the far more appropriate place to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Peter Baume has pointed out, the concentration of attention on the activities of the land councils and their funding is of very serious importance to the function of the whole Parliament. I believe in the last 10 years $140m has passed through the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. The action taken in the last couple of years by Minister Hand in using his discretion for top-up funds for additional administrative purposes of the land councils has been very marked. Of course, this has taken place at the same time as the entire build-up and the selling of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal. This has created a great deal of controversy in the Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory. Anyone who has been closely following the media in the past few days will be very well aware that the former Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Mr Gerry Blitner, has taken very serious issue with the way in which the Land Council is currently being administered and the way in which Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account funds are being utilised under these discretionary powers.

I am concerned that the ATSIC legislation incorporates this administrative type function for the administration or the accounting of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account through ATSIC's books. Land councils operate under the auspices of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act of 1976 and they are specifically designated for the benefit of the Aborigines in the Northern Territory, whereas ATSIC is an umbrella organisation that has Commonwealth and Federal connotations. I have been fearful for some time about the influence of Aborigines outside the Northern Territory, particularly urban Aboriginals, who do not identify as easily with the traditional Aboriginal people who still live very largely a ceremonial and different lifestyle in the Northern Territory. Anyone who has been following the debates on ATSIC, or the precursors to those-the statements by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs since he brought down Foundations for the Future in 1987-will be well aware that I have continually expressed concern that the centralised functions of ATSIC will override many of the Government's intentions with regard to administration of funds for Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. The two are specifically distinct and I am very fearful that these provisions within the ATSIC legislation, which will, in effect, gobble up and tightly control-or could have the potential to very tightly control-the trust funds for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, will create a great deal of controversy and tension that is totally unnecessary and has many other political overtones.

As Senator Peter Baume said, I am concerned also that the Crough report has not been made public. It has been obvious, just from a careful reading of the Northern Territory News, that it has been available in some form to members of the media. It is obvious that they have access either to the document or to leaked parts of it. It has been commented on for some weeks. It has been made available to the land councils for their own administrative reasons. I fail to understand why members of parliament who have been so closely identified with the very radical change in administrative forms in the ATSIC proposals cannot be given the courtesy of access to this most important document. I am sure that Senator Coulter from the Australian Democrats needs to look at it and to study it comprehensively, just as Senator Peter Baume, Senator Ron Boswell and I need to be very intimately aware of the terms and the recommendations of it.

It has also been reported in the Northern Territory media that the Minister did not fully accept all of the recommendations of the Crough report and has in fact engaged a further consultant-I believe it is Dr or Professor Altman from the Australian National University-to prepare additional and further recommendations arising from the Crough report. This seems to imply either that there is continuing political pressure in this most important area or that things are being kept secret and quiet and swept under the carpet, which is totally unnecessary. Therefore, I believe that we have to be very careful with these issues. I certainly will be pursuing all of the financial implications of them in the forthcoming Estimates Committee hearings. For that reason, I have indicated to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, that I am hopeful that we will have present at the Senate Estimates committee hearings the officers responsible for the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account and officers from the land councils who will be so vitally affected by this legislation, to give us an account of how things are being done under the present arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue further what Senator Tambling has put before the Committee. He will pursue that in the Estimates committee, and so he should. There are a number of matters which require further attention. I observe to the Committee that the explanatory memorandum is quite misleading on this clause. For example, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 226 (3), would require the Commission to keep accounts, and to prepare financial statements and annual reports in respect of the Trust Account established . . .

It is not actually doing that. The accounts are already kept and financial statements are already prepared. It would have been rather more clear had the explanatory memorandum pointed out that the purpose of this subclause is to transfer that function from the Department which does it presently-I take it it is the Department-to the new Commission. That would have been a much clearer and more accurate explanation of what this clause is seeking to do with the addition of the proposed new subsection to section 64 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

Having said that, I make a couple of other observations. We have had divisions on the previous three clauses which dealt with legislation administered within the portfolio and we have lost those divisions. It is not my intention, therefore, to take this matter to a division. I am grateful to the Minister for having indicated that he will propose an amendment and at this stage I seek leave of the Committee to withdraw amendment No. 59 standing in the name of the Opposition.
Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.
Amendment (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
Page 87, paragraph 226 (2) (b), proposed paragraph 23e (3) (ba), lines 7 to 10, leave out the proposed paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (60) Page 38, after clause 88, insert the following new clause in Part 2:
Secrecy
