I am grateful to the Minister for his previous indication that this amendment will be acceptable to the Government. Therefore, I just make the observation that the ATSIC legislation, as it has been drafted and presented to us, has nowhere in it a section to protect the privacy of those who will be approaching ATSIC. We believe that ATSIC clients, just like clients of the Aboriginal Development Commission, are entitled to privacy relating to their personal affairs. Their privacy is not otherwise provided for in any adequate way in this legislation and it is for this reason that we have proposed to add new clause 88a after clause 88. One could argue about where it should be added but this seemed to us to be an appropriate place for it to go. In its contents it merely seeks to provide what are fairly standard protections for the privacy of those who will be dealing with ATSIC. I commend the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to indicate very briefly that the original provision was not drafted in a way which was unmindful of or indifferent to the matters of privacy which Senator Baume has spoken about. It was thought that obviously matters of commercial dealings with the Corporation needed to be treated confidentially. In relation to non-commercial activities it was not thought to be so necessary but I nevertheless take the points that Senator Baume has made. The Government can accept the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next group of amendments relates to regional councils and we have a number of major matters before the Committee. This matter is one which, if not a major one, is certainly slightly more substantial. We have proposed a number of amendments, I think, Nos 61 to 70. The Government has indicated that it can accept amendment Nos 61, 62 and 63. For that reason I seek the leave of the Committee to move amendments Nos 61, 62 and 63 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (61) Page 3, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation'', paragraph (c), lines 38 and 39, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph and words:
``(c) an Aboriginal association incorporated under Part IV of the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976;
but does not include a Regional Council;''.
(62) Page 40, paragraph 90 (2) (c), line 7, leave out ``may'', insert ``has the capacity to''.
(63) Page 41, clause 92, at end of clause, add the following new subclause:
``(2) Nothing in this section or in any other provision of this Act shall be read as conferring on a Regional Council a function of acquiring land except:
(a) for its administrative purposes; or
(b) for the purpose of the performance of functions expressly conferred on the Regional Council by this Act.''.

Amendment No. 61 seeks to leave out the definition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Corporation and to insert a new definition. The new definition would read, `an Aboriginal association incorporated under Part IV of the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976; but does not include a regional council'. Those are the words that matter. One of our concerns has been that, without this qualification, the Commission could declare each regional council to be an Aboriginal corporation. If this amendment is accepted, as the Minister for Justice has indicated it will be, that would not be possible. Had the Commission declared each or any of the regional councils to be an Aboriginal corporation such a council would thus have been eligible to receive property and grants of money for Aboriginal advancement purposes.

I think Senator Coulter set out for us last time we met his view of what the function of the regional councils was going to be. It certainly was not to be the recipient of grants from itself. Without this amendment to make that clear we have no such protection. Had this amendment not been passed and had the Commission declared the regional councils to be Aboriginal corporations, there would be a strong temptation for dominant factions to use the regional council itself as the vehicle for receiving grants rather than using genuine community organisations, especially if they were community organisations not at that time in favour with the dominant faction.

I remind the Committee that this is exactly the situation that arose in relation to the land councils in New South Wales. Similarly, the capacity of regional councils to receive and hold property, real and personal, would offer a temptation for them to develop into de facto Aboriginal land councils. Of course, that does not mean that it would occur, but it could occur. Amendment No. 63 merely seeks to identify the purposes for which a regional council might have power to acquire land. It states:
``(2) Nothing in this section or in any other provision of this Act shall be read as conferring on a Regional Council a function of acquiring land except-
and there are two exceptions-
(a) for its administrative purposes; or
(b) for the purposes of the performance of functions expressly conferred on the Regional Councils by this Act''.

Clearly, its own administrative purposes would involve buying an office or building from which it could operate, if that was what it wanted to do. The Aboriginal Development Commission, for example, purchased Bonner House. We would not want to stop that happening. So we want to make sure that it is written in that that is an appropriate purpose and that the other purposes for which land might be acquired should be for the performance of functions which are conferred by this Act. In other words, we have taken time already in considering this Bill to look very carefully at the functions which ATSIC should have. We are merely saying that the conferring of power on a regional council to acquire land should be consistent with those purposes. That is why we have moved amendments Nos 61, 62 and 63. I am grateful to the Government for the indication that these three amendments are acceptable and I commend them to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply indicate that the Government does accept these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (64a). Page 39, after subclause 89 (7), add the following new subclauses:
``(8) Subject to subsection (9), in determining the boundaries of the regions from time to time under this section, the Minister shall:
(a) as far as practicable, try to ensure that the number of persons who will be entitled to vote at the next Regional Council elections for each region will be equal; and

(b) subject to paragraph (a), try to ensure that persons with common interests or backgrounds, having regard to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander tribal and customary links, are included within the same region.
``(9) For the purposes of this section Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are each to be regarded as a single Regional Council.''.

This amendment to clause 89, which appears at page 39 of the Bill, seeks to insert a new subclause (8) after subclause (7). Clause 89 deals with regions under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal. The Committee will recall that we have already discussed at some length what shall be the regions and what functions they shall have, and we will have a bit more to say later about the voting practices within those regions. I have to remind the Committee that this chamber-it might not have been this particular chamber; it might have been the chamber which we occupied previously-when acting as the Senate considered a referendum proposal from the Government party which sought to make malapportionment of electorates illegal in the States of Australia, that is, the general electorates. In the argument on that referendum proposal both within the Parliament and in the community the question of malapportionment of constituencies was canvassed very widely. I notice that Senator Sheil is in the chamber. He will remember that the State which he represents and which Senator Jones represents was mentioned at some length in relation to that argument.

The Opposition puts to the Committee a very simple proposition. If it is sufficiently important to condemn malapportionment of electorates and if the Government itself is now proposing an electoral structure, why should that structure represent malapportionment of the gross degree that we have seen in the proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —What are we going to do about the Torres Strait?

—My colleague asks, `What are we going to do about the Torres Strait?'. I remind him that because of concerns which Senator Tate and Senator Boswell put in relation to Tasmania, which is Senator Tate's State, and the Torres Strait, which is part of Queensland, Senator Boswell's State, we altered the original amendment which we had circulated. Proposed subsection (9) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this section Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are each to be regarded as a single Regional Council.

I have gone ahead to respond to Senator Boswell's interjection in saying that that was a criticism of substance. If I am objecting to malapportionment and if we carried the proposal through it would not be possible for the Torres Strait to have a separate region or for Tasmania to have a separate region. For other considerations it is desirable that each of them should have a region.

We have rehearsed in this place already, and I will not do it tonight, some of the figures which show just how gross are the disparities between regions. I put a very simple proposition, the same as that which was put in the Senate when we were discussing the referendum Bill. Why should the vote of one person be worth a quarter of the vote of another person? This becomes important because we will repeat this argument in relation to zones. Under this Federal system, as it were-which ATSIC will be-the zones will each elect a commissioner and those commissioners will have equal votes on the Commission. I would like to think that they represented roughly equal numbers of electors. So what we are trying to do here is to ensure that, as far as practicable, the number of persons who will be entitled to vote at the next regional council in each region will be equal.

At the same time we have included a second leg which seeks to ask that, as far as possible, persons with common interests or backgrounds, having regard to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander tribal and customary links, be included within the same region. We have included that because of the many complaints that those of us on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs have received. Senator Collins gave us the striking example of a couple of communities in Arnhem Land where out-stations were separated from their home base-the out-stations being in one region, the home base in another. We want to avoid that happening if we can.

This amendment we are proposing, that is No. 64a-with the word `Island' having an `s' added to it-seeks to provide that, as far as practicable, there should be an equality of electors. After all, we are asking this of the Australian Labor Party, which has been the champion of the fight against malapportionment in non-Aboriginal constituencies. We are asking the Labor Party why the same principle cannot be applied within the ATSIC proposal, accepting the validity of the argument which Senator Tate put to me that Tasmania and the Torres Strait do present special cases which need to be provided for, as we have tried to do within the terms of the amendment. We have proposed the following words in our amendment:
For the purpose of this section Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are each to be regarded as a single Regional Council.
That is irrespective of the numbers of electors.

There are a number of other matters which need to be raised but I will raise just one of them here. The regions set out in the map we had in September 1988 have been shown to be deficient of any understanding of tribal or community boundaries and they have been shown to be grossly malapportioned. If honourable senators go to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, at pages 11, 16 and the following pages, they will see that argument set out. The Select Committee itself recommended some improvements-for example, the sliding scale as to how many regional councils would be elected. That was an improvement and the Government picked that up.

TALK.START.PARA: —A big improvement.

—A big improvement. As a member of the Select Committee, I thank Senator Tate. It was a big improvement. It is to the Government's credit that it picked that matter up, and I thank it for that. It has removed some of the greater excesses but it has not resolved the problem. It has helped things to this extent: the sliding scale means that the collegiate that meets for the zone elections might have a different weighting as between regions of different size. But we have proposed a new clause 89 (8) so the Minister would be required to follow principles of equal representation. I do not know of any convincing argument that says that a Labor government, which was prepared to ask the Australian people by way of constitutional change to entrench opposition to malapportionment for white Australians, should not put the same principle into a Bill in which it is seeking to provide representation for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. If there is a significant difference, we should be told what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I may need to raise other matters in relation to this amendment. But I indicate, in summing up, that we did listen to the points by the Minister a few days ago in discussion off stage. I think the main objection he raised was sufficiently important to try to overcome it by way of an amended amendment. I urge him to pick up equal representation as a principle and to accept this amendment which is offered in an attempt to overcome what was one of the grosser failings of the ATSIC legislation, as identified earlier this year by the Senate Select Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just briefly indicate that the fundamental difference between ATSIC-and, therefore, the electoral methods that might underpin its composition-and the Federal Parliament is, of course, that the Federal Parliament is a law-making power within society and has the capacity and exercises the ability to appropriate moneys. ATSIC is not vested with any power to make laws, nor is it a body which finally appropriates funds. That is done by this Parliament. I think there is a very significant difference between the two.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make this point: as far as the criteria which Senator Baume puts forward for determining the boundaries of the regions are concerned, the two exceptions or exemptions which he has made are, I think, in themselves eloquent rebuttal of what he says he is trying to achieve. He admits by those exceptions and exemptions from his general principle that there can be situations where homogeneity and likeness of communities are more important than the question of mere numerical equality between regions. It just simply happens that because Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are so clearly distinct, being islands or island groups, we fastened on to them in the discussion I held with Senator Peter Baume. But it may be that there are many other communities throughout Australia which would find themselves joined together quite artificially by the first criterion in Senator Baume's proposal in a way which would be as disastrous for them as it would be for the Torres Strait Islanders to be put into some huge region including Aboriginal persons.
Senator Baume's proposed clause 89 (9) says:
For the purposes of this section Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are each to be regarded as a single Regional Council.

I ask Senator Boswell: What will happen to Seisia, which he mentioned earlier, and to Bamaga which are on the mainland, as I understand it? They do not fit into this proposal at all. I think they would be most upset to find that they were to become part of a region and amalgamated with some Aboriginal communities rather than retaining their links with Torres Strait Islanders living on the Torres Strait Islands. So I do not think the amendment circulated by Senator Peter Baume really does justice even to the interests of the Torres Strait Islanders.

TALK.START.PARA: —It exempts them.

—It does not. It relates only to those people living on Torres Strait Islands, not Torres Strait Islanders living on the mainland in the Seisia and Bamaga communities, for example. I think that that is a major problem. I remind honourable senators of a statement made by a critic of the proposed ATSIC arrangements. I would like the Committee to hear this comment. It was to this effect:

SPEECH.PARA: The work of many people, many years of slogging, will be wiped out, all to satisfy Gerry Hand's socialist left philosophy that all power must be centralised in Canberra. His attitude is that the `bush murrays' have not got the ability to make a decision for themselves in their own communities. That is what ATSIC is all about. ATSIC denies Aboriginals their right to live in a secure community because it pushes various communities together in the same regional council which gets one voice at zonal level. This may lead to the dominance of the more articulate urban Aboriginals whose priorities may be quite different from those of community Aboriginals. For example, urban Aboriginals may be more interested in legal and health services while Aboriginals in the communities may see water, sewerage, housing and roads as their priorities. The basic issue here is how to get adequate representation for all without denying Aboriginal people their ethos of relating to the people and needs of their own communities.

That very profound insight was by Senator Ron Boswell in the debate on 17 August 1989. I put it to Senator Peter Baume that the amendments which he has circulated would have precisely the effect of creating a very unreal relationship between urban and some more traditional Aboriginal peoples by forcing them into one region in the name of seeking equality amongst the numbers of those entitled to vote in that regional council election. I admit that the list to which I now refer was made up before the new amendment was circulated during the last 24 hours, apparently. Let us say that the Aboriginal population of Australia is approximately 230,000. Therefore, each region would comprise about 3,800 if all were of equal size. On this basis we would see the following arrangements for regions: Sydney metropolitan would get four regions; Melbourne would get two regions; Brisbane, four regions; Perth, three regions; Darwin, two regions; Adelaide, two regions; Townsville, three regions; and Rockhampton, two regions. That would give a total number of urban based regions of 22, whereas at present the metropolitan centres would account for eight regions.

I indicate to Senator Baume that the effect of his proposal would be to fulfil the fears that Senator Tambling and Senator Boswell have raised-that one might have an undue overall dominance of the urban Aboriginal communities in relation to the voice of the traditional Aboriginal communities. Within regions, one could have a swamping of the traditional communities by urban Aboriginals who were brought within their region in the name of this equality. So the Government does not accept the newly circulated amendment. I cannot believe that, in their heart of hearts, either Senator Boswell or Senator Tambling could support this proposal. Even if they were minded to, in relation to the Torres Strait Islanders-who must be of great concern to Senator Boswell, who I know has a very real affection for and understanding of these people-I do not believe that the amendment as circulated deals with their communities which live on the mainland of the Australian continent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin by picking up proposed new subclause (9) in Senator Peter Baume's amendment, and point out to him that the clause as circulated is not worded correctly. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purpose of this section, Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are each to be regarded as a single Regional Council.

Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands are geographic descriptions of places. It would need to be reworded that they are to be regarded as single regions, each electing one regional council, to put it in the appropriate form. What he said does not really make sense.

Having said that, the Australian Democrats cannot support this series of amendments for slightly different reasons from those outlined by Senator Tate. We do accept that as far as possible the principle of one vote one value should obtain. As Senator Baume will recall, in the Senate Select Committee I argued for that. Indeed, I think I helped to propose the recommendation of the Committee that the size of the regional councils be determined on a sliding scale to take account of the differing population of the regions.

Recognising that it is impossible to achieve more than that relatively modest improvement in equality of representation, I also sought to include the provision that the regional councils, as part of their duty during their first term in office, would have the responsibility of reviewing their electoral boundaries and processes and that each regional council would make a recommendation to the Minister in relation to both of those matters. The Minister would also-this is now written into the legislation-consult with the Australian Electoral Commission and have two sources of advice on all those matters which, amalgamated, would synthesise the concerns that Senator Tate has correctly enunciated about the cultural similarities that bind together certain groups and which may determine that one group is small and another group is larger, and over the boundaries in that relationship, also taking into account the appropriate forms of representation-the size of the regional councils and the electoral processes.

I firmly believe, as I have indicated in this Committee debate before, that it is impossible at this stage going into a new structure to adequately foretell exactly how this thing will work out. In this area more than any other, the appropriate mechanism is to get it as good as possible in terms of commonality of spiritual and cultural background and equality of representation, and then, having created that mechanism, hand it over to the Aboriginal people themselves through their regional councils, so that they can then take this matter forward and make modifications as they go along.

I do not believe that at this stage we can go any further than the Government has already been prepared to go in modifying the size of the regional councils. It does seem to me that in Senator Baume's proposal, even with the changed wording in relation to Tasmania and the Torres Strait Islands, he has already recognised that there are in those instances smaller groups that will need special consideration. I have discussed with a lot of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the way in which Torres Strait Islander people on the mainland-that means the bulk of Torres Strait Islanders-fit in. Should they vote back with their Torres Strait Islander regional council? The answer universally by the indigenous Torres Strait Islanders is, `No. We do not want them to vote with us. We would be swamped by those people, some of whom have been away for one or two generations'.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a couple of generations.

—They could have been away for a couple of generations; precisely. On the other hand, the provision of a special grouping on the mainland for those people is not very satisfactory. I was quite taken by Senator Tate's analogy with islands on the mainland. It is an analogy that I have previously made in a different context when we were attempting to get certain desert areas in Australia set aside as world conservation zones. I pointed out that the Galapagos Islands are important from the point of view of the conservation of species that have evolved surrounded by water. In many of the inner areas of Australia there are islands of population, islands of unique life surrounded by large areas of desert. In the same sense, they are islands. I think that the anomaly which is created by juxtaposing those provisions which Senator Baume is attempting to put into subclauses (8) and (9) simply indicates that we should be leaving this with the newly created regional councils. Let them determine how they want their boundaries organised in future, the size of the regional councils and the electoral processes. I think that that is as far as we can go at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will leave this place extensively amended and it will be up to the Minister in the other place to determine what he wants to do with it. I say to Senator Coulter that one more amendment or one less amendment is not the issue. The legislation will pass or fail on the will of the Government to see it through in another place and to bring it back if necessary. It is all very well for Senator Coulter to say that he accepts the principle of one vote one value, but we are going to give him an opportunity to vote for it. If he votes against it, I will not believe him. He says that he believes in one vote one value. It is a classic situation because when people are put to the test, they always find reasons not to vote for a matter.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Tate has offered us are the classic arguments given by those who have proposed malapportionment down through the ages, that is, that the electoral interests or electoral rights of certain people, usually urban people, have to be subordinated for some reason because there are some other purposes, some special social purposes so that, in fact, one group of Aboriginals, whom Senator Tate and I think Senator Coulter identified as traditional Aboriginals, should have an influence out of proportion to their voting numbers.

I will explain why it is necessary to look at this amendment. We are talking about a federal structure at the top of which will be elected commissioners-whatever the figure may be; 15 or whatever. One will be elected from each zone. Those commissioners sitting in the Commission will have one vote each. They will be equal votes, if I may say so without outraging my friend. It reminds me of a State parliament I know where there is one vote for each parliamentarian. That applies in many parliaments; not just in one. The fact is that those commissioners will be making decisions. Of course, they will not be passing laws and appropriating money. Who ever suggested that they would? What they will be doing is making decisions about budgets and the sharing of resources. They will be making day-to-day decisions which will affect people in the communities in a hundred ways. Does anyone deny that? Of course the commissioners will be doing that.

For them to have legitimacy it is desirable and necessary that their election be fair. I cannot believe that we are hearing a Labor government say that it wants malapportionment of the degree that exists between the regions as proposed in this Bill. I am not at all surprised at the Australian Democrats saying, `We believe in one vote one value but we will not vote for it'. But for the Australian Labor Party to say, `We will have one region with fewer than 1,000 electors and one region with 17,000 or 18,000 electors'-if we are prepared to put up with that and the regional councillors are so elected, whether on a sliding scale and there are 10 or 20 regional councillors-does not get rid of the effects of malapportionment. They will then meet as a college to elect one zone commissioner. That is unfair and it is the very reason the honourable senator proposed a referendum a couple of years ago. He thinks it is unfair too. It is unfair for whites but good enough for blacks. I do not understand how a Labor Party, which asked us to vote at a referendum to end malapportionment, can then put malapportionment of this extent into the ATSIC proposal and argue that it does not want to do anything about it.

I take full responsibility for the amendment; it is defective. The Minister has pointed that out. Clearly, it would have to take account of the mainland communities that belong to the Torres Strait, and they include Bamaga and Seisia. I notice Parliamentary Counsel is sitting there advising the Minister. There is no reason why, if the amendment is defective, we could not seek to have that defect corrected if an acceptance of this proposal about malapportionment was what was standing between us. This is a proposal to put something of an end to the malapportionment. The argument that urban people are in some way entitled to less voting power than others is something that I, as an urban dweller, have always found highly offensive. The problem arises for people on this side of the chamber because ATSIC itself is such a hopeless, flawed proposal. That is really where the trouble arises. What we are seeing now is one of the consequences of that proposal.

Labor's fault, Labor's error, is in going down this road and seeking to put together an administrative structure and an elected structure to try, as it were, to provide an heir to the National Aboriginal Conference, at the same time as it provides an administrative structure to take over the functions of the other portfolio agencies. It will not work and we are seeing just one area in which it is unfair and improper. Senator Tate has actually been defending, with the thinnest arguments, inequalities between voting regions which are greater than those we see for any State parliament, any constituency. When we understand that those councils will meet together to elect a zone commissioner and that those commissioners will meet as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission to make decisions about resources, the consequences of malapportionment become severe indeed.

I say to the Minister that if in fact the defect in my amendment-that is, that Bamaga and Seisia are not included-needs to be overcome I am perfectly content to seek, through him, help to overcome it. I have no more wish than he has to see that defect persisted with. What I am inviting the Committee to do is to make a declaration on malapportionment. The Opposition will press the amendment. We will watch how senators vote. We believe this is a chance for the Committee to make a statement about where it stands on malapportionment. I know where I have always stood and, before the Minister says anything, he might check the Journals of the Senate as to where I have always stood.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not doubt that for a moment.

—I have always had a very clear view about the morality of this matter and I believe ATSIC is deficient in the morality, in the drafting and in the solution it has found as between the size of the regions. We are trying to do something to correct it and I commend the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not doubt for one moment the sincerity of Senator Peter Baume's general political philosophy in relation to the question of one vote one value. But I do remind the Committee that he has already accepted that in relation to this ATSIC legislation there ought to be two quite significant exceptions in relation to the island of Tasmania and now the communities of Torres Strait Islanders. I understand Senator Coulter is not going to support the amendment; so I have not asked Parliamentary Counsel to deal with the question of the mainland communities of Torres Strait Islanders. But I wonder whether I had mentioned in my conversation the question of Bathurst and Melville Islands where there is a community of about 1,600 people. Under Senator Baume's proposal they would be required to be amalgamated and forcibly integrated into a region within the mainland Northern Territory. I wonder whether he might not have thought that that also, for purposes of cultural homogeneity, required an exemption to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am trying to say-and I take Senator Coulter's point-is that the proposed boundaries may require revision. Experience will teach us that, no doubt. But they have been put together in good faith in order to achieve the sort of cultural homogeneity which the Committee set up by this Senate apparently thought was important. I remind Senator Baume that the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, of which the members were Senator McMullan, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Boswell, Senator Collins, Senator Coulter and Senator Devlin, obviously spent some time on the question of voting strength within regions. It concluded on page 40, paragraph 2.118:

Where regions are created in the interests of achieving cultural unity and the resulting regions have small populations the disparity in representation (voters per councillor) could be addressed by linking the number of councillors to the population of the region.
The following paragraph states:

The Committee recommends that regions with populations of less than 1000 elect ten Councillors, those between 1000 and 2000 elect eleven Councillors with one additional Councillor for each thousand of population until those with more than 10,000 voters have Councils of twenty councillors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you accept a brief intervention? At no stage did I forgo our right to move an amendment to the Bill on this matter.

—Of course not, but I cannot read a dissent from that particular recommendation in the body of the report. I am not trying to be half smart; I am just saying that the Senate Select Committee did address this matter. Three of the persons sitting on that Committee are in this chamber, and they thought that at this stage of the development of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal that was the best that could be achieved having regard to the interests of achieving cultural unity in the various regions. For that reason, I believe that we should take Senator Coulter's advice and await the experience that we have over the next several years of the operation of these councils. No doubt that will enable us to pick up some of the anomalies which will inevitably develop. But I believe that they will not be anywhere near as disruptive and in many cases as truly divisive as would be the case if we attempted to amalgamate various communities in the way in which Senator Baume's proposal would require.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one brief point in answer to Senator Peter Baume's assertion that the Australian Democrats are not committed to equality of representation. In this matter we have two important principles. Those two principles are partly in conflict. There is a very fundamental mathematical principle that one cannot optimise two independent variables simultaneously. One cannot optimise the representational aspects which we are dealing with and at the same time optimise the cultural aspects. One therefore must make a judgment and come down with a compromise. The point that Senator Baume is making also relates to the representation of the councils when it comes to the election of the zonal representative. That is the point at which the malapportionment occurs.
—At which it becomes significant, really.

—At which it becomes significant. The population size of the individual zones is therefore perhaps of more relevance when one moves up to the next stage, which is the commission stage. The variation in terms of the size of the regional councils will not really matter at the level of the operation of a regional council; it will matter only when representatives of those councils come together to select the zonal representative.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, I am not demurring at all from the importance of equality of representation. I believe that what we have in the Bill will take that into account by way of the opinions and advice which will be expressed by the Australian Electoral Commission when it advises the Minister in relation to boundaries and electoral processes. But here we do have two principles. One of those principles with respect to Aboriginal people is somewhat different from what operates in the non-Aboriginal community. There are very significant cultural differences between Aboriginal people-between people of one tribe and another, between urban and non-urban Aboriginal people, between people who are still observing more closely their traditional cultural heritage and those who have, for various reasons, moved away from that cultural background.

Senator Peter Baume will remember that in the Northern Territory the original division of regional councils was strongly objected to by a number of Aboriginal people precisely because the boundaries had not been drawn in ways which reflected the traditional boundaries, the recognised boundaries. If any proposal is to work at all and impose, even in a quasi fashion, a non-European electoral process and decision-making process on Aboriginal people, again I say that I think we have the best initial compromise and it is up to the Aboriginal people, through this mechanism, to determine how they want this to evolve over time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the regional councils of ATSIC. I want to make it very clear that the Islander communities of Bamaga and Seisia were established on the mainland of Cape York Peninsula when Saibai Island went under water in a tidal wave in 1949. These communities see themselves as Islanders rather than Aboriginals. They are part of the Island Coordinating Council, a body funded by the Queensland Government, and I believe also funded to some extent by the Federal Government. I made representations in the Senate earlier when these communities were not on the map. I believe the new map has picked them up and I have been issued with a list of communities that are in the Torres Strait Regional Council area.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it very clear that the Islander people initially were so annoyed about ATSIC that they even took the massive step of trying to remove the islands from Australia. They had various meetings seeking secession from Australia. The fact that they now have this regional council and a zone has appeased them to some degree, although I would say that some of them still are not happy about the whole prospect of ATSIC. Initially they wanted their own separate commission. They did not want to be a minority of a minority. I put it on record that most of them are not happy about the ATSIC proposal. But we have gone some way towards lessening their unhappiness by allowing the Torres Strait communities, both on the mainland and in the islands, to become a regional council and have their own zone. I am concerned about the list I have been given. I believe that a community is missing from this Torres Strait regional council area-that is, Port Kennedy. Maybe the Minister can--

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly is intended to be included, I am advised. I am sorry that it was inadvertently left off the printed list you have been given.
—I know that the Minister and Senator Peter Baume are keen to have a vote before the adjournment of the Senate; so I will conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond to Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter said that his objections to our amendment No. 64a is that it attempts to deal with two matters. I remind Senator Coulter that our amendment No. 70a will be discussed when we look at zones. I take it from Senator Coulter's remarks that he is more amenable to the idea of equality of electors in relation to zones and I will remind him of that when we get to the question of zones. I commend the amendment which we have moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 7.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
