DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Cricket: City of Canberra Trophy-Nurrungar-ANZUS Treaty-Kakadu National Park

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to inform the Senate of a very exciting new trophy for cricket. Honourable senators in this place will know of my interest in things to do with sport and, in particular, my interest in women's sport. I was very pleased to be informed that last week an announcement was made about the Chief Minister's City of Canberra trophy, a new cricket trophy for under 19 men and under 21 women in the Australian Capital Territory. This is a very exciting and significant award. The inspiration for the trophy was the cricket ball that was used in the historic fifth test played in England this year and flown to Australia on the record-breaking flight of the Qantas 747-400 Longreach aircraft called the City of Canberra. That trophy was presented to the Chief Minister by the area manager of Qantas Airways Ltd. The Chief Minister has decided that this would make a splendid perpetual trophy for both men's and women's cricket. A copy of the trophy will be presented to the best all-round player in the under 19 men's competition and the best all-round player in under 21 women's cricket. In addition to receiving a trophy, the young cricketers will be given a return trip by Qantas to England where it is hoped that they will be given the opportunity to have some cricket practice, if not participate in games.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons I have raised this matter in the Senate is that I am very pleased to see this further acknowledgment of sport and, in particular, cricket and, of course, women's cricket which has actually been alive and well in this country for over a hundred years. Indeed, the game played between the Australian and English teams in Bendigo commemorated 100 years of women's cricket in Bendigo itself. And, of course, over this last five or seven years, we have seen quite a different media coverage and recognition of the importance of women's sport. The early cricket matches between English women and Australian women in 1985 received mocking press reports. But by the time they got to the final match in Bendigo, on which the series hinged, the reportage was very different and was no longer mocking of women's cricket.

We have had to recover and rediscover the significance and importance of women's sport in this country. This award, this prize, is very important because it gives equal recognition to women involved in cricket and it also associates them in some way with the recent significant victory by Australia in the Ashes series in England. This is not a bad thing to be associated with if one is a young male or female cricketer in this country.

I think it would have to be said that the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) award would be one of the richest sporting awards for cricket in the country. It is a very significant prize and I believe that the sponsors associated with the trophy-in particular Qantas and WIN television in the ACT-need to be congratulated. It is also hoped that this prize or trophy for under 21 women cricketers will lead to the development of cricket for girls of school age. The majority of women do not get much opportunity at school to participate in cricket and develop their skills from an early age. But with an award like this for under 21 women and men, hopefully young girls and men, if not all around Australia at least in the ACT, will be encouraged to take up cricket along with all the other sports they seem to be enjoying more and more.

I wanted to draw this very commendable prize to the attention of the Senate. The Australian Capital Territory Cricket Association Inc. and the Australian Capital Territory Women's Cricket Association, in collaboration with the sponsors and the Chief Minister, Rosemary Follett, are to be commended for this contribution to both men's and women's sport, and cricket in particular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to outline some of the issues that the Senate was denied the opportunity to debate yesterday by the extraordinary actions of the major parties. The Opposition has blamed the Government for what happened, but it was Opposition senators who persisted in calling for a quorum in an attempt to disrupt Senator Jenkins's speech yesterday. The protests that occurred at Nurrungar and the protests that occur when nuclear-armed ships enter our ports--

—I take a point of order. Senator Dunn has reflected upon the use by the Opposition of provisions within Standing Orders and has implied a motive which is quite divorced from the truth. I ask that she be asked to withdraw.
—I do not think at this stage that there is any substance to the point of order but I shall listen carefully.

—The protests that occurred at Nurrungar and the protests that occur when nuclear-armed ships enter our ports would not be necessary if our governments did not persist in maintaining our historically ill-motivated and militarily useless alliance with the United States (US). Since the Second World War a mainstay of our official defence policy has been the relationship with the United States that is usually referred to by the title of the most substantial agreement between our two countries-the ANZUS Treaty-although its terms do not prescribe the whole of our current relationship with the United States. The other elements of the relationship are usually described as deriving from our membership of the larger and rather nebulous Western alliance. I believe that we can do without ANZUS and the other obligations that are generally associated with this treaty. I believe that we never needed it and that it is essential for Australia to disentangle itself from ANZUS as expeditiously as possible. The costs of this involvement have been and continue to be high and the benefits are few.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer briefly to the genesis of the ANZUS Treaty because its origin illustrates some of the problems that the treaty still presents. At this point I recommend a paper that I have found very helpful in clarifying my views on the treaty. It is titled Breaking the American Alliance and it is by one of our own parliamentary researchers, Gary Brown. I suggest that senators who are currently supporters of ANZUS should not be put off by the title because it is a thorough and scholarly work. ANZUS is our fault. Australia-which then meant Menzies-practically begged the United States for some sort of security guarantee when it failed to persuade Britain and the United States to impose a hard Versailles type of peace treaty on Japan.

When the treaty was announced in 1951, it was of considerable help to the Menzies Government in a general election. This was no accident. John Foster Dulles in Washington had been informed by Australian Foreign Minister Percy Spender that there was a strong risk that Labor leader Evatt would topple the Menzies Government by playing on public fears of a resurgent Japan. This argument overcame the reluctance of the United States authorities to offer any kind of treaty and it issued a statement of intent 10 days before the 1951 election. The recorded statements of Dulles clearly show a deep suspicion of any government-or possible government-with Labor or socialist or even peace associations. This attitude has persisted right up to the present. At a defence conference last year our distinguished former Ambassador for Disarmament, Richard Butler, described his initial reception in Washington by senior United States officials. They regarded him as if he were a reptile that had just crawled out of a bog in the Russian steppes. The convenient release of the embryonic ANZUS Treaty just days before a close Federal election was only the first instance of our military treaty relationship with the United States interfering directly with Australia's domestic politics and sovereignty.

There have been many costs, as I have said, incurred by this treaty. The most notable has to be Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war. Like many other Australians I opposed our involvement in this war; it cost Australia directly hundreds of millions of dollars and nearly 500 lives. It also cost us a part of our international reputation and associated us with not only the carnage of the war itself, but also the bloody aftermath-especially in Cambodia-and the long term social, economic and environmental damage to the region. It was a tragic but also very silly war. Australia was not needed militarily but because our pseudo-independence gave a superficial international gloss of `free world against the evil empire of communism' to the conflict. The silliness of the war in military terms is demonstrated by the fact that the United States-despite its material power-lost the war. So much lost, so much ruined, for nothing. The vacuous predictions of the domino theory came to nothing too.

From the beginning the ANZUS Treaty was used to justify a run-down in the Australian defence forces and the forces we did maintain were tailored to fit into United States priorities. Major expense is still being incurred in exercises directed towards United States rather than Australian needs. This has left Australia at the mercy of a treaty which places no obligations on the United States except to consult. It has also deprived Australia of the opportunity to choose military options in its own region. The annexation of Irian Jaya, then known as Dutch New Guinea, and East Timor are cases in point.

When Sukarno started to agitate for the `return' of Dutch New Guinea, Australia was opposed to it, but it could get neither British nor US support. Without that guaranteed support-even in munitions supplies-Australia could not even use the military option as a bargaining counter. I do not assert that Australia ought to have gone to war over this issue, but the division of the island of New Guinea and the assimilation of the people in the western portion into an empire defined by an accident of colonial history has caused trouble and will continue to do so.

The situation was similar in East Timor. Although the Indonesia of today is in some respects different from Sukarno's Indonesia, change for the worse is certainly possible. If a militaristic, expansionist group were to seize power there the evidence of recent history would show two successful annexations in the face of international and Australian disapproval. This might well be an encouragement to fresh military adventures.

Australia's future role in the South Pacific may well present some difficult problems. Foresight and delicacy are needed in our dealings with our neighbours. We need to make our own decisions about our region. The evidence shows that the US regards Australia and the nations of the South Pacific as little more than a sideshow. Three examples illustrate this point rather well. The first is the failure of Australia and South Pacific nations to persuade the US Government to control the rapacity of the American fishing fleets in the Pacific. Gary Brown observes in his book that the US Tuna Boat Association seemed to have more influence with its government than Australia and the South Pacific nations combined. Only when tiny Kiribati signed a fishing agreement with the Soviet Union did the US take action.

The second example is the two reactions to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. When the news of the treaty was received in Washington, State Department spokesman Bernard Kalb regarded the treaty as a big joke at a widely reported and televised media conference. When it came time to make an official response the US appeared to have changed its mind about this funny, ineffectual treaty. Despite Australia's efforts to make the treaty acceptable to the US, it has not signed it. The third example is the total lack of response to our efforts to gain US support in persuading France to stop its nuclear testing in the Pacific. France is not an ally of the US, only a friend; but maintaining a good relationship with France is obviously more important to the US.

The Australian Government has made much of Australia's benign influence on the United States in disarmament matters. There are no visible signs of this influence in the above examples and I have not yet mentioned one of the most galling aspects of the recent United States-Australia relationship, and that is trade.

Japan is the notable winner in the economic competition between nations that sometimes takes on the appearance of a war. Although there are justified complaints that Japan is not always playing on a level playing field, the intrusion of the United States into Australian wheat markets is something else altogether. The use of subsidies of up to 50 per cent to take over traditional Australian markets is the economic equivalent of using chemical weapons. Australia's protests about this intrusion-and blatant betrayal of free-trade principles-have been dismissed with specious arguments. The annual loss to Australia is estimated at about $1.3 billion. Coincidentally, our defence purchase outlays for 1986-87 were also $1.3 billion. Most of it went to-guess where?-the United States.

Predictable protests about the wheat trade and other United States offences against fair trading have come from the farming community. But the linkage of the trade issue with the bases reveals something about the perceived value of the alliance in a relatively conservative section of our community. Mr Ian McLachlan, who has been associated with the far Right and was being groomed for a high position in the coalition's parliamentary party, said:
When friends like the United States are prepared to crucify you economically, what confidence can we have that they will defend us in time of military threat?

The answer to Mr McLachlan's question is implicit; we can have no confidence. There were calls to threaten the United States on the trade issue by withdrawing one or more of the leases on the so-called joint facilities. Government Ministers and spokesmen uttered a few vague squeaky threats but shut up when the United States responded with some irritation.

The option to threaten the United States by closing the bases has been made more difficult by the extension last year of the leases on Pine Gap and North West Cape-effectively for 10 years. I was dismayed and perplexed by this move. I still do not know what inducement or threat was offered by the United States to persuade our Government to extend the lease and sacrifice a negotiating advantage. When I examined the text of the new lease agreement I realised that it had the same barely-altered, composed-in-Washington character as the Australian statement dictated by George Shultz to Bill Hayden in 1983 after the fuss about the refusal to dry-dock HMS Invincible.

Despite cosmetic changes to the title of the US facilities, they perform the same basic function that they always have-that is, to give the US the capability to fight and win a nuclear war. This capability is constantly being updated. One of the latest additions is the defence support program satellite system for which Nurrungar is the principal overseas ground station. US generals are on record describing how crucial this system is to their state-of-the-art nuclear war-fighting system. There is no doubt that these facilities are primary Soviet nuclear targets and we actually have safety plans for a nuclear attack on Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape. This information was conveyed to me by Major-General Howard of the Natural Disasters Organisation late last year.

The much vaunted arms control verification function of the bases is only a by-product of their more sinister nuclear war-fighting and war-winning function. Mr Hawke in particular has made much of the verification function of the bases, including claiming that the intermediate-range nuclear force treaty could not have been signed, nor the strategic arms reduction talks begun, without the bases being on Australian soil. Professor Desmond Ball-who is likely to know-describes these claims as hyperbole. Most of the really important advances in verification are taking place overseas-like the agreements to allow inspection teams access to missile dismantling and to certain factories.

In 1984 both the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Hayden made strong statements on Australia's policy on nuclear war and strategy. They specifically rejected the concept of `limited' or `theatre' nuclear war but affirmed Australia's reluctant support for deterrence along the lines of `mutual assured destruction'-usually correctly described as MAD. Some well-informed authorities claim that MAD was never really even an official US policy; the emphasis of both sides in the nuclear stand-off has been on surviving and winning a nuclear war. Attempts at making an independent Australian policy statement on nuclear war are folly when we are in thrall to a self-willed superpower that pursues its nuclear war strategy through the bases we have allowed on our territory.

Although the bases are an affront to many Australians and although they do make Australia a nuclear target, the installations themselves are remote from most of the population. Nuclear weapons will only turn up there-briefly-if there is a major nuclear conflict. The nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed warships that enter our harbours are another matter entirely. Although the United States and the United Kingdom refuse to declare whether any individual warship is carrying nuclear weapons we have a pretty fair idea of both the presence and the number of weapons on visiting warships. Before carrying these weapons, warships and their crews have to go through a process of certification. This process is not particularly secret and similar vessels tend to carry the same weapon loads. We also have evidence that certified ships nearly always carry all their nuclear weapons.

One important fact about the nuclear weapons that come into our harbours is that they are all tactical weapons-designed for fighting the limited or theatre wars that Mr Hayden rejected so emphatically--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not want in any way to prevent Senator Dunn from completing her remarks, but I was wondering whether, if in fact it was a written text, she would care to incorporate her speech in Hansard. The debate is not being broadcast and I think it would probably suit her as much to have it incorporated in Hansard as to continue to deliver it by way of an address to the Senate.
—Order! The Chair cannot accept that it is a written speech because honourable senators are not permitted to read their speeches.
—I would be quite happy for my copious notes to be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The notes read as follows-

One important fact about the nuclear weapons that come into our harbours is that they are all tactical weapons-designed for fighting the limited or theatre wars that Mr Hayden rejected so emphatically in his 1984 statement. If we were to take this policy statement seriously, the only nuclear-armed ships we should allow in our ports would be the large submarines that carry the intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMS). Fortunately there is no reason for these vessels to come anywhere near Australia.

This rather begs the question of what the other ships are doing here. They are certainly not defending Australia. Vice-President Quayle made it quite clear during his recent visit that the US would not be defending us from the more likely local threats. I imagine that if Australia were to be suddenly attacked by a regional but non-Communist power any US warships in Australian harbours would leave immediately and head for the horizon.

I don't want to comment in detail tonight on the recently tabled report of the standing committee on foreign affairs, defence and trade and its 39 recommendations-which could justly be described as 39 steps to nowhere in particular. For instance, recommendation 29 wonders whether spraying a nuclear-powered vessel that has suffered a melt-down in its reactor with water might not reduce the contamination. I suggest that the consenting members of the committee should be allocated a port and a long hose so that this experiment can be tried at the first opportunity.

Most recommendations rubber-stamp the existing regulations and safety plans. The recommendation on dry-docking (recommendation 37) is almost a verbatim rendering of the text of a letter from Mr Beazley to the committee describing his current policy.

Rubber stamp is a phrase that applies particularly well to the whole report. The committee was well aware that any conclusion that would exclude the warships would be unacceptable to both the Government and the Opposition. The evidence available to the committee was meagre on essential details and the conclusion-that there are only a few minor adjustments to be made-is dictated by the insistence of our ally, the US, that we accept their nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships or risk losing the alliance.

We run the risks of a nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed ship accident. We suffer the distress of hosting nuclear weapons that we have decided, for ourselves, not to develop or use. We make parts of our territory nuclear weapons targets. In return we enjoy the benefits of the nuclear umbrella, just like everyone else on earth. I believe that it is time for us to withdraw from the alliance. New Zealand did this somewhat indirectly and despite threats of `punishment', New Zealand has not suffered any dire consequences. New Zealand is not a `friend' of the United States. Australia, too, should upgrade its relationship with the United States from Ally to friend.

The ANZUS relationship began in fear and it had continued on this basis. The relationship is based on power, not friendship and not on the shared values that are often alluded to when the subject of ANZUS is raised.

When we discard this alliance we will be able to make practical arrangements for our defence with whomever we like; quite probably we will still have close contacts with the United States. We will feel better about ourselves, we will feel better about the Americans, they will probably regard us in a better light. Many developments that I have not had time to mention tonight point to an `independent' Australia in the future. One of these developments is the slogan of `self-reliance' that our Minister for Defence is promoting, let us hope that it soon becomes a reality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) no thanks for that because I have not written what I have to say and I am not in a position to incorporate it in Hansard. Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise tonight to make a contribution, modest and indelicate as it might be, on considerations in respect of Kakadu National Park. Might I say, with the greatest respect, that this debate in Cabinet epitomises the very standing of this Government. It demonstrates the confusion, the chaos, the vacillation and, frankly, this Government crudely in pursuit of votes, not in pursuit of the national interest. The history of Kakadu National Park stages 1, 2 and 3 is a litany of broken promises and lost opportunities which in many respects is the hallmark of this Government. Senator Richardson's attempts to have stage 3, including the conservation zone, locked up is the third occasion on which this Government has made a political decision totally removed and totally divorced from considerations of merit. The decisions in respect of stages 1, 2 and 3 have all been made without the competing national interests in any way being judged on their merits.

SPEECH.PARA: Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) is not the first mining company to feel the sharp end of this Government's vacillation, distortion, confusion and, ultimately, changing of facts. Let us look at the sorry saga, for instance, of Geopeko. Geopeko has had mining tenements granted to it since 1974 in what we now find to be stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. So since 1974, 15 years ago, it has had those tenements granted under title of the Crown, yet it has not been able to mine. On 20 February 1985, 11 years after those tenements were first applied for, the declaration of stage 2 was revoked so as to have it incorporated into the one plan and the one park-Kakadu National Park. In other words, stage 2 dissolved into stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park. When that created some anxiety, quite necessarily and naturally, on the part of the mining companies, Mr Cohen gave a comforting reassurance that the conditions in respect of mining, provision 56 of the plan of management, would not be in any way corrupted or altered and that it was simply an administrative advantage in terms of the management of the park.

As I say, the first plan of management provided quite explicitly for the exploitation and mining of minerals and metals within the park. As long ago as 1974, Dr Rex Patterson, the then Minister for the Northern Territory in the Labor Government, wrote in the following terms to Geopeko on 21 December 1975:

I refer to your applications for renewal of exploration licences Nos 219 and 220. These applications relate to areas that extend into the area proposed as a national park in the Alligator Rivers region.

It is the intention of the Government, at the February 1974 sittings of the Northern Territory Legislative Council, to introduce new legislation providing for the creation of national parks in the Northern Territory, and for the issue of rights under that legislation to allow prospecting to be carried out within those national parks under suitable conditions.
He concluded by saying:

I am authorised by the Government to assure you that, if your applications for renewal of licences are approved only in respect of areas outside the boundary of the proposed park, you will, upon commencement of the new legislation, be issued with fresh licences under that legislation in respect of the areas within the park boundary to which your current renewal applications relate.
Please be assured that my officers will be available to discuss any matter of concern to you.

In 1974 Geopeko was given an undertaking and assurance by a Labor government that the integrity of its mining tenements, which were impinged upon by the proposed stage 2 of Kakadu National Park, would retain their integrity. That was the first time that the Government had an opportunity to break its promise, and it did so. What happened to Geopeko during the years? Notwithstanding the assurances of Mr Cohen that the rules of the game would not change with the incorporation of stage 2 into stage 1, there was some anxiety by Geopeko. The company wrote to Mr Cohen asking him for an assurance that that was not to be the case. He wrote back to and assured the company that nothing had in any way changed. That anxiety by Geopeko was matched by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines, then Mr Coulter; and it was Mr Cohen who, on 16 September 1986, wrote to the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and said:

amalgamation of the two areas simply provided administrative advantages, allowing the whole park to be operated under the name `Kakadu National Park' and under one plan of management. . . . Conditions applying to any operations for the recovery of minerals were unchanged by the amalgamation of the two areas.

Not being satisfied with that, Geopeko discovered that a proposed plan of management that was circulating did not include provision for mining, so it wrote to the Government. It wrote to Senator Gareth Evans, then Minister for Minerals and Resources. He wrote back on 8 September 1986, saying:

my department has provided comments on the proposed Plan to the Director, National Parks and Wildlife which seek inclusion in the Plan of provisions for operations for the recovery of minerals similar to those in the first plan.
That was the assurance that had been received thus far by Mr Cohen. The letter went on:
Such an approach is necessary to give effect to the Plan's key management objective of developing an inventory of all renewable and non-renewable resources in the Park. You can be assured-
the words of Rex Patterson ringing again-

that I am following this issue carefully with the long term objective of establishing a multiple land use policy for the region which balances the interests of the mining industry with those of other land users.

In other words, Kakadu was to embrace, through the Government, the principle of multiple land use. That letter was dated 8 September. On 16 September-the very same day that Mr Cohen had written to give warm reassurance to Mr Coulter that the rules had not changed-the Government issued a press statement. A joint press statement by Mr Cohen and Senator Evans said:

The revised terms of the Plan of Management for Stages I and II to be submitted to Parliament will be along the lines of the draft Plan publicly circulated by the Director of Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. The provisions in question differ from the previous Plan . . .
In eight days they differed, notwithstanding a letter that same day signed by Mr Cohen saying they had not. The statement went on:
The provisions in question differ from the previous Plan, now expired, which enabled exploration and mining to take place outside the pre-existing leases with the approval of the Governor-General.

So we found that Geopeko had been grossly misled and that, in fact, the rules had changed and Geopeko was unable to explore within leases which had not yet been granted. To that extent, Geopeko was now losing its non-renewed tenements. But at least it still had its pre-existing tenements, because the statement talked only about no exploration or mining taking place outside the pre-existing leases. But the truth was to be found some weeks later. On 12 November the same year Geopeko, for the third time looking for reassurance that the Government had not only not moved the goalposts but had not dismantled them, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He wrote back saying:

While I recognise that Geopeko has a number of pre-existing mineral leases within Stage 2 that are protected under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, I reaffirm that no mineral exploration will be permitted outside those areas-
he was repeating what had been said by the press statement on 16 September-
and that the Government will not countenance any mining in Stages 1 and 2 . . .

The nonsense of that letter is that one could mine inside the pre-existing leases under the plan of management which required the approval of the Governor-General; it was simply that the Governor-General was not about to grant approval. So Geopeko discovered after this period between 1974 and 1986 that not only had it been misled but in fact it had lost title to the leases it had previously held. It is a matter of history now. We know that Geopeko went to the court and the Government's decision was overturned and that on appeal the Government was successful in its endeavours.

That is the second case where a decision was made for political reasons, whether it be right or wrong. For that reason it is probably worth my reminding Senator Tate of the events of 1986 on about 14 September when the Prime Minister was presumptuous enough and, I might add, in those days responsible enough to write to Mr Cohen. Because he had got a whiff that the plan of management did not include provision for mining, he wrote to Mr Cohen. He said that he was concerned about the absence in the draft management plan for Kakadu of any provision for the possible future recovery of minerals within the park. The Prime Minister was reported in the National Times of 14 September as pressing for mining to be allowed in the uranium rich Kakadu National Park in defiance of Australian Labor Party policy. According to the article, Mr Hawke's letter said that:
. . . a Cabinet review of the Government's policy restrictions on trade has identified access to mineral exploration and mining in Kakadu, and the proposed Stage three as one area in need of review.
The article continued:
The letter says: `With this in mind and given Australia's present current account deficit-
this was in 1986 when the current account deficit was about half of what it is now-
I would have serious reservations with any proposal that would result in the imposition of a more restrictive framework on potential mineral exploration development within Kakadu . . .
I ask therefore that you examine the full implications of not including a provision for the recovery of minerals in the draft plan prior to its finalisation.'

He was saying that the management plan prior to the amalgamation was restrictive and that he wanted something less restrictive. He wrote to Mr Cohen. If my memory serves me correctly, a Cabinet meeting was to be held on one of the Royal Australian Navy ships to consider this issue. Mr Cohen could see that there was an inevitable march against his position given the Prime Minister's imprimatur of Senator Evans's position, so Mr Cohen, to quote the National Times:
. . . was staggered by Mr Hawke's intervention and may raise the matter with Caucus if Cabinet forces the issue.
No wonder Mr Cohen slipped out the door backwards. Mr Cohen was reported as saying:
He believes the Government would be committing political suicide if it opens the park to mining because of the backlash from environmental, peace, and Aboriginal land rights groups.

This is the very argument being put now by the Prime Minister and by Senator Richardson, who at that time supported mining and are now saying that there should be no mining in stage 3 in the conservation zone because of opposition from the environmental groups, the peace groups and the Aboriginal land rights groups. Of course, Mr Cohen or his Department leaked the letter from the Prime Minister. It was thrown on the bonfire, so there was much uproar, rage and indignation via these groups. This followed the turmoil of the Government announcing in the Budget of 1986 that Australia was to sell uranium to France, breaking an inviolable platform of the Australian Labor Party. The Government, understanding the necessity of doing something about the balance of payments, had made that decision. It was in that environment that the Prime Minister and Senator Gareth Evans both got rolled. It had nothing to do with merit, virtue or economic responsibility; it was simply a decision made in the interests of political survival. That is what we are seeing again at present.

There are just one or two other matters that I wish to touch upon in the short time I have left. We have now had the spectacle of Senator Collins-unfortunately, I have not had an opportunity to read it all, and I am sorry I did not have an opportunity to tell him I was going to raise this; I did not think I was-writing to the members of Cabinet seeking to persuade them to a point of view. Without reading in detail what he has been saying, I understand that point of view is that the Jawoyn do not have a proper land claim, that there is merit in mining stage 3 and that there is some question about Coronation Hill being a sacred site. In fact, in his submission he quotes me from Hansard, asking questions of the Aboriginal community.

I wish to touch on one matter with respect to Senator Collins that I find disappointing. If my memory serves me correctly, Senator Collins brought some of his constituents to Canberra in 1987, prior to the Australian Labor Party's conference in Hobart. They came to Canberra to see the Prime Minister and to go to the conference. They were traditional owners of Koongarra and they were seeking to allow mining in the Koongarra area. They were to receive a benefit of $265m if the mining project went ahead. Mr George Hunt, a traditional owner and the oldest member of the delegation, urged that the mine go ahead, saying that he had seen many friends die waiting for a decision. Mr Hunt is regarded as the most senior traditional owner. They came down with the proper approval, and quite rightly so, of Senator Collins.

Yet when the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts prepared its report on the potential of the Kakadu National Park, the majority report refused to endorse mining of Koongarra. One of the signatories to the majority report was Senator Bob Collins. The minority report, written by me and signed by Senator McGauran and Senator Panizza, recommended mining in Koongarra. Senator Collins would not sign or support that minority report.

Senator Collins now, quite rightly in my view, makes the point that the Jawoyn people do not have a legitimate land claim in respect of what is described as the sickness country-a reasonably new phenomenon in Aboriginal anthropology, discovered some time in the last two or three decades. As I have pointed out in this chamber previously, the Jawoyn people have already made a land claim in the vicinity of UDP Falls, Coronation Hill and in the conservation zone. That land claim has been unsuccessful. The Commissioner found no intrinsic spiritual relationship between the Jawoyn people and that area. The only area he granted was area one, some 60 or 65 kilometres south of Coronation Hill.

In many respects that matter has been resolved. Yet the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, in 1986 made his position quite clear in respect of mining in Kakadu. At that point he was not taking a position as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs because he was not then the Minister but representing the Left of the Labor Party. He held that mining should not take place. Now he is telling us that under the heritage legislation he is obliged to take certain steps which will prevent mining.
I refer to page 310 of the minority report in respect of sacred sites on Coronation Hill:
Senator Crichton-Browne: Nipper Brown, do you remember ever asking the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority to register Coronation Hill as a sacred site?
Nipper Brown: No, never.
Senator Crichton-Browne: Did you ever want Coronation Hill for a sacred site?
Nipper Brown: No, never. There is nothing there.
Senator Crichton-Browne: There is nothing at Coronation Hill?
Nipper Brown: Nothing. It is free.
Senator Crichton-Browne: You never signed any piece of paper saying: ``Make Coronation Hill a sacred site''?
Nipper Brown: No.
Senator Crichton-Browne: Mr Barraway,-
one of the other Jawoyn elders-
have you ever signed anything asking for Coronation Hill to be made a sacred site?
Mr Barraway: No, I have never.
The reason I asked both those gentlemen was that it is alleged that they sought an application to make Coronation Hill a sacred site, and they are shown on the application as the applicants. I asked:
Have you ever thought of Coronation Hill as a sacred site?
Mr Barraway: No.
It was after some further inquiry that we discovered that it was alleged that they had in fact signed the application form which they now disowned.

Then we addressed the question of the Bula and the sickness country and significance of the area generally. Nipper Brown was recognised as the senior elder amongst those present. The report continues:
Senator Crichton-Browne: There is no bula on Coronation Hill?
Nipper Brown: Nothing.
Senator Crichton-Browne: So the Coronation Hill area is not a sacred site area?
Nipper Brown: Nothing. It is free.
Senator Crichton-Browne: Did some people make a mistake and think Coronation Hill was a sacred site?
Nipper Brown: It is free.
Senator Crichton-Browne: Are you happy for BHP to explore on Coronation Hill?
Nipper Brown: We are all happy if they go ahead and explore for gold or anything like that.
Senator Crichton-Browne: Is there a senior elder amongst the men here today? Who is the senior man?
Nipper Brown: I am.
Senator Crichton-Browne: You are the chief?
Nipper Brown: Yes.

We had previously received evidence from Ms Wynjorroc and Ms Flora that there was no Bula at Coronation Hill and it had no intrinsic spiritual value. They said that it was of no significance. It is not without consequence to note that in respect of the Jawoyn Katherine area land claim before Justice Kearney-it was Ms Wynjorroc and Ms Flora who gave evidence. Therefore they are presumably judged by the Jawoyn people to be an authority.

There is some considerable debate in respect to BHP's activities in the area. I am certainly no apologist for the mining companies, least of all BHP. In further evidence to the Committee at Barunga by the Jawoyn people on 9 March, the transcript reads:
Chairman-Are the Jawoyn people happy with the situation at present where BHP has a permit for exploration?
Mr Fordiman-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have the Jawoyn people always been happy with their negotiations with BHP?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Byer: Yes.

He was also one of the elders. The evidence on page 315 continues in that light. It is clear from the evidence received from the Aboriginal community that Coronation Hill is not sacred site, is not a Bula, is not part of the sickness country, and it is not an area of intrinsic spiritual value, which Aborigines judge ought not be mined. In fact, at a meeting of the Jawoyn people they gave approval to BHP. Perhaps it ought to be remembered that half of the total employees on the BHP site are Jawoyn and there are something like 60 Jawoyn people presently on the waiting list requesting work on the site.

It is a great tragedy that these people are being used and manipulated, harassed and bullied and encouraged under duress to change their minds as to the real position. I am ever so sorry that we now find Senator Collins flying into the fray, casting doubt upon Coronation Hill in terms of the Aboriginal relationship with it. Those points were made. Those conclusions were to be found in the minority report, contrary to the majority report, and yet every member of the Labor Party on the Committee signed the majority report and refused to sign the minority report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
